column2: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Feb. 10 -- Premier Lon Nol suffered a stroke Monday that paralyzed half his body, reliable sources close to the Cambodian Government said today. An official statement said he had been ordered to stop all activities for medical reasons.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- A new effort to impose legislative restrictions on the war-making powers of the President began in the Senate today amid indications that there is conservative support for it in Congress.
The nuclear power plant whose shutdown nine months ago started a drawn-out electrical power squeeze for New Yorkers has gone back into service, the Consolidated Edison Company announced yesterday.
LONDON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Two girls who went to work in hot pants were in hot water today for raising male temperatures and lowering the production of British cars and cookies.
Mrs. Phoebe Wildman van Beuren and John D. Archbold, the sportsman and Standard Oil heir, plan to be married, but have not yet set the date for their wedding.
A helicopter carrying several news photographers was shot down yesterday in Laos. There was no indication of survivors.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The Federal Communications Commission revived and expanded today a inquiry into broadcast ownership.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10 (UPI) -Mike Pelyk drove a shot from the point into the Chicago Black Hawk net with less than four minutes to play tonight to give the Toronto Maple Leafs a 3-2 National Hockey League victory.

City environmental officials are trying in negotiations now going on to improve garbage collection by changing the deployment of sanitationmen, which they believe "shortchanges both labor and management."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Retail sales, seasonally adjusted, rose about $300-million in January on the basis of preliminary estimates, the Census Bureau reported today.

West Virginia's tall band of running and shooting Mountaineers will challenge Rutgers hopes for postseason tournament bid in the second half of the college double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 10 -A 16-year-old boy who acted as his own attorney in State Supreme Court to challenge a restriction that prohibits holders of junior operators' licenses from driving in Nassau County won his case today.
Mrs. John N. Mitchell thinks anyone who advocates violent revolution in the United States should be shipped off to Cuba on the next plane.
PARIS, Feb. 10 -- There were growing signs today that the Middle Eastern oil dispute would be settled -- at a price that would mean bigger fuel bills for Western Europe and Japan.

SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 10 -- The police arrested a 15-year-old nephew of the opposition presidential candidate Kim Dae Jung, today, on charges of setting off a homemade toy bomb at Mr. Kim's residence here two weeks ago.
MOSCOW, Feb. 10 -- The Soviet Union accused the United States today of undermining the Big Four talks on the Middle East by its support of Israeli positions.

BUFFALO, Feb. 10 -- The Knickerbockers lost their fifth successive game, the longest streak of Red Holzman's New York coaching career, but more importantly, they lost Willis Reed for five days as they dropped a 106-99 decision to the Buffalo Braves tonight.
A physician and two lawyers were indicted by a Federal grand jury here yesterday on charges of a conspiracy to extort $10,000 from another doctor.

GRANADA HILLS, Calif., Feb. 10 -- For the 80,000 persons evacuated from 20 square miles of pleasant suburban neighborhoods below the lingering threat of an earthquakedamaged dam, there is nothing to do but wait.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 10 -- Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky said today that South Vietnamese forces would probably remain in Laos until the dry season ends in May and predicted that they would go in again next year.
PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 10 (AP) -- Marty Fleckman carded a six-under-par 66 for a one-stroke lead over Arnold Palmer in the first round today of the five-day, 90-hole Bob Hope Desert Classic.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -The major Democratic Presidential contenders agreed at a meeting last night, in the interests of party unity, to refrain from attacking one another, Lawrence F. O'Brien, the party chairman, said today.

HOUSTON, Feb. l0 -- Scientific instruments left on the moon by Apollo astronauts survived without any apparent damage despite the sudden and sharp drop in surface temperatures as a result of this morning's lunar eclipse.

New York has never seen a staged performance of Berlioz's Vergilian epic "Les Troyens," but judging from the revivalist tremor in the air it should not be long before someone gives us the four-hour opera in full.

ROME, Feb. 10 -- An angry delegation of doctors, lawyers, architects and other professional men told Premier Emilio Colombo today that a proposed fiscal reform discriminated against them. The group threatened to call a strike of unlimited duration unless the legislation was amended.

TRENTON, Feb. 10 -- William F. Hyland, former chairman of the New Jersey State Commission on Investigation, testified today that organized crime was plotting to infiltrate gambling casinos if the latter were legalized in Atlantic City.

A Manhattan insurance company has been ordered by a Federal Court jury in Brooklyn to pay $70,000 above its liability because it failed to act "in good faith" in negotiating for out-of-court settlement.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 10 -- The Ulster Government moved today to stop Roman Catholic militants from flaunting symbols of the illegal Irish Republican Army.

The trustees of two carriers in reorganization, the Boston Maine and the Central Railroad of New Jersey, are taking steps to get the Transportation Department's guarantee of $10-million of trustee certificates for each line.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (UPI) -- The House Democratic leadership urged President Nixon today to freeze wages and prices immediately to curb inflation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The Council of Economic Advisers fully expects the gross national product this year to attain approximately the target figure of $1,065-billion and the figure was not "imposed" on the council for political reasons, a member of the group said today.
HAWTHORNE, N. J, Feb. 10 -- Tom Gorman won a match but lost a doubles partner today in the $30,000 Clean Air Tennis Classic.

Lewis L. Colasurdo, former president of the Crescent Corporation, was sentenced yesterday, in Federal District Court here, to two years in prison and was fined $50,000. The 55-year-old Hammonton, N. J., man had been convicted of conspiring in securities dealings that involved control of Crescent, a conglomerate company.

Congratulations for printing the article by Dr. M. T. Mehdi -- "Israel: Is It a Democracy?" It is not only enlightening and objective, but in its concluding two paragraphs recommending a secular, pluralistic society in the interest of democracy, is a constructive suggestion for peace in the Holy Land.

There have been many proposals for aid to the unemployed including extension of unemployment benefits, higher benefit payments, and deferred mortgage payments. Fortunately, at least one of these proposals has seen the light of day -- the extension of benefits.

SAIGON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- South Vietnamese sources reported that after the task force reached Tchepone today engineers began rebuilding the town's abandoned dirt airstrip, which will enable the South Vietnamese to fly in supplies and reinforcements.

MIAMI, Feb. 10 -- Jacinto Vasquez, the leading rider at New York tracks last year, is only second best at Hialeah this winter and he will start a fiveday suspension on Friday. But he was the leading figure at Hialeah today as he won both halves of the $50,250 Columbiana Handicap for fillies with a versatile riding exhibition.
The stock market caught its breath yesterday as prices mostly declined in the slowest trading in almost two weeks.

MOSCOW, Feb. 10 -- The Soviet Union's long-awaited economic plan for 1971-75 is to be made public soon, in time for nationwide discussion before the opening of the 24th congress of the Communist party on March 30.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The Navy plans to develop hydrofoils and craft capable of riding over land or sea on a cushion of forced air at speeds two to three times as fast as any existing naval craft.

The impending collision of two oil tankers near the Golden Gate Bridge recently was spotted on the screen of an experimental shore-based radar but could not be averted because officials on shore were unable to contact the bridge of one of the vessels involved.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 10 -There was nothing scientifically cool about Charles Francis Richter's initial reaction to yesterday's earthquake. "He jumped up screaming and scared the cat," according to his wife, the former Lillian Brand.
About 2,000 persons demonstrated here last evening against the Laos incursion and about 3,000 marched on the Boston Common.

JERSEY CITY, Feb. 10 -- Ed Cierski's two free throws with 13 seconds remaining broke an 85-85 tie and earned St. Peter's College a 87-85 victory over Manhattan College tonight before 1,882 at the Jersey City Armory.

Wiretapping and bugging now appear to be the wave of the future in American law enforcement, and all those who think the resulting diminution of personal privacy and individual liberty is a good thing should stand up and cheer the American Bar Association.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Feb. 10 -When Howard R. Hughes lived in the penthouse at the Desert Inn Hotel, equipment in his suite included a medical table, stands to hold blood during transfusions, oxygen dispensers, cardiographic instruments and other surgical and examining devices.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 10 -- Torpor runs high in Vientiane, the most lively town in Laos, on any day, so it is difficult to tell that today is Makhabouxa, a major Buddist feast and public holiday. But to those interested in official activities it became plain by midmorning that Government offices, instead of opening late, were not opening at all.
The uncritical and sweeping remarks made by Dr. M. T. Mehdi about the faith of Islam call for comments.
NEWARK, Feb. 10 -- Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson announced today the formation of an Office of Newark Studies to provide his office with help from colleges in the Newark area.

The welfare worker suspended from the Department of Social Services for helping to place a welfare family in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel testified yesterday that he had followed all department procedures before receiving superiors' approval to book the family there.

Pablo Picasso has donated to the Museum of Modern Art one of the rarest and most sought-after sculptures of the classic Cubist period -"Guitar" (1912), a construction made of sheet metal and wire that virtually changed the course of sculpture in this century.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The Federal Trade Commission accused two of the country's largest mail order houses today of violating the Truth-in-Lending Act.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 10 (UPI) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers obtained Al Downing, a lefthanded pitcher, from the Milwaukee Brewers today in exchange for an outfielder, Andy Kosco.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation announced yesterday it was laying off up to 6,500 employes as a result of the financial collapse of RollsRoyce, Ltd., and the British concern's inability to make scheduled deliveries of engines for Lockheed's new airbus.
New York City hospitals, plagued with cost problems and understaffing, are increasingly relying on the use of computers in major areas of medical care.
WASHINGTON -- As we read about, live through, and see one environmental crisis after another, perhaps the most difficult task facing each of us is to put the environmental picture into perspective.

MUCII WA URATA, Kenya, Feb. 1 -- When Charles Mugo left school more than a year ago at the end of the seventh grade, he had little to look forward to except helping his father make a subsistence living on the family shamba, or small farm.
PARIS, Feb. 10 -- Any possibility of serious negotiation at the Vietnam peace talks has apparently been written off for the next few months by the United States.
A four-day holiday weekend, created by changes in Federal and state laws, is beckoning New Yorkers by the thousands to warm resorts, snow-layered slopes and as far away as Europe.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 10 -- Concern increased here today over the situation at Sam Thong and Long Tieng, the two important Government positions southwest of Plaine des Jarres that have come under increasing pressure from North Vietnamese and Laotian Communist forces.
TRENTON, Feb. 10 -- Gov. William T. Cahill said today that he would not recommend any new or increased taxes in his budget message to the New Jersey Legislature next Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- President Nixon's latest welfare reform plan has been before the new Congress for less than a month, and it already is in serious trouble.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 10 -- Concern increased here today over the situation at Sam Thong and Long Tieng, the two important Government positions southwest of Plaine des Jarres that have come under increasing pressure from North Vietnamese and Laotian Communist forces.
TRENTON, Feb. 10 -- Gov. William T. Cahill said today that he would not recommend any new or increased taxes in his budget message to the New Jersey Legislature next Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- President Nixon's latest welfare reform plan has been before the new Congress for less than a month, and it already is in serious trouble.

Enzyme additives, which have been under attack as a health hazard, are being removed from the Procter Gamble Company's Tide, the largest-selling detergent in the country, according to union officials at the company's plant on Staten Island.
KINGSTON, R. I., Feb. 11 -- Fordham, led by Charlie Yelverton's 27 points, overwhelmed Rhode Island, 109-87, to record its fifth straight victory and 17th triumph in 18 games this season.
BURBANK, Calif., Feb. 11 (AP) -- A Lockheed spokes-

In his messages to Congress, while leading a war of fire and conscience in his own land, Abraham Lincoln called attention to the need for the United States to be a force for mediation and peace among all nations. He did not put limitations of "honor" in his timetable for peace; his word for it was "forbearance" in our foreign relations.
QUANG TRI, South Vietnam, Feb. 11 (AP) -- It appeared doubtful today that troops could reach the site of a helicopter shot down in southern Laos with four press photographers aboard.
Cornell University scientists have developed an electron beam intense enough to produce the enormously high temperatures needed for fusing hydrogen atoms into helium atoms.
LONDON, Feb. 11 -- The British Government agreed today to keep the Rolls-Royce RB-211 jet-engine project going for three more weeks.
The Collegiate School, the nation's oldest independent day school, announced yesterday that it had ended a search of more than a year with the appointment of Paul B. Mott Jr. as its 23d headmaster.

Robert Ilario, Sy Holsman and Gary Alleccia, whose motto is "stay out of electronics," are friends and prospective business partners who were seeking a new line of work yesterday at the opening of the 13th annual Start Your Own Business Exposition at the New York Coliseum.
The sharpest political satire in town at the moment is being presented by the Paul Taylor Dance Company on its third program in the City Center American Dance Season at the ANTA Theater.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Feb. 11 -- The Brazilian Government has charged a Roman Catholic priest and his assistant, a social worker, with subversion 10 days after they were arrested here by the political police.

Muhammad Ali, the compulsive conversationalist, has long been the delight of promoters, publicity men and sports writers on the prowl for quotable quotes. He's like one of those mechanical dolls the gagsters used to make jokes about a few years ago. Wind him up and he talks. But no one ever had to crank up the former Cassius Clay. The words just spilled forth.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 11 -The threat of flooding from a damaged reservoir dam decreased steadily, and tile tension that had gripped Los Angeles since Tuesday's earthquake began to unwind.
HOUSTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -Scientists prepared the Lunar Receiving Laboratory here today for the arrival of the Apollo 14 astronauts and the scientifically precious rocks they brought from the moon.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11 -- Villanova never expected things to be so easy tonight as the Wildcats controlled the boards, worked the fast break with profitable abandon and trounced Notre Dame, 99-81, before 9,289 persons in the Palestra.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 11 -- Seated on stage, clipboard in hand and busily scratching changes in and out of the colorfully marked typescript of his first play, Theodore H. White, journalist, historian and chonicler of the quadrennial American rush to political power, had the happy look of a bespectacled gnome held spellbound by the echo of his own words.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -The reopening of the Suez Canal under an Egyptian proposal that is receiving wide attention would benefit the Soviet Union, the United States and Western European powers, but all have been circumspect about commenting on the proposal, made a week ago by President Anwar el-Sadat.
HARTFORD, Feb. 11 (AP) -The current "scare" about mercury poisoning in food "is for the birds," says the chairman of Harvard's nutrition department.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- A bill to implement a compromise plan that would spare a group of condemned homes in Corona, Queens, was filed in the Legislature today along with a request from Mayor Lindsay for the "earliest possible" approval.

BRUSSELS -- If, as suggested in a previous column, gigantic figures no longer dominate international relationships, the obvious substitute for personal ascendancy is a continuation of the existing momentum of national policies. In this respect, Soviet Russia benefits.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 11 -- The presidents of the big national construction unions said today that they would put forward no program of their own in response to President Nixon's request that prompt action be taken to end the wage and price spiral in their industry.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- The House Republican leader, Gerald R. Ford, did not report $11,500 in campaign contributions last fall from stock brokers, an oilman, bankers, doctors and a union group.
ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- Two Republican legislators introduced bills in the Senate and Assembly today to postpone the scheduled June primary this year to Sept. 14.
LONDON, Feb. 11 (Reuters) -- Britain's overseas trade showed a deficit of $26,4-million in January, the Government announced today.
The city's Commissioner of Air Resources called yesterday for amendments to Federal antipollution legislation to require better pollution-control devices on existing cars as well as new cars.
The "new" Ron Swoboda, who said he had matured, signed his 1971 Mets' contract yesterday, along with his close friend and restaurant partner, Ed Kranepool.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11 -- Dennis Ralston says he is playing better than ever. After tonight's convincing 7-5, 6-4 victory over fourth-seeded Tony Roche in the $62,500 Philadelphia International Indoor tourney, there is every reason to believe him.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The Department of Transportation said today that airlines could solve their financial crisis by trimming their schedules, without a fare increase.

The Federal Government ordered an immediate "embargo" yesterday on its contributions to New York City's slum-clearance program, charging that the city had failed to find "decent, safe and sanitary" housing for families displaced by the program.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 11 (AP) -- Arnold Palmer managed only a one-under-par 71 but moved into a share of first place today in the second round of the $140,000 Bob Hope Desert Classic golf tournament.
The stock market picked up some steam yesterday as prices and volume rose after Wednesday's slowdown.

GENEVA, Feb. 11 -- A conference called by the United Nations to negotiate a new international agreement to stabilize world trade in wheat has lowered its sights by abandoning hope of getting an accord covering prices.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 11 (UPI) -- Pete Hamilton and David Pearson won a pair of qualifying races by the narrowest of margins today to nail down high starting positions for the Daytona 500 stock car classic on Sunday.

"Why Not," a feature-length film by Arakawa, the young New York conceptual painter, is the current movie, showing through Feb. 17, in the Whitney Museum's New American Film Makers Series. I shall be very much surprised if it does not become the hit of the series, a veritable succes de scandale, of which there have recently been depressingly few in the avant-garde cinema scene.
Perhaps it was audacious of the composer Henry Brant to take Beethoven's String Quartet, Op. 131, and rescore it for woodwind quintet. Some will even deem it sacrilegious, some just foolish.

The Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company, Inc., America's largest food retailer, which has improved its sagging profits but not solved its interracial problems, announced yesterday the early retirement of Melvin W. Alldredge, its chairman and chief executive officer, effective April 16.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -The Interior Department disclosed today that seven of the 13 appointments Under Secretary Fred J. Russell was required to make for an expert advisory council on coal mine safety were persons without mining or engineering experience but with strong credentials in the Republican party.
The recent ruling of Appellate Justices Capozzoli, McGivern, Markewich and Nunez in favor of returning an adopted child, Lenore De Martinos, to her natural mother is inhumane and unprecedented.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 11 (UPI) -- United States headquarters said today that 24 Americans were killed in battle in Vietnam last week, the lowest seven-day toll this year. But South Vietnamese combat deaths increased sharply.

The love affair between the Nixon Administration and the hardhats in the construction unions seems to have foundered on the age-old rock of freer entry for blacks into skilled building jobs. The unions have announced their determination to fight new apprenticeship rules proposed by the Labor Department, even though two years of top-level negotiation preceded their issuance last month.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 11 -- Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, the United Nations intermediary in the indirect Middle East peace talks here, is understood to have sent written questions to Israel and the United Arab Republic in an effort to get them to respond to each other's views.
SAPPORO, Japan, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Julie Holmes earned the United States its first gold medal of International Winter Sports Week today with a sparkling victory in figure skating.

Prices of frozen orange juice concentrate dropped yesterday following a Government crop report. The report indicated that supplies of Florida oranges are larger than last year despite talk of the effects of a freeze.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The United States and the Soviet Union today signed the new treaty barring nuclear weapons from the ocean floor. The area covers about 70 per cent of the earth's surface.

MOSCOW, Feb. 11 (AP) -Reliable Soviet sources said today that Simas A. Kudirka, the Lithuanian sailor who was refused political asylum in the United States after he had jumped aboard a Coast Guard cutter last November, is well and living in a new apartment.

Venezuela's Minister of Mines and Hydrocarbons predicted yesterday that the international oil companies would not come to an agreement with the major petroleum-exporting nations before the Feb. 15 deadline set by these states.

Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., the giant mutual-fund group, was sued here yesterday along with several I.O.S. companies and their major benefactor, the International Controls Corporation, on charges that included "fraud manipulative devices and contrivances."
PINE BLUFF, Ark., Feb. 11 (AP) -- Many white pupils walked out of Watson Chapel High School shortly after classes opened today as the district began operating under a courtordered desegregation plan.

MADISON, Wis., Feb. 11 -A Federal grand jury indicted today three Army enlisted men, one o them a Vietnam War veteran, on charges of stealing explosives and blowing up a telephone exchange, an electric substation and a water works at Camp McCoy, Wis., last July.

SARATOGA, Tex. -- The lumbermen who cut its oak and pine and magnolia call the Big Thicket a "romantic state of mind." Their trade association says that the bears exist now only in the natives' tall tales, that the wilderness is no longer primeval and that the whole brooding area "differs chiefly from the rest of east Texas in being a little flatter, a little wetter and possessed of more abundant crawfish."

LONDON, Feb. 11 -- Near the docks of London's seamy East End, Mrs. Jane Kerr sits in the living room of her four-room tenement flat and sips a cup of tea. Her feet are swollen and her hands tremble. Her first husband died of cancer and her second husband has moved to Liverpool.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The Air Force announced today that it would cut back the development program of its new B-1 strategic bomber -- successor to the aging B-52 -- to save money and to get the more advanced aircraft ready for production a little sooner than originally planned.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UPI) -- The Senate confirmed today the nominations of fivedirectors of the Securities Investment Protection Corporation.
The generally depressed business climate, pushed 1970 earnings of the Avco Corporation 59 per cent below from the level the year before on a sales drop of 16 per cent.

By now it should be evident to Hanoi that the United States is leaving the field of battle. North Vietnam has not been invaded, and with the diminishing forces south of its border, the possibility of trespass on its territory hits the vanishing point. Has it then occurred to Hanoi that it is time for its forces to stay home?

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UPI) -- Citing at least four injuries, the Food and Drug Administration issued a public warning yesterday against the "clacker," a toy enjoying a popularity surge similar to that of the hula-hoop in years past.

Some months ago I wrote an article, "The Artist as the Enemy," at the kind suggestion of The Times. This article in somewhat edited form was published on the Op-Ed page on Oct. 24. Following this, the article was reprinted and reprinted again in many countries. It was not political but was of strictly philosophical character.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UPI) -- Elliot L. Richardson ordered today a review of the Public Health Service's commissioned corps, a quasimilitary force of 6,000 uniformed officers that has done research and provided medical services for nearly a century.

With a lock of his hair, his purse and his spectacles, a great - great - great - granddaughter of Sir Walter Scott was here to celebrate the 200th anniversary of his birth and to invite New Yorkers to celebrate it in Scotland this summer.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 11 (UPI) -- The Pittsburgh Steelers, looking at the bright side of Chuck Noll's rebuilding program rather than his teams' records, extended his contract as head coach today for two years through 1973.

Reports broadcast by the American Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System yesterday said that American ground troops were taking part in the South Vietnamese incursion into southern Laos, some in South Vietnamese uniforms.

Hoping to get more motorists to switch to mass transit, and spurred by the success of the special bus lane on the main New Jersey approach to the Lincoln Tunnel, transportation agencies here have prepared plans to make bus travel even faster and more attractive.
KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Feb. 11 -- President Nixon's annual review of foreign policy -known as the "State of the World" message -- will be made public Feb. 25, the White House said today.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Ruben Navarro, the lightweight contender from Los Angeles who gained a crack at the title as a last-minute substitute, might prove a rugged opponent for the champion, Ken Buchanan of Scotland, when they meet in a 15-round bout tomorrow night in the Sports Arena.
The following review originally appeared on Sept. 19, 1970, when the film was shown at the New York Film Festival. The movie is being exhibited here commercially at the Lincoln Art Theater.

RAE BARELI, India, Feb. 4 -If anything is close to certain in India's unpredictable national election early next month, it is that Prime Minister Indira Gandhi will be re-elected to Parliament by her own district.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- Spotlighting their behind-the-scenes struggle to succeed Governor Rockefeller, Lieut. Gov. Malcolm Wilson and Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea Jr. will speak at rival Republican dinners in Brooklyn tomorrow night.

The new Danish pastry arriving yesterday at the New Embassy Theater with the title of "Relations" is as dull as it is dirty. This is the tired old saw about no fool like an old fool, as a graying prosperous businessman gets hooked by a pretty, slimy sensualist, with the expected ugly consequences.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Total business sales rose in December for the first time since July, the Commerce Department reported today.

One of the most pleasing incidental acts of the Ballet of the 20th Century has been to return Suzanne Farrell to the New York stage even if only for a brief tour of three weeks. Wednesday evening Miss Farrell and Jorge Donn danced the lovers in Maurice Bejart's "Romeo and Juliet Suite," seen in the United States for the first time at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

YONKERS, Feb. 11 -- Making his first start of the year in this country, Herve Filion drove Mountain Pride N. to a come-from-behind victory in tonight's feature mile handicap trot at Yonkers Raceway. Minutes after the reinsman had received the plaudits of the fans, he said he had no special plans to surpass the world record of 486 triumphs he set in 1970.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The British Government's announcement that it was extending the Rolls RB-211 engine program for another three weeks followed a request that it do so by David Packard, the Deputy Secretary of Defense, well-placed informants said today.
The Cosmos, New York's entry in the North American Soccer League, will compete in the Northern Division of the eight-team loop when the expanded league opens its season in April.

The Port of New York Authority, in an abrupt move, said yesterday that it would, in effect, re-examine its role in mass transit in the New York metropolitan area. The Port Authority has long been a target of criticism from politicians, civic leaders and citizens' groups for its seemingly overwhelming commitment to automotive transportation and its reluctance to move more of its activities -- and money -- into mass transit.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Senator Henry M. Jackson predicted today that powerful elements of the Democratic party would "insist" on the nomination of a 1972 Presidential candidate with "a responsible position in the area of national security."
MILWAUKEE, Feb. 11 (AP) -- With Lew Alcindor and Oscar Robertson dominating play, the Milwaukee Bucks crushed the Los Angeles Lakers, 122-88, in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

Eastern railroads, in an attempt to secure repeal of what they call "excess crew" laws of New York, Indiana and Ohio, announced yesterday plans for filing tariffs that would permit them to collect a surcharge of $10 on each car of freight either originating or terminating in the three states.
"Give the kids a break" seems to be the underlying message in a Ted Bates Co. New York ad that will be running in the Feb. 22 issue of Time magazine.

The travesty of the decision of the New York State Supreme Court, which returned a screaming, protesting Richard Bacile to his natural mother whom he had never known, is the final proof that a preconceived notion of the rights of the natural mother is based not in fact but in faulty principles.

Mel Davis and Greg Cluess put out their best scoring efforts of the season last night to lead St. John's to an 82-71 victory over Niagara before 3,912 fans at the Redmen's gymnasium in Jamaica, Queens.

PARIS, Feb. 11 -- Communist representatives at the Vietnam peace talks said today that 10 American battalions were engaged in ground combat in Laos and named the divisions the units came from -- the Fifth Mechanized, the 101st Airborne and the Americal. But the American spokesman, Stephen Ledogar, accusing the Communists of "heaping exaggerations upon lies," said, "That's all nonsense."

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 11 (UPI) -- Eddie Westfall scored three goals tonight for the second time in his 10-year career in the National Hockey League and led the Boston Bruins to a 5-3 victory over the St. Louis Blues.
Witness after witness complained to the State Attorney General yesterday of what they called exorbitant and often misrepresented fees charged by commercial abortion referral agencies.

The Rutgers band and the Rutgers basketball team brought a sparse Madison Square Garden crowd to life last night after New York University lulled the fans into sleepiness while failing to gain its first two-game winning streak of the season.
The restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored where indicated.

TRENTON, Feb. 11 -- State Attorney General George F. Kugler Jr. ruled today that it was legal to hold another referendum in New Jersey next November on whether to lower the voting age of 21 to 18 in state and local elections.

While his teammates were traveling to Atlanta for a game tonight against the Hawks, Willis Reed of the Knicks flew here from Buffalo yesterday for treatment of tendonitis in his left knee that will sideline him until Tuesday.

CONCORD, N. H., Feb. 11 -Gov. Walter R. Peterson Jr. proposed today that New Hampshire give up its position as the last holdout in the nation against broadbased state taxes and enact a 3 per cent state income tax.

Capt. Alan B. Shepard Jr., the first man to hit a golf ball on the moon, will be honored with a "Mulligan Award" at the Metropolitan Golf Writers Association's annual awards dinner Tuesday at the Hotel Americana.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- The State Public Service Commission told Governor Rockefeller, in a report made public today, that there was little prospect of substantial improvement in electric generating capacity in this state during the next few months.

WASHINGTON -- Like New Yorkers who live in the shadow of the Empire State Building but have never been to the top, Tom Lumpkin and his family never went through the White House until this week, even though they live less than 10 miles from it.

Trout Unlimited and the Association of Northwest Steelheaders, together representing about 12,000 sportsmen - conservationists, have joined forces. Trout Unlimited is a national organization dedicated to the conservation and protection of trout and salmon and the waters that support them.
Prof. Daniel G. Collins, the first state chairman of the New Democratic Coalition, has decided that he will not run for the office again when his term expires in March.

FREEPORT, the Bahamas, Feb. 11 -- Members of the group that represents most of the principals and other supervisors in the New York City school system arrived here by chartered plane this evening for the start of their annual convention and learned, to the surprise of many, that their major speaker would be Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner.

They're leading women to the guillotine at the Saks Fifth Avenue beauty salon. Willingly, at that. The salon's newest hair chopping technique is called the Guill otine Cut, and although the idea is rather terrifying, the result is the layered (or "lion") tresses many young women are sporting these days.

The young players (ages 12 to 21) did this by presenting a program that featured Prokofiev's "Alexander Nevsky" and also included Beethoven's Fantasy for Piano, Chorus and Orchestra (Op. 80) and music from Ives's "Washington's Birthday."

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 14 -- Richard Petty, who has won more money at stock-car racing than anyone else, captured the Daytona 500 today to become the first three-time victor in that annual race for late-model stock cars. It was Petty's 120th victory in 13 seasons of competition in this class.

"Tight conditions" for electricity will "continue for the next two to three years" for New York City and Westchester County customers, and not until 1974 or 1975 will there be a "comfortable reserve" again, a Consolidated Edison Company spokesman warned yesterday.
HOUSTON, Feb. 14 -- For the second time in 20 years, a Houston independent oil operator of the "big rich" class has fallen on hard times.

BONN, Feb. 14 -- The United States, Britain and France have proposed to the Soviet Union that West Berlin forgo its claim to be an integral part of the West German Republic, Western allied sources said here today.

CRANFORD, N. J., Feb. 14 -- Ch. Varga's Tijuana Brass, a perky, fawn and white 2-year-old, was judged best in show at the 17th annual Chihuahua Club of Mid-Jersey unbenched specialty at Veterans Memorial Hall today.

A city proposal to impose a tax on the now tax-exempt Port of the New York Authority in place of voulntary payments "in lieu of taxes" was criticized by the Port Authority yesterday as an apparent product of "confusion and misunderstanding."
Leopold Stokowski made his contribution to Beethoven's 200th anniversary year in the American Symphony Orchestra concert yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 14 -- Twenty-three Western oil companies agreed today to additional payments of more than $10-billion to six Persian Gulf states for a five-year oil agreement intended to stabilize the crisis-prone industry.
State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz charged yesterday that an oral "test of reasoning" used to select steamfitting apprentices was discriminatory.
Walter R. Fletcher of The New York Times received two awards at the Dog Writers' Association of America annual dinner at the Statler Hilton Hotel last night.

Many people have the notion that it really doesn't pay to shop around for automobile insurance because the cost is pretty much the same, regardless of the company you're talking to.

IRON MOUNTAIN, Mich. Feb. 14 (AP) -- Jerry Martin, 20-year-old United States champion, set a North American ski jumping record of 345 feet today in the first round of the Kiwanis Ski Club invitation meet on Pine Mountain.
SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 14 (AP) -- Lenny Schloss returned to his home state today and defeated Brazil's Ronnie Barnes, 6-2, 7-6, at the start of the national indoor open tennis championships today.

KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Feb. 14 (UPI) -- President Nixon flew back from the Bahamas today and spent a quiet Valentine's Day here with his family.

BEAUPRE, Quebec, Feb. 14 -- Shaggy-haired Patrick Russel of France, who arrived in Canada earlier this week ranking fourth in World Cup competition catapaulted himself into the lead today with a pair of all-or-nothing winning slalom performances.

DENVER, Feb. 14 -- The Sierra Club, one of the nation's most influential conservation groups, called today for repeal of the Homestead Act and any other laws that allow the Government to sell or give away public lands.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Two former Army lieutenants say that superiors allowed officers to cheat on qualifying exams for posts that put them in a position to supervise the firing of defensive nuclear missiles, according to The Daily Oklahoman.

The Columbia Broadcasting System said yesterday that members of its news department were being dismissed as part of the general 15 per cent budget cut instituted by the company. The acknowledgment followed several reports late last week that C.B.S. News personnel here and in Washington were being let go.

Among the current fund-raising devices is the tennis benefit: for $25 you can challenge Clark Graebner to a minimatch in front of your friends. According to Gene Scott, who has promoted a number of these shows, the exhibition tennis match is "replacing theater benefits and white elephant sales.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 14 -- Chile's first hundred days on the road to socialism have shown President Salvador Allende Gossens to be clearly in charge of his left-wing Government.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 14 -- As the steel inventory buildup continues to gain momentum, two problems loom larger and larger. Rolling-mill capacity limitations will cause delivery lead times to extend and this problem will be compounded by a shortage of transportation facilities -- both rail cars and trucks.
Cheers and tears, greeted the victory yesterday in a return to the ring by a retired Irish terrier champion in the 54th specialty show of the Associated Terrier Club at the 102d Engineers Armory.

PARIS, Feb. 14 -- The Persian Gulf oil settlement was expected to have far-reaching consequences, not all of them unfavorable, for the West.
PONTIAC, Mich., Feb. 14 -- The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation today agreed to its biggest cash injection in history to insure uninterrupted operations of a defunct bank -- $100-million.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board has denied United Air Lines permission to raise fares slightly in 22 markets involving Chicago, New York and Washington.
ROME, Feb. 14 -- Pope Paul VI urged Roman Catholics today to pray for internal peace in Poland.

AMSTERDAM -- It is interesting to note today's artistic interaction between the ballet worlds of the United States and the Netherlands. It is not likely that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization has anything to do with it, but maybe this collaboration was brought about because both countries have only a quite recent dancing history (in the Netherlands, fullscale ballet merely started after World War II) compared to countries like France and Russia.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 14 (UPI) -- The No. 2 team Italian of Enzo Vicario and Corrado del Fabbro took the lead today on the first day of the Kennedy Memorial Games two-man bobsled competition. Their two-heat time was 2 minutes 18.64 seconds.

The University of Florida basketball team did little for the morale of the hospitalized Adolph Rupp Saturday night.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 14 -- The Mexican automotive industry has raced into red ink despite record output and sales last year. In fact, auto men here fear that another big sales could mire their industry in deeper troubles.

TORONTO, Feb. 14 (UPI) -- Phil Esposito, Wayne Cashman and Johnny Bucyk scored a goal each to lead the Boston Bruins to a 5-1 triumph over the Toronto Maple Leafs today, ending a 13-game Toronto victory string at home.

Your Jan. 27 editorial "Demagogy on the Rent Front" is in itself demagogic. BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 15 -- Once again, the Arab commando movement is reappraising its goals and is engaged in squabbles over its organizational structure. LONDON, Feb. 15 -- Bobby Redrupp, a vegetable seller at a stall in Chapel Market, Islington, is a natural expert in the imaginative word play that is Cockney rhyming slang.

HARTFORD, Feb. 16 -- Gov. Thomas J. Meskill called today for an increase in the Connecticut state sales tax to 7 per cent, a level that would make it the highest in the country. At the same time, the Governor urged that the tax, now 5 per cent, be applied to a number of previously exempted items.

ALBANY, Feb. 16 -- Governor Rockefeller announced today the approval of grants totalling $7.1-million to the Board of Education, six community school boards and a private school, all in New York City, for narcotics treatment and prevention programs.

BACHHRAWAN, India, Feb. 5 -- "We have many great hurdles to cross this time," said V. P. Mishra, a bloc leader for Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's New Congress party in this rural north Indian town. "'We must get the new symbol printed and take it to all the villages so that the people will become familiar with it."

The Israeli Housing Ministry's announced plan to push ahead with the construction of new housing for Israelis on former Arab lands in East Jerusalem constitutes a serious threat to the future of the Holy City and to the cause of peace.

We never get enough classic theater in New York. Certainly we don't get enough classic theater of the quality of the Phoenix Theater's production of Moliere's "the School for Wives," which opened last night at the Lyceum Theater. It once more shows that Moliere can be funny, blithe and totally enchanting.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia -- Several mornings a week Alaka Baye Alemu leaves his mud-walled home in Lalibala and walks to the nearby Emmanuel Church. He reads prayers for three hours, returns home for breakfast and then sets out for a day of work in his fields.

DARLINGTON, S.C., Feb. 16 -- A Darlington County grand jury indicted 22 men today on riot charges stemming from an incident last March 3 in Lamar, where two school buses were overturned by a white mob protesting a school desegregation court order.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 17 -- Spring training camps came alive along Florida's Gulf coast today as the countdown began for the baseball season.
The Hartford Fire Insurance Company yesterday reported net operating income for 1970 of $54-million, a record. The figure was up 31.5 per cent from 1969's net operating income of $41.1-million.
A plan for 800 more parking spaces in the Yankee Stadium area was disclosed yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 17 (AP) -- Ilie Nastase of Rumania, the defending champion, and Cliff Richey, last year's runner-up, advanced to the quarter-finals with straight-set victories tonight in the $50,000 national indoor open tennis championships.

" Roommates" is about Henry, a young New Yorker who wears his hair in the modified Jerome Ragni bob favored by weekend dropouts. He works for the All-State Collection Agency, shares a railroad flat with Solly and has a girl named Sandy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- A top-secret memorandum to Attorney General John Mitchell from his antitrust division recently fell into the hands of this newspaper, after having been smuggled out of the Justice Department via its heating tunnel by two nuns who infiltrated the mail room.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UPI) -- Wholesale prices, pushed up by sharply higher costs for food, rose 0.7 per cent last month, the sharpest increase in a year, the Labor Department reported today. The report showed inflation had continued to plague the economy. The department reported earlier, on the basis of incomplete information, that wholesale prices rose only 0.6 per cent last month.

The New York season -- which is getting better, better and better -- last night rolled out another immaculate and thrilling production of a classic. The classic is Ibsen's "Hedda Gabler," the place is the beautiful Playhouse Theater, and the company is led by Claire Bloom and Donald Madden.

A week after his 17th birthday, Bill Skinner dropped out of Wilmington (Del.) High School and joined the Navy. High school had become, he says, "redundant." He spent four years and three months in service, some of that time aboard the U.S.S. Canberra, grew a mustache, earned a high school equivalency diploma, shaved his mustache, and was discharged a second-class petty officer. Back home, he married and became a sheet-metal worker.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -Representative Ogden R. Reid of Westchester disclosed today that the Army's controversial intelligence surveillance of civilian dissent and political activity was so widely known in government from 1968 on that even the military aides to all 50 state Governors were informed of its scope and operations.

Potato futures rose sharply on Tuesday in the wake of last week's Government report, but the upswing proved shortlived yesterday. After a jump in price at the opening, the key May contract plunged to set a new life-of-contract low.

The Carnegie Commission on Higher Education called yesterday for greatly increased public and private support to help the country's 105 black colleges and universities emerge from their "historic isolation" into the mainstream of American higher education.

The Mercantile Security Life Insurance Company and the Republic National Life Insurance Company, both of Dallas, announced yesterday that their respective executive committees have approved the merger of Mercantile Security into Republic National.

JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, Feb. 11 -- The Saudi Arabian Government continues to move along slowly but vigorously long after most other Arab monarchies have fallen by the wayside.
PARIS, Feb. 17 -- Rene Tomasini suddenly became a household word in France today with remarks about television news and permissive courts that some compared to those of Spiro T. Agnew.
New York University's fencing team stretched its victory streak to 22 meets over three seasons by defeating Columbia, 19-8, in the losers's gym last night.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company plans to seek stockholder approval at the annual meeting on April 22 for authorization of an additional 150 million shares of common stock and 50 million shares of preferred stock.

A former coin dealer who pleaded guilty to Federal charges of conspiring with Joseph Colombo Jr. and two other men to melt down coins for their silver content testified yesterday that Mr. Colombo had not personally financed the alleged operation.
Propelled by the most powerful bond market rally in the postwar era, earnings of the First Boston Corporation soared in the second half of 1970 to more than four times the year-earlier level.

A Swedish television producer and journalist, in New York to work on a book about Harlem, said yesterday that he had been deprived of his membership at the Metropolitan Club after he brought black guests to the club.
Prices moved lower yesterday on the American Stock Exchange for the first time in five sessions.

A Florida resident is being sought by a Manhattan grand jury for questioning about an alleged conspiracy with an indicted gambler, Hugh Mulligan, to kill a witness to a 1964 armored car robbery involving $500,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The Food and Drug Administration today proposed strict new safety and effectiveness standards for fixed combination drugs, including many of the most widely sold prescription and overthe-counter products.

The Rev. Aloysius B. Begley, Providence athletic director, was a sad man when he returned to his college following the Eastern College Athletic Conference convention yesterday. The survival of Big Thicket is a testament to nature's resiliency. This extraordinary wilderness in East Texas has been overcut by lumber companies and flooded with brackish water by oil companies. Yet 300,000 acres, one-tenth the original forest, still retain their natural quality. The Big Thicket has been called the "biological crossroads of North America." Here the almost extinct ivory-billed woodpecker and the bald eagle are making a last stand.
Gerardo Ribeiro, a Portuguese violinist now studying at the Juilliard School, was presented in his New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night by the Concert Artists Guild.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans explained today his holding of stock in a subsidiary of the Penn Central railroad. He said he did not know whether he owns that stock now.

The Senate's failure this week to muster a two-thirds majority for closure means that the unnecessary talkathon goes on. Southern conservatives are determined to block a modest reform of the filibuster rule which would permit the Senate to close debate by a three-fifths rather than a two-thirds majority. Enough Republicans from the Middle West and the Mountain States tacitly agree with the Southerners for the minority to prevail.

The study by the New York Civil Liberties Union of 115 instances in which pupils were suspended last year from their schools adds up to a serious indictment of the system's disciplinary practices. The fact that in one year the staggering total of 14,000 suspensions took place raises questions why this form of punishment was so exclusively used.

Such rated listings -- available at the various government tourist offices of the countries involved and at many travel agencies -- present the traveler with packs or categories of hotels he can deal with and pick from. The packs come neatly stacked, of course, with the poshest on top.
MOSCOW -- One consumer story being told in Moscow these days is about the woman who burst excitedly into her neighbor's apartment.

Championship golf is ahead of its usual schedule this year. The Professional Golfers' Association championship starts Thursday at Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., or roughly six months earlier than customary. Why?

These sturdy vignettes would have seemed at home in the pages of transition or Broom. Which is not to say that they are dated, but rather that they have a timeless quality about them. Miss Dillon excels at slightly out-of-focus perceptions that can give a gothic twist to the mundane.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- The State Department says it plans to start issuing passports through selected post offices across the nation by the end of this year.

Borough President Robert Abrams of the Bronx ventured into Manhattan yesterday to charge that "dozens" of sidewalk cafes on the East Side were operating without licenses and franchises, depriving the city of $500,000 a year in revenue.

Selecting a representative group of paperbacks dealing with significant issues involving Negroes is no easy matter. Paperback publishers seem increasingly bereft of viable criteria of relevance in the choice of books they issue on Negroes: Anything that touches on Negro topics seems publishable, and standards of relevance, caliber and sophistication are tossed to the winds.

Iran, with a population of 27 million, has more narcotics addicts than any other country in the world -- except the United States. Beginning in the 1950's, the Iranian Government tried to cut the supply of opium and the opium derivatives morphine and heroin used by the country's 250,000 addicts, but smugglers from Turkey and Afghanistan, traveling wild mountain passes, usually outwitted the government agents.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 20 (Agence France-Presse) -- Premier Tran Thien Khien has canceled a press decree he signed on Jan. 21, after an outcry by the Saigon press, official sources disclosed here.

PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. Feb. 20 (AP) -- Sandra Palmer shot a two-under par 71 today and took the lead by three strokes in the $60,000 Sears Womens World Classic at wind-blown Port St. Lucie Country Club.

ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- A question that has nagged Long Island homeowners, politicians and businessmen for much of the last decade -- whether and where to bridge Long Island Sound -- is to be answered "once and for all" by June 21, if Governor Rockefeller has his way.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 20 -- Intense ground fighting was reported today on the northern flank of the South Vietnamese advance into Laos, which remained stalled for the third day.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 20 -- Seventeen of the teams of the major leagues were in action in Florida this weekend in spring training, the seven others in the southwest, and despite the fact that their camps were pitched in beach resorts, deserts and tourists oasis, all of them were getting reminders that civilization was creeping closer.

TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Feb. 20 -- David McLernon, Canadian raquets champion, gained the semifinals of the 69th annual Tuxedo Gold Racquets Tournarnent today in the Tuxedo Racquets and Tennis Club. He defeated David Minot of Boston, 15-1, 15-12.

This is understandable; until recently, if you went into a bookstore and asked for something on crime, you would be directed to the murder-mystery shelf.
Some years the maple sap begins to flow the last week in February. And some years it waits till mid-March. The calendar date is of no importance to a tree.

THREE more countries have joined the coinage plan of the Food and Agricultural Organization of the United Nations, it was announced last week. Since 1966, the FAO has been urging world governments to issue monies with a food or agricultural motif in their designs, both for general circulation and as collector items.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- With Arab-Israeli diplomacy now at a crucial stage, American specialists on the Middle East report that the Soviet Union is cautiously signaling its approval of the current trend but that its commitment to an ultimate peace agreement is still untested.
SEA CLIFF, L. I., Feb. 20 -"Most of us fought against the Bolsheviks," said the wife of a former Czarist officer, "but now they are calling us Bolsheviks."

MOSCOW, Feb. 20 -- A Soviet economics journal disclosed today that administrative personnel laid off as part of a nationwide paring of staffs have been eligible for nearly a year to receive a form of unemployment insurance while training for new jobs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The campaign finance legislation that Republicans are preparing to introduce this week sets no limits on amount candidates may to get themselves elect

About 200 welfare clients moved their beds, clothes, food and television sets into a new but still unoccupied 26-story apartment building on the Upper West Side yesterday afternoon and declared they intended to stay "forever."

LIGHTHOUSE POINT, Fla., Feb. 21 (UPI) -- Francoise Durr, the Parisian queen of the clay courts, stunned Mrs. Billie Jean King for the second straight week today to win the final of a women's professional tennis tournament.

For the first time in several years, retailers across the country have begun to stem the tide of inventories that "just melt away" -- goods that vanish through shoplifting, internal theft and human error.
The corporate bond market last week almost spun out of control as it crash dived through its steepest price decline since late 1969. Then late Friday it seemed to begin to right itself.
AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 21 -Chancellor Charles A. LeMaistre of the University of Texas system announced today the selection of Dr. Stephen H. Spurr as president of the University of Texas at Austin.
LOS ANGELES -- The mansion on Cerrocrest Drive in Beverly Hills has no number, but then its late occupant didn't need a last name to be known, either.

Aaron Shikler, the artist who painted the recently unveiled official White House portraits of President and Mrs. Kennedy, has become the latest family associate to share his intimate observations with the public.

It was a pleasure to read your editorial of Feb. 9 entitled "Holidays -- One Through Five" and to learn of your present thoughts regarding the legislation passed by Congress two and a half years ago on "Monday Holidays."

The nation's colleges and universities, severely pinched between rapidly escalating costs and lagging incomes, are adopting a wide range of strict economy measures. The steps range from abolition of departments and reductions in faculty to cutbacks in snow shoveling and lawn mowing.

WINTER HAVEN, Fla., Feb. 21 -- The Cowardly Lion, owned by Mrs. Sally Sexton and ridden by Rod Jenkins, finished fourth in the stake today, but it didn't mean a thing because he had already won the regular working hunter championship at the Central Florida hunter and jumper horse show.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y. Feb. 21 (AP) -- An American team was declared winner of the four-man bobsled championship at the Kennedy Memorial Winter games today when the second-day competition was called off because of thawing weather.

TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 21 (AP) -- Dale Douglass caught the faltering leaders with a four-under-par 68 today and moved into a first-place tie after two rounds in the weather-plagued, $110,000 Tucson open golf tournament.
KUWAIT -- When Shinichi Satow came to Kuwait five and a half years ago, there were only 40 Japanese living in this small but prosperous country.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21 -- It was a diverse group that had gathered at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School of Finance and Commerce and Prof. Irwin Friend, the diminutive major domo of the proceedings, was frankly a bit skeptical that the 40 people he had assembled would produce a profitable result.

Monthly reports covering such matters as processing controls, money management, customer service and personnel ratios will now be required from the 65 largest member organizations of the American Stock Exchange, the exchange's board of governors announced yesterday.

WESTON, Conn., Feb. 21 -- Amy Goodman's Without Warning captured the regular working hunter championship at the Nimrod Farm's horse show today after a hackoff with Debee Porter's Strictly Business. Each horse had one blue ribbon for 5 points.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- A decision by Brazil to seek World Bank financing of a big steel mill expansion project, instead of financing by individual supplying countries, has posed a major issue of principle for the United States Government.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- A 24-year-old West Point graduate is carrying dissent within the Army over the Vietnam war to new lengths. His tactics have forced the Army leadership into a public test of its ability to deal with this kind of dissaffection.

On the front of the Hampshire House, one of the lavish cooperatives along Central Park South -- Alice Tully has two floors there and Sophia Loren was robbed there -- is a plaque, dated 1931, saying: "Dedicated to yesterday's charm and tomorrow's convenience."

FORT PIERCE, Fla., Feb. 21 (AP) -- An emergency curfew went into effect in Fort Pierce today after a night of firebombings and racial unrest that ended with three young blacks wounded by gunfire and 29 people arrested.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 21 -- Steel mills were allocating tonnage last week.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 21 -- Thurman Munson, first-string catcher and 1970 rookie of the year, and Fritz Peterson, the left-handed 20-game winner, were on the brink of being classified as holdouts today as New York Yankee pitchers and catchers gathered to begin spring training tomorrow morning.

Two unorthodox but promising educational ventures -- the New York Urban League's Street Academies and the independent Harlem Preparatory School -- are in serious difficulty. Both projects aim at salvaging disadvantaged youngsters who have dropped out of school and are on the brink of dropping out of society. After an encouraging beginning, the two experiments now face the loss of much of their financial support from industry and foundations.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb 21 -- Not Cleon Jones's bat, not Tommie Agee's knee, not Ron Swoboda's temper. The biggest question mark of spring training for the New York Mets, said Manager Gil Hodges today, is Jerry Koosman's arm -- and Hodges has no idea how effective it will be.
WESTPORT, Conn., Feb. 21 -- Following the migration of major corporations to the suburbs, a new migration has begun -- that of the small, independent concern engaged in specialized business services.

The Mansfield Tire and Rubber Company reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings -- hampered by the strike in the auto industry and a strike at Mansfield's Tupelo, Miss., plant -- fell 81 per cent to $147-258, or 9 cents, a share, from the year-earlier $780,190, or 52 cents a share.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 21 -- The President of Pakistan, Gen. Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan, today announced the dissolution of his 10-member Cabinet, effective tomorrow.

MUNICH, West Germany -- Within the last five years 800 movie theaters closed in West Germany. The phenomenon is not exclusively German, of course; what is exceptional, however, is the artistic poverty of the pictures shown in German movie houses.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -Backed by the endorsement of Attorney General John N. Mitchell, a legal foundation formed to file friend-of-court briefs on the "law enforcement" side of court cases is beginning to prosper.

The New York Shakespeare Festival's Public Theater, that impressive Astor building on Lafayette Street, is fast becoming one of the most exciting theaters in the world, with its multiple auditoriums, its manifold activities and its special air of unfeigned gutsiness.

The city's Housing and Development Administration announced yesterday that the city was asking for bids on the purchase of 100 house trailers for the temporary relocation of families living in the Arverne section of Queens.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 19 -- It has been two years since a member of the Arkansas legislature last invited another to step outside to settle a personal dispute.

REGGIO CALABRIA, Feb. 21 -The Roman Catholic Archbishop of Reggio Calabria crossed three barricades and defied insults today to urge an end to violence in a workers' suburb that has remained a holdout of insurgents.
New orders for American machine tools last month slumped to their third lowest level since April, 1961, with only August and November, 1970, recording less activity.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Feb. 21 -- Today, as they have done 24 hours a day, 12 months a year since 1966, Americans and Canadians watched the outside world for signs of nuclear war from within their hollowed-out mountain near here, alert for the smallest indication that the nuclear button might have to be pressed.
NEWARK, Feb. 21 (UPI) -A new president of the bankrupt Central Railroad of New Jersey has been named, Robert T. Timpany, railroad trustee, announced over the weekend.

INZELL, Germany, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Ruth Schleiermacher of East Germany won the women's world ice skating sprint championship today with a world record 175.73 points. She edged Anne Henning of Northbrook, Ill., who shattered her day-old world mark in the 500-meter event.

The present tight electric power situation in New York City stems from poor planning by the Consolidated Edison Company before the present management took over, Joseph C. Swidler, chairman of the State Public Service Commission, said last night.

TORONTO, Feb. 21 -- John G. McClelland, Canada's best known book publisher, jolted his countrymen last week by announcing that his business was for sale and that if he couldn't get $1.5-million from a Canadian buyer or otherwise raise money in Canada he just might sell to an American.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -Boeing and British Aircraft Corporation officials held a joint press conference here the other day to promote their proposed supersonic transports, the American SST and the British-French Concorde. MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 21 (UPI) -- The kidnapped Brazilian consul, Aloysio Dias Gomide, was freed tonight after more than six months of captivity after his wife, Maria, paid a ransom to the leftist Tupamaro guerrillas.
DOVER, Del., Feb. 21 (AP) -- Sunday racing made its debut in Delaware today. More than 8,000 fans turned out at Dover Downs and wagered a record $573,856 through the parimutuel machines.

The Federal Government has abandoned a long-disputed plan to build a highway through the country's sole national memorial forest, the Joyce Kilmer Memorial Forest in the southwestern tip of North Carolina.

DETROIT, Feb. 21 (AP) -- The Chicago Bulls, despite Dave Bing's 54 points, downed the Detroit Pistons, 125-112, today for their fifth straight victory in the National Basketball Association. It also was their 12th triumph in their last 15 games.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- President Nixon's reaffirmation at a news conference last week of his opposition to the "forced integration" of suburban housing not only shed a bit more light on what he means by that term, but also sent nervous ripples through the two Federal agencies that have tried the hardest to open the suburbs to low and moderate-income housing -- the Department of Housing and Urban Development and the Department of Justice.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (UPI) -- Deputy Attorney Genera Richard G. Kleindienst defended today the Nixon Administration's contention that it has an inherent Presidential right to wiretap dissident domestic groups.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- In its first tentative step toward programing guidelines for television, the Federal Communications Commission has suggested that big-city stations devote at least 15 per cent of their time, including prime evening time, to local shows, and 15 per cent to news and public affairs.
HONG KONG, Feb. 21 -- Despite an absence from public view of almost five months, Wei Kuo-ching, the veteran political leader of the Kwangsi autonomous region, has not been purged.

Carlos Siega's goal with two minutes to play gave the German-Hungarians a 2-1 victory yesterday and ended New York Hota's unbeaten streak at 15 games in German-American Soccer League game at Metropolitan Oval in Queens before a crowd of 1,500.

WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 21 -- Miss Johanna Davis Drooz, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Herbert Emanuel Drooz, was married here this morning to Alan Steven Yoffie. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs William Yoffie of Worcester, Mass.

SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 21 -- Clark Graebner won a tennis match today that made a grown man cry -- Cliff Richey.

PANAMA CITY, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Roberto de Vicenzo of Argentina won the Panama open today with a nine-under-par 63 on the final round.

The advertising agencies of the nation increased their worldwide billings 2.6 per cent in 1970, Advertising Age, the respected weekly journal of marketing and advertising, will report today.

An increasingly common argument against public aid to parochial schools was repeated by Governor Rockefeller on Feb. 8. The argument is that tuition grants to private schools would encourage white parents in both the North and South to send their children to segregated white schools.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- The Legislature approved a Sept. 14 primary date today despite Democratic charges that the Republican majorities in both houses were trying to undo the permanent spring primary reform enacted in 1965.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24 -James L. Van Alen Jr. of Philadelphia gained the quarterfinal round of the United States amateur court-tennis championship by defeating Robert S. MacDonald of New York, 5-6, 6-3, 6-2, 4-6, 6-4, today at the Racquet Club.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 24 -- It is so easy to buy heroin from peddlers in Vietnam wherever there are American troops or convoys that a tiny plastic vial can be purchased for $3 outside the headquarters of an American general.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission revoked today the investment adviser registration of Shortline Reports, Inc., New York. Among other things, the S.E.C. accused the company of false and misleading advertising.

WASHINGTON, Feb 24 -- The Secretary of Defense and a senior military aide insisted today that South Vietnamese forces had deliberately paused in the offensive in Laos rather than being bogged down as a result of enemy attacks.

Even though Two barely remembered Marty, as a rather dim figure in the yearbook with too much hair oil, the papers said he was Presidential timber and one of the newsmagazines had even said "Presidential timber trying to become Presidential plastic."

The J. C. Penney Company, Inc., turned in its best quarterly performance of fiscal 1970 with a 10.5 per cent increase in earnings on a sales gain of 5.4 per cent in the 13 weeks ended Jan. 30, according to the preliminary unaudited report issued yesterday.

Grandmaster Istvan Bilek won the 1970 Hungarian Chess Championship, scoring 10 1/2-4 1/2 during the 16-man round robin. Second was Master Polgar with 9 1/2, and tied for third were Kluger and Adorjan, 9 each.

He will glance at the TV schedules in The Sunday Times, descend to the gloom of his base ment, and catch a little sports on television.

Dun Bradstreet, Inc., which for almost a century has been rating the financial capacity and credit-standing of American business, announced yesterday the most significant changes in the process since it began employing such littleknown credit reporters as Abraham Lincoln.

Do you know why the page you're reading now is the size it is? Answer: It's a tax dodge. When British newspapers were taxed by the page in 1712, printers were quick to figure out they could pay less tax and publish more news by using huge pages. Those taxes disappeared more than a century ago, but readers -- and machines -- were accustomed to handling big pages, and they stayed.

Why, accept, of course, and try to demonstrate in the piece how foolish and futile his own efforts are.
