If art is nothing but artifice that has died and gone to heaven -- and you'll find more meaningless definitions in almost any book on esthetics -- then the lieder recital at its best should be one of music's sublimest experiences.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- Hopes swelled today for early termination of a nationwide rail-strike threat as negotiators for the union, who are legally free to walk out at any time, resumed talks on wages and work rules.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- James H. Van Aken, 17 years old, of Western Springs, Ill., was named today top winner -- and recipient of a $10,000 scholarship -- in the 30th annual Westinghouse Science Talent Search among high school science students.

CAIRO, March 1 -- Amid an emerging sense of gloom over the stalled efforts for an Arab-Israeli settlement which seemed to be flourishing until a week ago, the United Arab Republic appealed today to the Big Four to save the situation before the expiration of the Suez Canal cease-fire.
The city has started pulling down the iron fences around the center islands on Park Avenue from 46th to 96th Street in a facelifting operation to be completed by midsummer.

DES MOINES, Iowa, March 1 (UPI) -- Mrs. Richard M. Nixon said today that she hoped to make a determined effort to improve the quality of life in the United States and the world while she was First Lady.

Mrs. Juliana Schoenfeld of Forest Hills, Queens, had trouble getting a cab at Kennedy International Airport yesterday. The cab drivers were busy being interviewed -- on how taxi service at the airport was about to improve.

Experts have to resign themselves to the fact that superior cardplay often goes unrewarded. In the long run they will show a profit, but in the short run their score may be no better than another player who has selected an inferior line of play that happens to succeed.

Exactly fourteen months ago a City Hall spokesman conceded that, as a result of unusual weather conditions, the pothole situation had become critical. Now, after a new round of announcements about the annually unusual weather, a state of crisis has again been admitted to exist.

The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it had filed a counterclaim against the Control Data Corporation and its subsidiary, the Commercial Credit Company, alleging violations of the antitrust laws.
LONDON, March 1 -- More than a million industrial workers stayed off their jobs today in a political strike.

Coaching isn't as much a matter of X's and O's and tactics as it is a matter of handling people, according to Ron Mitchell the new basketball coach at Boston University. Mitchell, who will succeed Charles Luce next season, is the first black basketball coach at the university.

Ray Austrian, founder and president of The Picture Decorator, Inc., 740 Madison Avenue, and a former advertising man, died here Sunday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 65 years old and lived at 177 East 75th Street.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Within yards of where a bomb exploded early today, British soldiers swarmed up a narrow stairway and set fire to the Capitol in 1814.
Afeni Shakur, who warned her fellow Black Panther party members that one of their supposed comrades was a policeman, yesterday cross-examined the man she suspected.
Your angry Feb. 21 editorial, "A Wider War," and Tom Wicker's tirade, "A Slaughter of Innocents," of the same date present formidable practical and moral arguments against the incursion into Laos.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 28 -- With more than 1.5 million snowmobiles churning about this year in the nation's snow belt states, new efforts are being made to control their use, limit their noise, and educate their drivers on how not to kill themselves.

Picking a team winner in the I. C. 4-A indoor track and field meet seemed easier yesterday for metropolitan area coaches than solving several administrative disputes for this weekend's 50th annual championships.

TOKYO, March 1 -- The Shield Society, the private army of university students formed by the author Yukio Mishima, has announced its dissolution, three months after its founder's spectacular ritual suicide.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- After extended internal debate, the Administration has decided not to include the Teacher Corp in its initial proposal for a new merged volunteer service agency, knowledgeable officials disclosed today.

LOS ANGELES, March 1 -- Raymond Massey did not get the Raymond Massey portrait and Burt Bacharach did not get Butch Cassidy's bicycle. Still, the first auction to be held by Sotheby-Parke-Bernet in its new Los Angeles Hall generally seemed appropriate for Hollywood.

Barton Silverman of The New York Times has been named 1970 Photographer of the Year by the New York Press Photographers Association, which announced the winners in its 35th annual competition yesterday.
BERLIN, March 1 -- The West Berlin City administration and the East German Government today opened talks aimed at reaching an agreement on border-crossing passes for West Berliners during Easter.

ALBANY, March 1 -- The State Public Service Commission ordered hearings to begin here on March 16 on the New York Telephone Company's request for a 29.1 per cent rate increase, which would produce $391-million annually in additional revenue.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 1 -- The Rev. James T. Burtchaell, University of Notre Dame provost, has proposed the complete incorporation of St. Mary's College, an all-girl school, into the University of Notre Dame.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI) -- Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas cleared the way today for Spencer Haywood to finish the season with the Seattle SuperSonics of the National Basketball Association.

The Penn Central applied for fare increases on its Harlem and Hudson lines yesterday, the first day that regulation of fares was shifted from the Public Service Commission to the state transportation department.
When Monogram Industries acquired National Screw of Cleveland three years ago, Martin Stone, Monogram's chairman, said he was confident about turning that company around.
LONDON, March 1 -- The Conservative Government, reversing its position, today adopted its predecessors' plan to end Britain's historic role in the Persian Gulf area this year.
PHILADELPHIA, March 1 -- Representative William J. Green rejected the advice of Mayor James H. J. Tate today and announced his candidacy for Mayor of Philadelphia.

In his State of the World address, President Nixon said it would be his policy to keep open the lines of communication with the Marxist Government of Chile. "We will not be the ones to upset traditional relations," he said. "We are prepared to have the kind of relationship with the Chilean Government that it is prepared to have with us."

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- In the aftermath of the bomb explosion in the Capitol early this morning, Congressmen and Federal officials began to struggle today with the dilemma of protecing Government buildings without limiting public access to them.

A group of investors headed by David F. Bolger, president of Bolger Co., Inc., announced yesterday that it planned to make a rival offer to acquire the Okonite Company, a subsidiary of Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc. Bolger is a general investment company specializing in corporate real estate.

GENEVA, March 1 -- Robert L. Vesco, president of the International Controls Corporation of Fairfield, N. J., was believed to have tightened his hold on Investors Overseas Services by taking over the chairmanship of the financial group's parent company.

MIAMI, March 1 -- Muhammad Ali, self-proclaimed predictor, poet and prophet -- not to mention pugilist of unlimited vocal capacity -- talked it up today. The former heavyweight champion of the world, also known as Cassius Clay, was on a radio program that he thought was a conference set up, with Joe Frazier talking from his camp in Philadelphia.
The London Stock Exchange dropped sharply yesterday. Dealers reported a flow of selling but almost no buying.

Consumer Affairs Commissioner Bess Myerson contended yesterday that a series of new rules governing moving companies recently issued by the state Public Service Commission "unfortunately avoid real regulation that would adequately protect consumers rights."

The New York Life Insurance Company -- the fourth largest insurer in the country -- disclosed yesterday that the bankruptcy of the Penn Central Transportation Company resulted in an unrealized loss for the giant insurer of more than $20-million on that transaction.
DETROIT, March 1 -- The nation's first black new car dealer is going out of business.
The bond markets, which had hoped to move this week's record volume of new corporate issues with a certain amount of dispatch, ran into heavy going yesterday.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, March 2 -- South Vietnamese troop reinforcements, assembled in the northeastern corner of South Vietnam, were moving westward to the Laotian border yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

Dr. Leo D. Klauber's letter (Feb. 22) regarding a potential future threat of excessive Pentagon power with an all-volunteer army is at odds with American history. During the peacetime years of the 20's and 30's (and before World War I) the War Department did in fact have an all-volunteer army at its command.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- A welfare bill that would couple the concept of President Nixon's family assistance plan with a first step toward Federal assumption of the states welfare costs is taking shape in the House Ways and Means Committee.
Few will disagree with President Nixon's hope that soon we may enter upon a generation of peace.
FREEPORT, L.I., March 1 -- About 30 acres of land owned by New York City in this South Shore village was acquired by the village today for $1.3-million.
New York City told the Federal Court of Appeals here yesterday that it had "mistakenly" believed the Cornwall, N.Y., pumped-storage hydroelectric project would reduce air pollution here

Where can you buy rings for a wedding at dawn in Central Park, African sculpture, pre-Columbian pottery, silver art nouveau objects, and two Shirley Temple dolls all in the same place? Adamas Antiques, at 105 West 10th Street, is one store that sells these items and more.

In your Feb. 13 news report on the application of Cornelius McNeil Cooper Jr. for honorable discharge from the United States Army, you quote him as saying, ". . . my moral convictions are entirely inconsistent with the duties I am called to perform . . ." and that "service in the armed forces is an immoral action."

HARRISBURG, March 1 (AP) -- Pennsylvania halted payments today to private concerns providing vital services, and a financial crisis -- with political strings attached -- threatened to make Thursday a payless payday for 70,000 state employes.
A videotape film purportedly showing a defendant trying to sell forged checks and stolen stock certificates was shown before a Supreme Court Justice yesterday in Manhattan Criminal Court.

In 1914, when he was a young reporter on The Times, Joyce Kilmer published a volume of verse, "Trees and Other Poems." Its title poem has become a popular classic. Four years later, Kilmer was killed on a battlefield in France.

At the Fordham-Marquette game last week, a local coach pointed out: "That Digger Phelps is involved with the two best college teams in the East. He coaches Fordham and before that he helped recruit and coach Penn into the powerhouse it is."

NEWARK, March 1 -- The Essex County Prosecutor's Office moved today to have three officials of the Newark Teachers Union begin serving a six-month jail sentence that was stayed last week on condition that they ask their membership to end their month-long strike.

Richard D. Zanuck, who-resigned under fire last December as president of 20th Century-Fox along with David Brown, his executive vice president of creative operations, have joined Warner Brothers as senior executive vice president and executive vice president in charge of creative operations, respectively.

Economic recession, coupled with inflation, has made this a particularly difficult winter; and yet donations to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have set a record for the fifty years of this annual appeal. Readers have given the extraordinary total of $1,055,877.91. This is the first year the total has surpassed one million dollars.

Arvid Anderson, impartial chairman of the city's Office of Collective Bargaining, said yesterday that he had directed the three mediators in the uniformed services' contract disputes to begin efforts immediately to resolve the issue of pay parity for the city's patrolmen.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The bomb that exploded in the Capitol building early today was placed in a lavatory on the building's ground floor, indicated by a cross on the diagram above.

Regardless of its success or failure, the present Laotian incursion by the South Vietnamese army, with American logistical and air support, may quite conceivably result in an earlier end of our involvement in the Vietnam war. Since this is a real possibility, it appears to me that the renewed campaign by some of the "end-the-war" advocates is unnecessary.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Capt. Ernest L. Medina accused the Army today of trying to keep him from challenging the testimony of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. that orders to kill civilians at Mylai had come from Captain Medina.

CASA GRANDE, Ariz., March 1 (UPI) -- Willie Mays ended his first holdout today when he agreed to a two-year contract with the San Francisco Giants for $155,000 to $160,000 a season, making him one of the highest paid players in baseball history.

JERUSALEM, March 1 -- Israel's policy-makers, braced against criticism from the United States, are expressing confidence that time is on their side in the diplomatic peacemaking effort and that the continuation of a firm stand on their basic positions will eventually pay off.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Nixon Administration's chief environmental officer said today that concern about pollution from a large fleet of supersonic transports could and should be divorced from the immediate question of developing two SST test models.

Charpentier's "Louise" is a mixture of sadness, comedy and sociology (if you can apply that last term to a conflict based on the ways of life of the workingman and the artist). And of course, it is a love story.

Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner and the school system's administrators are facing each other with an increasing hostility that interferes with both the routine management of the schools and the urgent process of reform. Both sides have contributed to the conflict. It is time to put an end to it by dealing rationally with the facts behind it.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI) -- President Nixon awarded the Apollo 14 astronauts the space agency's highest award at a dinner tonight and added a special prize for Captain Shepherd's lunar golf game.

Faced with a loss of earnings in December, 1969, the American Can Company scrapped its corporate advertising program. And with it, naturally, went the job title, director of corporate advertising and services, and the man who held it.

Sammy Price, who played piano at Barney Josephson's famous Greenwich Village nightclub, Cafe Society, in the nineteen-forties, has joined Mary Lou Williams, another graduate of Cafe Society, in providing music at Mr. Josephson's current restaurant, the Cookery, University Place at Eighth Street.

SISAL, Yucatan, Mexico -- Two mornings of excellent duck hunting and one morning of superb, if rigorous, quail hunting out of the Club de Patos on the northwestern coast of the Yucatan were made even more memorable by our Mayan guides.
Business spending for new plant and equipment will rise a scant 3 per cent this year to $83-billion from $80.6-billion in 1970, Lionel D. Edie Co., Inc., predicted yesterday.

Creative figures in the performing arts -- dramatists, lyricists, composers -- deserve the minimum amenity. Some of their Contributions, written while either too young or too old or caught in middle-age trauma -- warrant the kindness of going, unremembered, small slips gently consigned to the darkness of human frailty.

ROME, March 1 -- The police today moved armored vehicles, including half a dozen personnel carriers, into L'Aquila, a mountain city 50 miles northeast of here, where rioting continued for the fourth consecutive day.
The J. C. Penney company's campaign against secrecy in the Treasury Department's administrative handling of the Anti-dumping Act of 1921 suffered a setback yesterday.

A warning that the Washington Square campus of New York University might have to be closed within the next few days if the weather turns cold and striking members of Teamster Local 810 continue to prevent fuel oil deliveries was issued yesterday by James H. Hester, president of the school.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 1 (AP) -- The Prime Minister of the Irish Republic and a Roman Catholic bishop today condemned the wave of guerrilla violence here.

The elderly white-haired man, looking more like a retired banker or State Department official than a three-time Pulitzer Prize-winner, was holding up remarkably well under the hot lights of his third television interview as he leaned forward to catch the reporter's question.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court denied today a hearing to three companies and three individuals convicted of having conspired to fix prices on sinks, bathtubs and toilets from 1962 to 1966.
Fairleigh Dickinson made its debut in Madison Square Garden a success last night by defeating Dartmouth, 53-48, before a sparse crowd of 4,198.
Silver traders, who have suffered the doldrums of low prices for quite a while, found something cheering yesterday.

The Florida Power Corporation reported yesterday gains of 9.3 per cent in 1970 operating revenues and 5.8 per cent in net earnings. The annual report placed operating revenues at $158,144,572, up from $144,739,865 a year earlier.

MOSCOW, March -- Soviet citizens awoke this morning to find that prices on washing machines, electric razors, ballpoint pens and other consumer goods had been reduced as part of cuts on prices of goods no longer in tight supply.

DES MOINES, Iowa, March 1 -- President Nixon's plea for support of his revenue-sharing program, punctuated by a pledge to add $100-million to rural development funds, received the backing of a Democratic Governor here today, but his appearance touched off a demonstration by a coalition of farmers, antiwar protesters and construction workers.

It is 8:30 on a rainy Monday morning, and in the face of the poet, who is tall and broad-shouldered and wears a blue knit sailor's cap pulled jauntily forward above thin-rimmed tortoise shell glasses, there is vitality and light: something both sacerdotal and seafaring.
Two-step price increases amounting to almost 12 per cent for grocery bags and the paper used to make them were announced yesterday.
LONDON, March 1 -- A leading British motor insurance company announced tonight that it was insolvent and warned 500,000 motorists to stay off the roads until they could get new insurance.

LONDON, March 1 (AP) -- Rod Laver beat Tony Roche, 6-3, 7-5, and Yugoslavia's Nikki Pilic ousted Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill., 4-6, 6-3, 6-4, in the semifinals of the $30,000 Rothman's international indoor tennis tournament tonight. The first prize is $7,800.

American Airlines, which, like most airlines, has complained of a shortage of passengers lately because of the nation's sluggish economy, said yesterday that it was taking 40 of the seats out of its Boeing 747 jumbo jets.

ST. PETERSBURGH, Fla., March 1 -- Nobody knows exactly when the New York Mets switched, but late in the nineteen-sixties they started to search for hitters to help their young pitchers. Now they have half a dozen home-grown swingers in training who represent the chief change from the team's past and the chief hope for its future.
MIAMI, March 1 -- One hundred yachts sailed for daylight today as the 176-mile race from Miami to Nassau began under the darkness of a squall off Miami Beach.
A $15,000 women's tennis tournament, which Mrs. Billie Jean King termed yesterday "probably my supreme challenge," will be played here March 24 through 27 at the 34th Street Armory on Park Avenue.

MILWAUKEE, March 1 (UPI) -- Lew Alcindor and Oscar Robertson each scored 29 points tonight to lead the Milwaukee Bucks to a 127-103 National Basketball Association victory over the Philadelphia 76ers and their 16th straight.

The change in the Washington Birthday holiday had no perceivable effect in retail buying last month, according to leading New York retailers. In the four-week period ended last Saturday, department stores registered a gain of 4.9 per cent in their downtown stores and 5.5 per cent for their stores in the metropolitan area.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., March 1 -- Clayton Rawson, mystery story writer, editor, and magician under the stage name of The Great Merlini, died today in United Hospital, Port Chester. He was 64 years old and lived at 219 North Barry Avenue.

TAYNINH, South Vietnam, March 1 -- Bereft of leadership by the death of Lieut. Gen. Do Cao Tri in a helicopter crash last week, officers at his forward command post directing a 23,000-man operation against North Vietnamese troops and supplies in Cambodia appear to be in a state of confusion and uncertainty.
SEATTLE, March 1 (AP) -- George H. Stoner, senior vice president of the Boeing Company, died yesterday in a Seattle hospital where he was to undergo lung surgery. He was 53 years old.
WARSAW, March 1 -- Poland's leadership is preparing a law against "social parasites," meaning persons who have no visible means of support.

The Coca-Cola Company had record sales and earnings last year and record fourth-quarter profits, according to the report issued yesterday by J. Paul Austin, president of the Atlanta, Ga., based company.

Drivers and mechanics for a private bus company serving the Mill Basin area of Brooklyn struck at 12:01 A.M. yesterday, forcing 4,500 commuters and 1,500 school children to find other ways of getting to work or school.
A 12-inch pipebomb exploded outside the New School for Social Research early yesterday morning, shattering windows and rousing nearby residents. No one was injured.
Ninth has always been an avenue of many nations with food shops representing Italy, Greece, France and Spain stretched out from 34th to 57th Street.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Tuesday, March 2 (UPI) -- The Vietcong struck Cambodia's only oil refinery at the port of Kompong Som for the first time in the war early today, burning four gasoline storage tanks, the high command reported.
ALBANY, March 1 -- The State Court of Appeals was asked today to order a rehearing in the adoption case involving a 9-month-old girl who has been ordered returned to her natural mother.
The stock market scored a small gain yesterday, just about recovering the loss registered on Friday.
Ab DeMarco is coming to New York today -- not to play for the Rangers, but to see their doctor.
MOSCOW, March 1 -- The cars of two American newsmen were vandalized today in apparent retaliation for damage done to vehicles belonging to Soviet diplomats in Washington.
NEW DELHI, March 1 (AP) --Five persons were killed and scores injured today in violence that disrupted the opening of
LOS ANGELES, March 1 (AP) -- Thurmond Clarke, who retired Sept. 1 as chief United States district judge for the Central California district, died yesterday at the age of 68.

KARACHI Pakistan, March 1 -- President Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan announced today the indefinite postponement of the opening of the National Assembly two days before it was to begin drafting a constitution to return Pakistan to civilian rule.

BONN, March 1 -- In a parlor game of Middle East and brinkmanship politics being played out by students here, realism and naturalness toward Israel have been displayed, suggesting that young West Germans are losing their guilt feelings toward Jews and, therefore, the sympathy that has kept Bonn's "special relationship" with Israel alive.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Supreme Court has agreed to rule on the constittuionality of anti-contraceptive laws that make it a crime to distribute birth control materials to unmarried persons. Twenty-six states have such laws.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- The Air Force is removing slot machines from its overseas bases and will have banished them entirely by July 1, 1972, Senators inquiring into military corruption announced today.

The Loews Corporation announced yesterday the appointment of Herbert A. Hofmann as president of Loews Hotels and Bernard Myerson as president of Loews Theatres, two of its divisions. The appointments to the newly created positions are effective immediately. Mr. Hofmann, who joined the company in 1951, has been senior vice president in charge of the Loews Hotels division, which operates 15 major hotels in the United States, the Bahamas and England.

The wild, wild West came to the East Side last night. Dance hall girls and rodeo riders, chic Indians and just plain blue-jeaned cowpokes rode through the night in taxis rather than broncos, although one group went through the trouble of hiring a stagecoach.
James Cash Penney, founder of the J. C. Penney Department store chain, left an estate worth about $35-million it was disclosed yesterday with the filing of his will in probate at Surrogate Court.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- Senator Ernest F. Hollings, an avowed protectionist, said today that the reported plan by Japan to impose self-restraints on textile exports to the United States without establishing specific categories of items for control "won't do the job."

NEW HAVEN -- The Long Wharf Theater goes from strength to strength. This season alone it has given us a fine production of a Maxim Gorky classic, the American premiere of Marguerite Duras's "House Without Doors," and now a new double-bill by Robert Anderson, "Solitaire-Double Solitaire."

MIAMI, March 1 (UPI) -- Eleven 3-year-olds, headed by His Majesty and Jim French, were entered today for the 40th running of the Flamingo Stakes Wednesday at Hialeah Park. It is the first $100,000 added race of the year for Triple Crown hopefuls.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Army is going before Senator Ervin to try to explain its outrageous domestic surveillance operations, which are supposed to be a thing of the past. The Army has a lot to explain, all right, but its officials are not the only ones.

LONDON -- When Reginald Maudling was appointed Home Secretary in the incoming Conservative Government last June, the liberal sigh of relief was almost deafening. He had a reputation as the most moderate and civilized of Edward Heath's leading colleagues. The individual outlook of a Home Secretary can shape or reshape the outlook of his department.

REHOVOT, Israel -- "My wife and I understood that prejudice against us would exist," said Dr. Fritz Nader of Heidelberg University, a 30-year-old West German chemist, recalling his doubts about working in Israel. "But we were afraid about the children -- that they might not understand."

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Apollo 14 astronauts reacted strongly today to suggestions that the manned space program be cut back and that men be replaced by machines in future explorations of the solar system.

One man who was particularly interested in seeing and being seen by the Apollo 14 astronauts in Washington yesterday was Dr. James Chipman Fletcher, a tall, gangling 51-year-old university president from Utah.

WASHINGTON -- The United States is now withdrawing its ground forces from Vietnam -- all critics to the contrary notwithstanding. But this withdrawal will not reduce the requirement for an American strategy offering some hope to the nations of Asia that the United States has an interest in their future.

KHESANH, South Vietnam, March 1 -- Clarence J. Romero Jr. of the Bronx, a 20-year-old warrant officer, has the most dangerous job in the air war over Laos. He pilots a tiny light observation helicopter (L.O.H.) at tree-top level, waiting to draw fire.

KINSHASA, the Congo -- Congolese Protestants, still sharply divided by ecclesiastical differences inherited from European missionaries, are seeking unity on the basis of a strictly African brand of ecumenism.

The administrator of the Coney Island Head Start ofice was arrested yesterday on charges of illegally receiving welfare payments while collecting $10,800 a year for work in the preschool-children's program.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, March 1 -- The Government of this eight-year-old nation is on the verge of amending its Constitution to make it a crime to talk about racial issues.
The Bank of America, the nation's largest bank, announced yesterday plans to sell a $100-million issue of seven and one-half year capital notes.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Treasury bill rates declined sharply again at today's auction from previous week's levels to their lowest average discount rates since September 1963, the Government reported late this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The United States today rebuffed a Soviet effort for immediate Big Four action to bring pressure on Israel to negotiate concessions, and it urged Moscow to stop what it called propaganda exchanges on the Middle East.
A bill raising taxicab fare rates by about 50 per cent was signed into law yesterday by Mayor Lindsay. The new rates go into effect at 6 A.M. today.

BRUSSELS, March 1 -- The Common Market's foreign ministers agreed today to give Britain a four-and-a-half-year period of adjustment if she becomes a member. The period would be intended to bring her farm prices up to the higher levels in the six-nation trade bloc.

SHAW, Miss. -- Mayor P. M. Bennett, wearing a hat and an open collar as be busied himself in his furniture store, stopped to shake his head in blank-faced bewilderment. "My, goodnight," he exclaimed, "since 1965 when I took office we've been making improvements all over the black sections, paving streets, putting in sewers. I just don't understand why, if they wanted to put a law suit on us, why they chose this particular time."

Paul Zindel's new play, "And Miss Reardon Drinks a Little," is about three school-teaching sisters who are locked in the suffocating embrace of their family. Anna (Julie Harris), the youngest, is on the brink of insanity.
Controller Abraham D. Beame predicted yesterday that the new Health and Hospitals Corporation would exhaust its funds long before the end of its first fiscal year on July 1.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- World trade showed another large increase by value in 1970, but higher prices accounted for an unusually large portion of the increase, the International Monetary Fund reported today.
The American Stock Exchange ended slightly higher yesterday in comparatively light trading.
BOGOTA, Colombia, March 1 (UPI) -- New student disorders flared briefly today in the troubled Department Del Valle, where eight persons were killed and 47 injured Friday in student-police clashes.

ALBANY, March 1 -- The State Assembly approved today a proposal to extend the throughbred racing season by as many as 15 days and to enlarge the horse owners' and New York Racing Association's shares of the betting pool.

The aim of the tiny minority of fanatics who are in the business of anarchy is to bring on a general repression in the hope that it will breed more rebels, more anarchists and ultimately the dissolution of society.

William B. Camp, the Controller of the Currency, has recommended that the First National Bancorporation, Inc., of Denver, the large bank-holding company in Colorado, be allowed to acquire the National State Bank of Boulder, Colo., because it is "an endangered bank."

FORT BENNING, Ga., Feb. 2 -- Capt. Ernest L. Medina, who has accused the Army of trying to prevent his testifying at the trial here of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., may be invited to testify after all.

The nation's savings and loan associations had a record net inflow of deposits of $2.6-million during January, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced. The huge influx of funds was the principal factor behind a record drop in interest rates on home mortgages during the month, which fell to 8.17 per cent from 8.38 per cent in December.

Three Chicago community action groups yesterday withdrew petitions they had filed with the Federal Communications Commission to deny renewal of broadcast licenses to WBBM-TV and WBBM radio, of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

When the Penske-White Ferrari 512M is rolled off its trailer for testing this weekend at Sebring, Fla., it will represent a triumph of the car preparation for which Roger Penske is deservedly famous (not to mention his gall in painting a Ferrari blue).

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Dr. James E. McDonald, an atmospheric physicist from the University of Arizona, told a House committee today that a full fleet of supersonic transports would so reduce the protective layer of ozone in the atmosphere as to cause an additional 10,000 cases of skin cancer in the United States each year.
" Sometimes," said Judy Peabody the other day, "Sam feels we live like hermits."
LONDON, March 2 (Reuters) -- The police were called today to pacify angry motorists besieging the offices of the Vehicle and General Insurance Company here after its financial collapse.

HARTFORD, March 2 -- The Connecticut Supreme Court refused today to intervene in the trial of Bobby G. Seale and Mrs. Ericka Huggins and let stand a decision that the two must be tried by a 12-member jury in the death of a fellow member of the Black Panther party.
DACCA, Pakistan, March 2 -- This capital of East Pakistan was in the grip of roving gangs of demonstrators today on the first day of the general strike.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 2 -- The United Arab Republic declared today that "Israel has registered in the United Nations, for the first time in the history of the world organization, its determination to expand, annex and acquire Arab territory, and overtly declare its refusal to withdraw from the Egyptian territories."
ALBANY, March 2 -- Governor Rockefeller said today that he did not think most of the additional state aid being considered for parochial schools would go to impoverished inner-city areas.

While disassociating myself from the counterproductive and indeed foolish tactics of the Jewish Defense League, I regard the barring of its leader, Rabbi Meir Kahane, from the conference held in Brussels on the situation of Soviet Jewry as an obvious hypocrisy.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, March 3 -- More South Vietnamese troops crossed into Laos yesterday to counter a continued build-up of enemy troops and armored forces in the battle area.

BHARATPUR, India -- "Work Is Worship," says the big sign at the entrance to the plant makings railway freight cars in this teeming North Indian town. If the sign bears truth, then about 1,300 men who used to work in the sprawling, metal-roofed shed are not doing much worshiping these days.

DACCA, Pakistan, March 4 -- Sheik Mujibur Rahman, the East Pakistani nationalist leader, announced today that he had authorized some relaxation of the general strike he had called to protest the postponement of a constitutional assembly.

Both sides know the Nixon plan for "Vietnamizing" the Indochina war depends on at least partial victory in the continuing Laos battle. Partial victory means destruction of sufficient Communist stockpiles along the southward channel of the Ho Chi Minh Trail to prevent Hanoi from mounting another serious offensive for another year.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 4 -- Political extremists kidnapped four American airmen today and threatened their execution by a firing squad unless the United States paid a $400,000 ransom. The police arrested a suspect, prompting an additional demand that he be freed.
The city has requested $9.2-million in state funds to quadruple its methadone-maintenance treatment program to reach 9,000 addicts in the next 12 months, Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday.

Providence College and the University of Massachusetts yesterday became the fourth and fifth basketball teams to be entered to the 34th annual National Invitation Tournament. The tourney is scheduled for Madison Square Garden on March 20, 21, 22, 24, 25 and 27.

NEW DELHI, March 4 -- Tarkeshwari Sinha, a prominent member of the Old Congress party, has soft features and a mellifluous voice, both belying a tough spirit and a fiery tongue, which she has used successfully during the three decades of her political career.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The White House, after looking into various past activities of William J. Casey, President Nixon's nominee to head the Securities and Exchange Commission, has reaffirmed its support of Mr. Casey for the job.

Stuart Hodes's ballet "Abyss," which was first given by the Harkness Ballet six years ago, was revived by the City Center Joffrey Ballet at the New York City Center on Wednesday night. The leading roles, originally given at the work's premiere in Cannes, France, by Lone Isaksen and Erik Bruhn, were here danced by Lili Cockerille and Dennis Wayne.
The American Broadcasting Company yesterday filed a petition with the Federal Communications Commission asking a waiver of the F.C.C.'s three-hour prime time rule that will go into effect this Fall.

A ring of youthful muggers who the police said used young girls as lures and operated in the Times Square area were arrested yesterday. The gang, the police reported, was allegedly responsible for 75 to 100 muggings since the first of the year.
A revolt was building among community school boards yesterday against the Board of Education's order to lay off teachers and reduce services.

LEAD, S. D., March 4 (AP) -Denver University won first place in the downhill and the cross-country races today as the National Collegiate skiing championships began. The Pioneers took a big lead in their bid for a 14th title.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Representative Herman Badillo injected a new element into the debate on revenue sharing today by proposing that the Federal Government lend $20-billion to the states and cities over the next two years.
Neil Simon has written a new comedy, "The Prisoner of Second Avenue," which will be presented by Saint Subber on Nov. 10 at a theater to be announced.
ALBANY, March 4 -- State legislators from the New York City suburbs voiced vigorous opposition today to any city payroll tax that would put a heavier financial burden on their constituents.

PARIS, March 4 -- The Paris police took to the streets today in an effort to convince the public that they are not "fascists or sadists" but good citizens "loyal to the institutions of the republic and of democracy."
Punishing winds and driving snow lashed the Northeast yesterday, producing heavy snow accumulations inland and perilous conditions along the coast.
OTTAWA, March 4 -- One householder shoveled snow from his sidewalk through a window into a bathtub today to let warm water melt it and flush it down the drain.
OAKLAND, Calif., March 4 (UPI) -- A report in the Black Panther newspaper has accused Eldridge Cleaver, a fugitive, leader, of holding his wife, Kathleen, a prisoner in Algiers.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- A retired Army colonel told a panel of amused Senators of his running battle to prevent a brothel from being erected in the center of Army headquarters in Vietnam.

LONDON, March 4 -- Daniel J. Haughton, chairman of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, will meet airline customers for his Tristar jet in New York tomorrow in what could be a crucial session for the plane's future.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 4 -- A presidential search committee at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology is reliably reported to have selected Dr. Jerome B. Wiesner, former science adviser to President Kennedy, as its nominee to be the school's 13th president.
Three days of sporadic but repetitive power failures have reduced nearly 600 families in Riverdale to an uncertain state of existence.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Murray M. Chotiner, President Nixon's longtime political adviser, resigned from the White House staff today to enter private law practice here.

Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board, called yesterday for intensive and continuing negotiations between the Consolidated Edison Company and two unions representing 18,900 of the utility's workers.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -President Nixon indicated tonight that the United States was willing to see the Middle East cease-fire extended tacitly rather than by agreement, and he declined to put public pressure on Israel to make negotiating concessions to the Arabs.

WASHINGTON March 4 -- W. A. Boyle, president of the United Mine Workers of America, resigned today under Government pressure as a director of the union-owned National Bank of Washington.

Dorothy Kirsten made her debut with the Metropolitan Opera on Dec. 1, 1945, as Mimi in "La Boheme." On Wednesday night, she sang the same role with the company, celebrating 25 consecutive seasons there.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -President Nixon accused Senator Stuart Symington of Missouri of taking "a cheap shot" in suggesting that William P. Rogers had been Secretary of State in title only.

The restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored where indicated.

AUBURN, N.Y., March 4 -- It would not be completely accurate to describe this town in the Finger Lakes region as paralyzed by the snow that descended on upstate New York, but it certainly did slow things down.
SAIGON, March 4 (AP) -- The heavy fighting in Laos was reflected in the weekly casualty reports issued today by the allied commands here.
The 48 regular substitute teachers at Junior High School 13 in Harlem worked as usual yesterday alongside the 33 regularly licensed teachers, but they were worried and confused.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The Tariff Commission ruled today that Japanese television sets were being sold in the United States at less than fair value and should be subject to special dumping duties. The commission said that as a result of the dumping domestic television makers were being injured.

NASSAU, Bahamas, March 4 -- A 31-mile race around Booby Rocks tomorrow is all that separates Running Tide, a one-year-old sloop, from being acclaimed the champion of the Southern Ocean Racing Conference now.
Judith Alstadter, a New York pianist who made her debut here last year playing a program of Faure's music, returned to Tully Hall on Wednesday night with a varied program.

MANILA, March 4 (AP) -Moslems armed with rifles and machine guns attacked Iligan and seized the provincial capital on Tuesday, the Philippine News Service reported today.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- President Nixon proposed today that states and cities be allowed to use Federal money to create temporary public service jobs for the unemployed.

Since its inception in 1968, the Studio Museum in Harlem has directed its attention to survey exhibitions of black artists. Although such exhibitions made the art world aware that there was a community of black artists, the shows have been nonetheless criticized as weak and ineffective.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (UPI) -- The Senate Judiciary Committee unanimously approved a constitutional amendment today that would give 18-year-olds the right to vote in all elections.

The all-star Precision Club touring team, including Benito Garozzo and Giorgio Belladonna of Rome, and Robert Jordan and Arthur Robinson of Philadelphia, begins two days of serious competition here today. They will face the toughest opposition they have yet met in their American tour.

In the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More here yesterday afternoon Miss Constance York was married to Terence David Lynch by the Rev. John C. Calhoun.

LINDEN, N.J., March 4 (AP) -- The Humble Oil and Refining Company said today that its investigation had showed that the Dec. 5 explosion and fire at its Bayway plant here stemmed from an overheated reactor, rather than sabotage, as was originally suspected.
Three years ago last month, Henry Lewis stepped into the history books when he took charge of the New Jersey Symphony and thus became the first black musical director of a United States orchestra.

Two bulletins from the Dream Factory: the autobiography of one of its discontinued products, and a fiction about the packaging of a model that never reaches the market. ATHENS, March 4 -- Four underground organizations have compiled what they describe as a blacklist of about 2,000 Greeks who are termed collaborators with the ruling military junta.

Willie Morris resigned unexpectedly yesterday as editor in chief of Harper's Magazine, a post the 36-year-old writer had held for the last four years.

A tearful 19-year-old girl who said she heard the two pistol shots that killed her boyfriend last Saturday night was held in $100,000 bail in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday as a material witness to the murder.

MIAMI, March 4 -- Jack Nicklaus suffered a scoring let-down today as he resumed his tournament campaign after winning the Professional Golfers' Association title last Sunday. The New York Rangers will carry a six-game winning streak into the Olympia tonight when they face the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League game that will be televised in New York over WOR (Channel 9) beginning at 8 o'clock.

A new -- but don't get too excited -- musical, "Look Where I'm At!" opened last night at Theater Four, where once Mart Crowley's boys had their band on 55th Street. At least I presumed it opened. I saw it Thursday night on its final preview.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The White House made public today the following recapitulation of American prisoners of war and men missing in action to clarify President Nixon's statement at his news conference last night that "there are 1,600 Americans in North Vietnam jails under very difficult circumstances at the present time":

DETROIT, March 5 (UPI) -- Lew Alcindor and Oscar Robertson, who have sparked Milwaukee all season, dominated the game with the Detroit Pistons tonight in leading their team to a 108-95 victory that gave the Bucks 19 straight triumphs -- a National Basketball Association record.
The Procter Gamble Company raised prices yesterday effective April on all gylcerin grades by 1 cent a pound, making P.'s average price 21 3/4 cents a pound. Glycerin is used in making soap.
ALBANY, March 5 -- Governor Rockefeller urged the Legislature today to bar the display of pornographic materials in public places or places "easily visible from public thoroughfares."

ANKARA, Turkey, Saturday, March 6 -- Two persons were killed and more than a dozen wounded yesterday when students exchanged shots with troops trying to enter a university dormitory in search of four kidnapped American airmen. One of those killed was a student and the other a Turkish soldier.

OTTAWA, March 5 -- Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, no longer Canada's most eligible bachelor, was warmly congratulated by political friends and foes today on his surprise marriage last night to Miss Margaret Sinclair. The bridegroom is 51 years old and the bride 22.
Mayor Lindsay deferred the public unveiling of his package of new taxes yesterday after his top officials briefed Governor Rockefeller's advisers.

The last of 44 welfare families housed at the Margaret Fahnestock Nurses Residence since they occupied the offices of Human Resources Administrator Jule M. Sugarman in January was moved from the residence yesterday and assured of an apartment.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, March 6 -- More South Vietnamese troops moved westward across the enemy's supply-trail network in Laos yesterday, and helicopter-borne advance units were reported preparing a ring of troop landing zones near the key junction town of Tchepone.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- "The military's job is to fight and not to lead social revolutions."

CAIRO, March 5 -- The Egyptian leadership has decided to continue "withholding fire" along the Suez Canal after the expiration of the cease-fire this weekend to give a "last chance" to diplomatic efforts for a peaceful settlement with Israel, reliable sources here reported today.

HAMPTON, Va., March 5 (UPI) -- Ion Tiriac of Rumania came from a 1-5 game disadvantage in the first set to win it, 7-5, and then went on to defeat Thomas Koch of Brazil today in the quarterfinals of the National Indoor tennis tournament.
An estimated total of 35,000 Penn Central riders were delayed for up to 80 minutes by a series of mechanical problems during the morning rush hour yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird announced today a major new program that will require every man in the armed forces to attend classes in race relations.
LISBON, March 5 -- Portugal accused Zambia today of responsibility for the kidnapping of 11 civilians of Portuguese nationality by Mozambique nationalists based in Zambia.

PARIS, March 5 (AP) -- An American citizens' group trying to learn more about the issues of the Vietnam war met with North Vietnamese officials today. A conflict was shaping up over a meeting with United States officials.

KEHL, West Germany -- In this bustling German border town on the east bank of the Rhine opposite Strasbourg, French buses mingle casually with the local traffic, French soldiers sip pernod with German girls at corner bars, and on Europe Bridge, Kehl's only road link to France, the French tricolor and the black, red and gold ensign of West Germany flutter side by side in the breeze.

MENLO PARK, Calif., March 5 -- Allan Nevins, the historian and biographer who won two Pulitzer Prizes and pioneered in the establishment of the oral history movement, died today in a nursing home after a long illness. He was 80 years old.
Nina De-Nur, a native-born Israeli, says she is in the United States "looking for Arabs."

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- Three corporations and four individuals were indicted today in connection with the publishing of an abbreviated text of a Federal pornography report, accompanied by allegedly obscene pictures.
School Chancellor Harvey B Scribner said yesterday that he "will not honor payrolls that are in violation of Board of Education policies" requiring a cutback in school personnel starting Monday.

Religious orders who have withdrawn teaching nuns and brothers from many Roman Catholic schools were reminded yesterday by a high-ranking member of the church that they may be "abandoning the schools at a time when the church urgently needs them."

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers urged the Senate today to approve the 1925 Geneva protocol banning chemical and biological warfare but with the understanding that the United States would remain free to use tear gases and herbicides.

The chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation announced last night that a permanent injunction had been entered, with the consent of Occidental and himself in the United States District Court here in an action brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
ALBANY, March 5 -- Governor Rockefeller put his signature today on a bill that lengthens the thoroughbred racing season by nine days and increases the pari-mutuel betting takeout by 1 per cent.
LONDON, March 5 -- The British Government has offered to invest an additional $144-million in development of the Rolls-Royce RB-211 engine.

James Farmer, the civil rights leader who resigned three months ago as Assistant Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, warned yesterday that cities might use Federal revenue-sharing funds to disperse blacks who had begun to gain political power.

MIAMI BEACH, March 5 -- With the fight only three days away, Muhammad Ali refrained from sparring at the Fifth Street gym today. Instead he went through what his trainer, Angelo Dundee, called a "shake-out," defined by Dundee as "keeping loose and doing his own thing."
PRINCETON, N. J., March 5 -- Each long jump pit has a personality, Fred Samara said today. But not every pit has feeling. You know, soul.

With the air of a heavy-weight champion who knows the weaknesses of all his opponents, Prof. Paul A. Samuelson defended the new economics at the New School for Social Research here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The nation's unemployment rate declined in February for the second consecutive month, the Labor Department reported today.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that the advisory committee of its board of governors had censured and fined two specialists, who make markets in stocks assigned to them on the exchange's trading floor.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 5 -- Secretary General Thant appealed publicly to Israel today to reconsider and "respond favorably" to a request by Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, the United Nations intermediary, for a commitment to withdraw her forces from all Egyptian territory.

The Glen Alden Corporation's plan to merge Schenley Industries, Inc., into the parent company met another potential roadblock yesterday with the filing of the second lawsuit in two days to thwart the plan.

An unusual match will be played today at the Mayfair House of Bridge, 119 West 57th Street. Prices on the London Stock Exchange moved fractionally lower yesterday in quiet dealings.

PHILADELPHIA, March 5 (UPI) -- John Maull, a sophomore, came off the bench to score 12 points in the last 10 minutes and led La Salle to a 74-71 victory over Lafayette tonight in the Middle Atlantic Conference University Division playoffs at the Palestra.

DETROIT, March 5 (AP) -- United States auto production remained unchanged this week from last week's level as continued heavy overtime by the General Motors Corporation was offset by cutbacks by the American Motors Corporation. MIAMI, March 5 -- Bruce Fleisher, a 22-year-old golfer who lacks credentials to play on the pro circuit, moved into a tie for second place today after two rounds of the $150,000 Doral Eastern open tourney. He scored a five-under par 67 for a total of 139.

NASSAU, Bahamas, March 5 -- Dora won the Nassau Cup today, Running Tide clinched the season's S.O.R.C. title, Sorcery crossed the finish line first and Andante II, a little Class E boat, was the surprise of the fleet in the final event of the Southern Ocean Racing Conference.

LONDON, Ontario -- Many Londoners are shocked to find that Canada's economic slump, accompanied by generally heavy unemployment, has touched this normally busy, typical industrial city in the heart of Ontario's "golden triangle."

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The Justice Department asserted today that it had not granted antitrust immunity to United States oil companies for coordinating their negotiations with oil-producing countries. But the department refused to state precisely what it had told the oil companies.
A three-alarm fire raged through a 125-year-old Episcopal church in Greenwich Village early this morning.

TOKYO, March 5 -- Japanese television manufacturers said today that they would fight to the finish against the United States Tariff Commission's ruling that they had dumped television sets on the American market.

NARITA, Japan, March 5 -- Ever so gently, a leafless tree, three young farmers in helmets still clinging to its trunk, was lowered to the ground. Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday creation of a seven-man committee to study the future of the Municipal Broadcasting System. One area of study is the feasibility of creating a Public Broadcasting Center here.

PARIS -- While negotiators in Brussels are wrangling over how much Britain would pay in her first year of European Common Market membership, another point of contention -- sterling itself -- is developing behind the scenes.

CAIRO, March 6 -- Irritated by a focus of world attention on the Suez Canal cease-fire instead of on what Cairo regards as the basic issues of an ArabIsraeli settlement, Egyptian leaders appeared determined today to allow the cease-fire to lapse, while keeping their guns silent for the time being under a voluntary "withholding of fire."

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- A study group report initiated and endorsed by top officials in the Nixon Administration challenged today the traditional institutions of higher education and called for an "intensive national effort" to develop an alternative system.

Eric J. Schmertz, chairman of an impasse panel in the firemen's contract dispute with the city, recommended settlement terms yesterday. He did not make the details public, explaining that the presentation to both parties was confidential.
ROME March 8 -- The Italian educational system is in a state of disarray.

TOKYO, March 8 -- The Japan Textile Federation, which represents all major groups in the textile field, declared today that it would voluntarily restrict exports of textiles to the United States for a three-year period beginning July 1.

Two months ago the State Legislature unanimously passed a bill again extending the life of the city's Interim Board of Education for another year, this time until June 30, 1972. In part, the Legislature's action was motivated by a desire to put off until next year a decision on how a permanent school board should be selected.

JERSEY CITY, March 8 -- City Clerk Thomas F. X. Smith announced today that two rival insurgent political organizations that were independently seeking the removal of Mayor Thomas J. Whelan had filed enough petitions between them to force a recall election.

Each week about 1,000 patients of mental hospitals and narcotics treatment centers enjoy a free night out here. They are seated as house guests at theatrical, musical and sports events because of the work of a former pianist named Michael Jon Spencer.

SAIGON, March 8 -- Informed American sources said today that most of the South Vietnamese operation against North Vietnamese troop concentrations and supply depots in Cambodia had come to a halt following the death of its dynamic first commander, Lieut. Gen. Do Cao Tri.

In a complex, three-way deal the Abacus Fund, Inc., announced a preliminary agreement to sell its 25 per cent working control of the Security National Bank, Huntington, L. I., and then merge into the Leasco Corporation.

An experimental course, spawned in part by the 1968 strike at Columbia University, has been keeping its students in class for as long as 13 hours a day in what some of the students consider a "constructive revolution."

NEW HAVEN -- I do not see how anyone who seriously undertakes to look at our present society can proceed without first addressing himself to the problem of advanced monopoly capitalism and its relationship to the impoverished majority of the world. The facts speak louder than ideology.

St. John's, La'Salle, Hawaii, Georgia Tech and Syracuse were named yesterday to the National Invitation Tournament, bringing the field to 10 teams. Six berths remain to be filled for the basketball tournament, which will open at Madison Square Garden with an afternoon triple-header and an evening double-header on March 20 and conclude a week later.
Six top editors of Harper's Magazine are expected to act as a unit and remain or resign together at a meeting this evening with John Cowles Jr., chairman of the board of Harper's.

Robert Kasanof, a former trial lawyer for the Legal Aid Society, has been appointed the attorney-in-charge of the society's Criminal Courts branch, Orison S. Marden, chairman of the board of directors, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The New York Stock Exchange and the new off-track betting agency in that city have been wrangling as to whether playing the ponies or plunging in the market is the safer investment. Neither is as risky as predicting elections, conventions, primaries, etc.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Capt. Ernest L. Medina, the commander of the infantry company that swept through the hamlet of Mylai 4, was ordered today to stand trial on charges of premeditated murder and assault with a dangerous weapon.
ALBANY, March 8 -- The Assembly gave final legislative approval today to a bill repealing the long-time ban on the sale of alcoholic beverages on primary and election days.

President Nguyen Van Thieu's repeated threats to invade North Vietnam and President Richard Nixon's refusal to deny American military involvement in such an invasion compel us to ask these questions: Is there any reason to believe Hanoi would not devote all its resources to defeating such an invasion? Should Hanoi fail, is Peking's involvement not inevitable?

The corporate bond market -- delicately balanced between heavy financing demands on the one hand and large amounts of investible funds on the other -- showed added signs yesterday that the sharp recent rise in interest rates may be nearing an end.
The Apollo 14 astronauts, interrupted occasionally by demonstrations for better schools and welfare housing, received the honors of the city yesterday.

Pennsylvania's misfortune may trun out to be another boost to Fordham's chances in the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament that starts Saturday. If these teams make it through the first two rounds they will meet in the third round or Eastern Re gional final on March 20, at Raleigh, N. C.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 8 (UPI) -- Vice President Agnew said today that American Indians must have the right to govern their lands and their resources but the Federal Government must continue to provide financial support.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Congressional leaders announced today that "private sources" had offered a $100,000 reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the person or persons who bombed the Capitol a week ago.
JERSEY CITY, March 8 -- Jersey City's 40 public schools were closed today by order of the School Superintendent after 425 noninstructional personnel struck for higher wages.
WASHINGTON, March 8 United States officials said today that the Administration had adopted a policy of not paying ransom in cases of political kidnapping.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Senator Vance Hartke warned today that nationalization of American railroads was a distinct threat if there was a financial collapse of the industry.

WESTBURY, L.I., March 8 -- The Schenck Transportation Company, the outfit that provides "wheels" for those improvers of the breed who like to be taken from the flat racing to the trots, had six buses ready and waiting in the north parking area at Aqueduct this afternoon.

TORONTO, March 8 -- The Canadian Government is pressing Washington to forget about a trans-Alaska oil pipeline in favor of a line that would bring Alaskan oil to the United States by way of Canada's Northwest Territories and prairie provinces.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, March 9 (AP) -- Two hundred fifty North Vietnamese soldiers were reported killed in Laos yesterday in a battle with South Vietnamese marines who were heavily supported by artillery barrages and American air strikes.
Joe Frazier is the master of the boxing world. The 27 year-old Philadelphian realized his dream last night when he won undisputed claim to the heavyweight championship.

The International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday a new computer aimed at the heart of the multi-billion dollar data-processing market -- the medium-scale user.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Chairman Wright Patman and eight other members of the House Banking Committee introduced legislation today aimed at reducing the economic power of banks and other financial institutions.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 8 -- While trying not to worry about Mel Stottlemyre's stiff shoulder, the New York Yankees posted a 2-1 victory over the Atlanta Braves today and made their won-lost exhibition record 3-1.

CLEVELAND, March 8 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury investigating possible antitrust violations in the National Football League questioned today the Cleveland Browns' owner, Arthur Modell; the San Francisco 49ers' quarterback, John Brodie, and the Baltimore Colts' tight end, John Mackey.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 8 -- The Palestinian guerrilla movement is having financial difficulties. Its budget has shown a deficit for the first time since the movement began six years ago.

The great relief at the release unharmed of the four hostages must be accompanied by deep satisfaction that Turkey refused to negotiate with the left-wing revolutionaries and that the United States, in support of this stand, ignored the demands for $400,000 in ransom.

The owners of the 14-story, 98-family apartment house that will rise on the southwest corner of Harlem's 147th Street and Seventh Avenue, watched excitedly yesterday as a roaring bulldozer dug a foundation and five trucks hauled away dirt and rubble.

Sam Shepard is fascinated by America's folk heroes, which for him means not merely historical and legendary figures, but also movie and pop stars. These larger-than-life people and their illusions -- almost everyone wants to be someone else -- populate the stage in his free-wheeling new play "Mad Dog Blues," now running at Theater Genesis.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- (UPI) -- The Nixon Administration proposed today that states be required to spend a fixed amount for education of the poor under the President's revenue-sharing plan.

ALBANY, March 8 -- Governor Rockefeller refused to say today whether he would seek another term as Governor, but he did not rule out the possibility of seeking the Presidency if President Nixon decided not to seek re-election in 1972.

Like a lot of other people, Assemblyman Samuel D. Wright was looking forward yesterday to seeing the fight between Muhammad Ali and Joe Frazier. But regardless of the outcome at Madison Square Garden, Mr. Wright was assured of having another kind of fight to occoupy his attention today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 8 -- An apprehensive mood reigns in the countryside around Vietnam's capital city, whose, defense has been left to irregulars and auxiliary forces while nearly 50,000 of Saigon's best troops have been moved out of the country to fight North Vietnamese troops in Cambodia and Laos.
TRIPOLI, Libya, March 8 -- The negotiations over Libya's demands for increased oil revenues are going badly for the American and other foreign companies involved, Western sources said today.

Sears, Roebuck Co., the world's largest merchandising organization, had record profits for the 10th successive year and peak sales for the 16th consecutive year in the annual period ended Jan. 31. NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 8 -- Dr. Jean Wilson Day, a 40-year-old assistant professor of chemistry at Rutgers University, was bludgeoned to death in her bedroom near the university's Piscataway campus early yesterday morning.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation achieved new highs in sales and earnings for 1970. The company announced yesterday that its operations last year marked the 11th consecutive year of record performance.

And they have plenty to choose from.

Dow Chemical of Canada, Ltd., has announced the appointment of Clyde H. Boyd as president and a director of the company. Leroy D. Smithers, formerly president, has been made chairman. Mr. Boyd joined the Dow Chemical Company in 1941 and in 1966 he was named director of manufacturing for Dow's European operations and in 1967 was appointed a vice president of Dow Chemical Europe S.A., the position he has held until the present time.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 11 -- There is just no escape from the continuing shock waves generated by The Fight. Even in this baseball-oriented territory the sports pages are still brightened by aftermath stories of the Frazier-Ali superspectacular and ballplayers pounce on newly arrived eyewitnesses for still further details. Strangely enough, though, there is far less curiosity about Joe Frazier, the winner, than about the loser, the man most players called Cassius Clay.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- President Nixon rejected as inadequate today the plan announced earlier this week by Japan to restrict textile exports to the United States, and again threw his "strong support" behind legislation to restrict textile imports by mandatory quotas.
NEW HAVEN, March 11 -- For the first time in Yale's 270 years, a woman has been nominated to the Yale Corporation -- the university's 16-member board of trustees.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission told the New York Stock Exchange today that it must terminate price-fixing of commissions on large stock transactions no later than April 5, even though it is not technically possible to amend the exchange's constitution by that date.

Fordham, which returned to varsity football competition in 1970 after a 16-year absence, will play Columbia in the 1972 opening game for both teams. The contest is scheduled for Sept. 30 at Baker Field, Columbia's home arena.

SALT LAKE CITY, March 10 -- Three documents labeled "indictment," which have been on file with the United States District Court clerk here for two weeks, accuse the sheriff of Salt Lake County of cheating jail prisoners out of their proper food in order to enrich himself.

NOVI SAD, Yugoslavia -- Young people are disappearing from Yugoslavia's granary, the Serbian autonomous province of Vojvodina, moving into this attractive provincial capital on the banks of the Danube, and leaving behind a social and economic problem that officials believe is critical.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 11 -- The Saigon Government's plan to move refugees from the northern part of South Vietnam to the southern part has been quietly set aside in favor of resettling them within their native provinces, American officials said today.

Up to 1,000 students and faculty members of the Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School in Brooklyn staged a two hour-demonstration yesterday outside Governor Rockefeller's office on West 55th Street to support state aid for students in nonpublic schools.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The Senate, in the first legislative setback for the President's proposal to merge Federal aid programs into broad revenue-sharing plans with the states, voted today to extend the Appalachian Regional Development Commission for another four years.

FORT BENNING, Ga., March 11 -- The final witness in the court-martial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. said today that troops involved in the Mylai killings were so unready for combat that the brigade commander protested and asked for 60 additional days of training in Hawaii before the men were shipped to Vietnam in December, 1967.
In February, before last week's network TV bull market, prices had dropped so that, although the amount of time sold was 1.6 per cent more than in February, 1970, revenues had fallen 9 per cent.

ABETONE, Italy, March 11 (AP) -- Annemarie Proell of Austria continued her domination of women's Alpine skiing today by winning the final giant slalom of the Foemina Cup competition.

Fewer spectators will be able to sit in the grandstand at the St. Patrick's Day parade next week because the city has decided it cannot afford to replace deteriorating bleachers.
The restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored where indicated.

A State Supreme Court justice yesterday dismissed a contempt indictment against Hugh Mulligan, who has been described by the police as a major bookmaker and loan shark with 50 employes and a key corrupter of policemen.
