UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 12 -- Yosef Tekoah, the Israeli delegate, met for the second consecutive day today with Dr. Jarring. Both meetings were at Mr. Tekoah's request.

The philosophical thrust of the National Urban League -- toward an economically strong black community integrated into the general society -- will not be radically changed by the death on Thursday of Whitney M. Young Jr., the organization's best-known executive director.
The demand for early 19th-century English porcelain remains strong despite the growing interest in earlier work.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Because of increased printing costs, the Patent Office expects to suspend issuance of patents for 12 weeks this summer. After May 18, none will be granted until Aug. 10.

That some academics, students and intellectuals have dropped their support for Israel is hardly news. In part it seems a quite normal development. A power struggle rages in the Middle East; both sides make passionate claims; the arguments grow complicated. Serious people, it follows, may find the Israeli case not entirely persuasive.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Much of Premier Golda Meir's outline of an Arab-Israeli settlement has been put forward publicly by Israeli officials before, but some of her comments about the terms for the Sinai Peninsula are new at this juncture in the negotiations.

Tickets for run-of-the-mill opera performances may not be selling now the way they were this time last year, but the New York State Theater was filled Thursday night for the New York City Opera's presentation of Donizetti's "Lucia di Lammermoor" with Beverly Sills in the title role.

Three new elementary schools, 24 small size elementary schools and a variety of other school buildings and plans -- $47.5-million worth in all -- are being added to the city's capital construction plans.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- American negotiators flew to Vienna today for the fourth round of the talks on the limitation of strategic arms with little hope of an early break in the deadlock with the Soviet Union on major issues.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- A gala affair, graced with assorted Senators, ambassadors and social superstars, welcomed the Age of Aquarius of the nation's capital tonight at the official opening here of "Hair."
Tomorrow at 9 P.M. the "Burr Bacharach Special" will be shown on the Columbia Broadcasting System. All right. Now consider for a moment the peculiar genre of the Television Special.

LOS ANGELES -- It would have been very nice had cops not forgotten that historically it has been their destiny to forbear -- that, like Bernard Malamud's Jewish protagonists, one can become ennobled and liberated by his ability to silently abide.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- State Department officials said today that an unarmed United States Navy freighter was halted briefly yesterday by warning shots from an Ecuadorian warship, then allowed to proceed.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff said today that the late Representative L. Mendel Rivers, who was chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, had tried to stop a Senate inquiry into alleged corruption in Army post exchanges.
The Consolidated Edison Company and two unions that had threatened to strike tomorrow reached tentative agreements last night.
A plan to help avoid another transit fare increase next Jan. 1 by imposing new bridge and tunnel tolls is being seriously considered by the city and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

Institutional investors accounted for most of the record volume on the New York Stock Exchange during the first two months of this year, Stan West, director of research for the exchange, announced yesterday.
I differ with Prof. Henry S. Commager as to the wisdom of tuition charges. [Op-Ed Feb. 25.] His opposition rests on two claims:
DETROIT, March 12 -- Eighty minutes after he qualified in the one-mile run, Marty Liquori won his first National Collegiate indoor track and field title tonight in the two-mile run.
The builder of the 40-story addition to the Bankers Trust Building at 280 Park Avenue sued for $80-million in damages yesterday in the State Supreme Court.
Prices on the New York Stock Exchange wound up the week just about where they began as the market wandered indecisively yesterday.
Michael J. Maye, president of the Uniformed Firefighters Association, called upon Mayor Lindsay yesterday to sit down personally and negotiate a new agreement with the firemen.

Fordham's basketball team, attempting to emulate the New York success stories of the 1968 Jets and the 1969 Mets, will meet Furman in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship tonight.
BALTIMORE, March 12 -- Dr. Lincoln Gordon, president of Johns Hopkins University since 1967, resigned today.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- When someone presents a credit card in charging a purchase, a skeptical clerk can insert it in a sensor on his desk and have the rightful holder's picture displayed. The system, protected by Patent 3,569,619, granted this week, is the latest of the many inventions of Luther G. Simjian, president of General Research, Inc., Greenwich, Conn.
RICHMOND, Ind., March 12 (AP) -- The police arrested 89 demonstrators today when they refused to abandon a sit-in outside the Richmond High School principal's office.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- The Senate's passage today of Social Security legislation has all but assured an additional Government stimulus for the economy this year of at least $4-billion.

MILLBURN, N. J., March 12 -- Attorney General John N. Mitchell said tonight that the Justice Department hoped to recommend ways to establish a "predictable time" after which a convicted person's opportunities for appeal would have been exhausted.
SYDNEY, Australia, March 12 (AP) -- Ken Roswell gained the final of the Dunlop Australian open tennis championship tonight by beating Tom Okker of the Netherlands, 6-2, 7-6, 6-4.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers reportedly indicated to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that the United States believes a more flexible Israeli negotiating position will be necessary to break the Middle East deadlock.

AUSTIN, Tex., March 12 (AP) -- A homemade bomb was found tonight by a policeman at Municipal Auditorium while a dinner attended by former President Lyndon B. Johnson and Gov. Preston Smith was in progress.

" Going vertical" has always been identified in business with bigness. Visions of many plants of a single company devoted to a full spectrum of activities, from the manufacture of primary materials all the way to production of the finished consumer product, have loomed large in the minds of most people contemplating the concept of "going vertical."
Trading was desultory and prices were mixed yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.
The new-issue market scored another sharp advance this week in heavy trading, and underwriters prepared a large number of first public offerings for next week.

Netty Simons presented six of her "chance" works written in the last three years at Carnegie Recital Hall Thursday night, and she provided her expert performers with good, sharp ideas to toss around. The results were often attractive.
WASHINGTON, March 12 (Reuters) -- President Nixon has directed the Tariff Commission to investigate whether quotas are necessary on certain cheeses from Western Europe.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (UPI) -- The Federal Trade Commission, in the first such move of its kind, said today that it would seek a Federal court injunction prohibiting Philip Morris, Inc., from inserting millions of samples of Personna razor blades in Sunday newspapers.

Arthur Mitchell's Dance Theater of Harlem ended its three performances at the ANTA Theater last night with a familiar program. This Broadway debut has been a great success. Mr. Mitchell, his associate artistic director, Karel Shook, and their 24 dancers have had a great deal of sentiment on their side.

Mozart and Bruckner make an ideal concert pairing, as Karl Bohm showed in his guest appearance with the New York Philharmonic Thursday night. Starting with Mozart's Symphony No. 33 in B flat (K.319), a deceptively light and dry wine that can suddenly turn heady, the conductor capped off the feast with one of the heaviest ports in the symphonic repertory, Bruckner's Eighth Symphony.
NEWPORT, R. I., March 12 (AP) -- Several hundred protesting construction workers were blocked by military policemen today from entering the naval base where President Nixon was speaking.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- New evidence suggesting that viruses are a factor in causing human-breast cancer has been reported by an international team of scientists.
WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- A Pennsylvania chemical company canceled today its planned dumping of waste arsenic compounds into the ocean at the request of the Federal Government.
Personality, the Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs colt who was acclaimed champion of his class in 1970, will make his local debut as a 4-year-old today when he competes in the Paumonok Handicap at Aqueduct.

The National Urban League announced yesterday that President Nixon would attend the funeral service for Whitney M. Young Jr. to be held here Tuesday morning at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, March 13 (AP) -- South Vietnamese forces in Laos pulled back yesterday from positions near Tchepone, former transshipment point on the enemy's supply trail complex.
I warmly applaud A. H. Raskin's column ("Unused Inflation Curb" March 1) and I would like to embellish it with some additional facts.

The stock on Roy Buckley Enterprises, Ltd., took a big jump last night after the 27-year - old right - hander from Columbus, Ohio, held the lead in the $85,000 Cougar open with a score of 9,343 after 40 games.

PHILADELPHIA, March 12 -- Tom Aretz of Villanova won his second title in two nights by taking the 100-yard breast-stroke final in 59.20 seconds tonight in the 31st Eastern Seaboard intercollegiate swimming championships at the University of Pennsylvania's Scheer Pool.

WEST POINT, N. Y., March 12 -- New York University won the team championships in epee and foil today and opened a large lead in its bid for a third Intercollegiate Fencing Association three-weapon crown in the last four years.

The City's Council Against Poverty reversed its previous ruling and voted early yesterday morning to allow Aspira, one of the city's major Puerto Rican self-help agencies, to continue to operate under its present format.

Pan American World Airways filed a $24-million suit yesterday against the United States Government, Lloyd's of London and 14 leading American and British insurance companies on its claim involving damages caused when Arab guerrilla hijackers blew up one of its 747 jets in Cairo last September.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 12 -- Danny Cater has three names and three positions, but no hits.
PITTSBURGH, March 12 (UPI) -- The United Steelworkers of America announced today that a wage contract proposal had been negotiated with three major can manufacturers to settle a 26-day strike.

LOS ANGELES, March 12 (AP) -- A Federal judge said today he had issued an order in the Spencer Haywood case invalidating the National Basketball Association's rule against signing college athletes before their class was graduated.

ATLANTA, March 12 -- In 1943, when he was a strapping, 13-year-old kid in the Pennsylvania coal fields, Anthony Bernard Herbert ran away from home and enlisted in the Marines. "I guess I should be glad Mom came and took me back," he laughs now.
LONDON, March 12 -- The training of lawyers in England and Wales would give much greater emphasis to academic work under proposals made this week by an official Committee on Legal Education.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., March 12 -- Competing on deep snow that compared favorably with depths usually found in their Alps, France and Italy dominated the opening of the World Student Alpine racing trials today.

The periodic discussions of how we select Presidential candidates usually assume two polar positions. One suggests the abolition of the national convention as unsightly, undemocratic and boss-ridden, and the substitution of a national primary. The other argues that a national primary would restrict the nomination to wealthy athletes, i.e., those who have the stamina and money to survive a first primary, a possible runoff primary and the election campaign itself.
Official figures disclosed by Premier Chou En-lai indicate that Communist China has made significant, though limited, economic progress in the last decade.

DES MOINES, Iowa, March 12 (UPI) -- Mediapolis High School ended Montezuma High School's 89-game victory streak, 104-103, today in the quarterfinal round of the Iowa Girls' High School basketball tournament.
MARSEILLES, France, March 11 -- "When you have a good mayor, you keep him," proclaims a poster in the streets of France's second largest city. "Comiti will do better," another says.

SAIGON, March 12 (Reuters) -- North Vietnamese forces were warned of a South Vietnamese attack in southern Laos last October, or four months before it started, and were told they must crush it at any cost, a former North Vietnamese master sergeant said at a news conference here today.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., March 7 -- The new man in town, the Rev. Carl McIntire, has become, this space-center village's most controversial figure in his first few weeks on the scene.
The New York Telephone Company has applied to the State Public Service Commission for permision to install picture telephones after May 1.

DETROIT, March 12 (UPI) -- United States passenger-car production jumped significantly this week with 13 General Motors assembly plants turning out cars on overtime, Ward's Automotice Reports said today.
Mayor Lindsay calls his tax program a "survival package," but the question is whether this plan to boost taxes by $880 million will save the city or hasten its decline.

Three hours is an inordinately long time to wait for a jazz concert to come to life. But despite the efforts of a quintet, a quartet and a 17-piece band, that was how long it took Thursday night for a concert at Town Hall for the benefit of Phoenix House to lift itself from a sense of placidity that settled early and hung doggedly on.
LONDON, March 12 -- Paul McCartney today won the first round in his battle to dissolve the Beatles' partnership when a High Court judge appointed a public receiver to manage the group's assets.
NEW DELHI, March 12 -- Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has won a stunning personal triumph.

ROME, March 12 -- The Chamber of Deputies was asked by legal authorities today to authorize criminal proceedings against one of its members, Carlo Felici, on corruption charges involving American pinball machines.
NEW DELHI, March 12 -- Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's New Congress party emerged today as the supreme force in Parliament, sweeping opposition parties of both left and right into insignificance.

BOSTON, March 12 -- Clarkson College of Potsdam, N. Y., ended Cornell's four-year title reign, 4-1, and Harvard upset the nation's No. 1 ranked team, Boston University, 4-2 in semifinal-round games of the Eastern hockey championships tonight in the Boston Garden.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 12 -- Kermit Zarley, the Canadian open champion, equaled the course record of 64 today and with a 36-hole aggregate of 132 overtook Arnold Palmer, Jerry Heard and others to lead the $150,000 Florida Citrus invitation tourney.

The report of two investigators for the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on conditions in Greece under the Army regime makes gloomy but familiar reading. It will surprise only those who have taken seriously the fatuous statements of Defense and State Department officials about the early restoration of a constitutional order and parliamentary democracy in Greece.

The place to develop a big jazz band nowadays, it would appear, is on a television talk show. Billy Taylor, whose 11-piece band works the "David Frost Show," yesterday brought it out from behind the conversation and commercials that normally obscure it to present it live -- vividly alive -- at Downbeat, 42d Street and Lexington Avenue, as part of the weekly noontime Jazz Adventures series.
Corrugated shipping containers, which are looked upon as "coincidental indicators" of the economy, are becoming more costly.

LONDON, March 12 -- "I suppose you Americans have twice our income per capita, but that is just a way of lying with statistics. This is a better country to live in, we all know that: more comfortable, less worried, a satisfactory life. The fact that we show up poorer in the figures does not really matter."

A year ago, in one of the more despicable acts of violence committed by white segregationists, a mob in Lamar, S. C., stormed three school buses carrying Negro children to a newly integrated school. Police, also under heavy attack, used tear gas to disperse the rioters but said that their primary concern for the youngsters' safety prevented them from making arrests on the scene.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 12 -- A 21-year-old ex-convict was arraigned here early this morning in the murders of two teen-agers last month.

The statements of concern and the rhetoric of "involvement 'in the community'' that emanated from so many public relations departments of major corporations a few years ago seem to have given way, if not to a retreat, then to an orderly withdrawal, from the problems of society.

Politicians and union leaders, welfare mothers and doctors, crowded a Congressional hearing on Staten Island yesterday to try to help determine the uncertain future of the United States Public Health Service Hospital there.
Your Feb. 13 editorial criticizing my recent order to the Housing and Development Administration is so permeated with error that the record must be set straight.

DETROIT, March 12 -- An agreement that could become an important step toward reuniting the labor movement was signed today by the United Automobile Workers and the International Machinist and Aerospace Workers Union.
A Jewish student press, reflecting what has been called "a new Jewish consciousness," has arisen on college campuses in North America.

Armand Grover Erpf, a senior partner of Loeb, Rhoades Co., an investment banking firm, and a supporter of publishing enterprises including New York magazine, left an estate valued at about $8-million, according to a will filed in Surrogate Court here yesterday.

Francine Farkas, Alexander's fashion director, wore her black velvet hot pants outfit to introduce the store's spring fashions for men the other day. Everybody agreed she looked cute. But when a male model emerged in similar pants over black pantyhose and with a ruffled white shirt, the audience howled and let out a wolf whistle or two.

SEOUL, South Korea, March 12 -- A Defense Ministry spokesman said today that South Korean troops had completed the replacement of American soldiers on the Korean armistice border under the United States military cutback program.

BONN, March 12 -- Two years after tenuous consolidation through merger, West Germany's coal-mining industry is facing a new crisis, but this time it is poor management and not dwindling demand for coal that is causing the problems.

BOWIE, Md., March 12 (AP) -- Mrs. Stephen C. Clark Jr.'s Hoist the Flag, last year's juvenile champion and a 3-to-1 future-book favorite for the Kentucky Derby, made his sophomore debut in an overnight race at Bowie today and won by 15 lengths.

Any military interference with constitutional government is an occasion for regret, but at least the "coup by communique" in Turkey is a coup with a difference. The armed forces did not take over the Government; they merely demanded formation of a stronger, non-partisan civilian regime capable "within the framework of democratic principles" of reuniting the country, ending unrest and getting on with promised reforms.
Luis Stepenberg, described by Federal autorities as one of the world's biggest heroin smugglers, died Thursday, apparently of a heart attack; government officials said yesterday.

New Jersey's largest utility company is considering the construction of a two-million-kilowatt nuclear generator at Bayonne, in the heart of the New York-New Jersey metropolitan area, to meet an expected doubling of the power demand by the end of the decade.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- The Census Bureau says that the median value of owner-occupied homes increased by 43 per cent over the last decade while median monthly rents rose 55 per cent.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- President Nixon says his wife, Pat, who celebrates her 59th birthday Tuesday, is a woman "of great strength of character" and superb sensitivity whose "passion for privacy" prevents her from enjoying all aspects of her role as First Lady.

The appointment of J. Henry Smith, president and chief executive of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, as general chairman for the United Fund of Greater New York's 1971 annual citywide appeal beginning May 4 was announced yesterday by J. K. Jamieson, chairman of the fund's board.

ATLANTA, March 13 -- Two of the world's greatest bridge players, Giorgio Belladonna and Benito Garozzo of Rome, captured a major title at their first attempt in the spring national championships of the American Contract Bridge League here this afternoon.

George Riemer, who spent seven years in the Jesuits, has looked up 11 of his old colleagues and subjected them to the ordeal by tape recorder. The result is an edited notebook that reveals in some depth a variety of occupations.
The price of season permits for most of the city's tennis courts has been raised from $10 to $15, the Parks Department announced last week.

Carefree, casual and adventurous -- that's what ski weekends should be. These qualities were built into this compact, multi-level house on Stratton Mountain in Vermont designed for a family of ski buffs. One door opens onto a ski trail so they can schuss right up to the house at the end of the day.

A State Senate committee investigating the Board of Education's $36.2-million deficit asserted yesterday that the city school system's accounting procedures were antiquated, chaotic, based on "guesstimates" and drastically in need of revision.

DUBAI, March 13 -- British officials in the Persian Gulf area are winding up the special treaty relationships Britain has with the seven Trucial States, Qatar and Bahrain. The British Foreign Secretary said recently that these treaty relationships would terminate at the end of the year.

Old weather lore says only that March will be windy, choosing not to prophesy even from week to week. But of one thing we may be sure -- March not only brings change but is change. You see it, you hear it, you feel it.

The Carnegie Commission on Higher Education recommended yesterday that American colleges and universities adopt bills of rights and responsibilities that would apply equally to faculty, students, administrators, staff and trustees.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Hollywood's gone and New York is an urban crisis. But Palm Beach that gilded never-never land of the very rich, can still be depended upon to supply more than its share of the nation's glamour.

KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., March 13 (Reuters) -- More than 300 migrant workers peacefully demonstrated today near President Nixon's winter retreat here to back demands for relief aid after a major crop disaster in Southern Florida.

Although I found Roy Bongartz's run-in with the French amusing, "There'll Be Camping Ce Soir," (Travel section, Feb. 21), I did not consider it the least bit funny. Here we have an American who plunks himself down on posted property, who does not possess a camping carnet (he does not even seem to know that such exists); and who then tries to do some natives out of a reserved campsite.
LISBON, March 13 -- Portugal has awarded a concession for the opening of three gambling casinos in the new resort area in her southernmost province, Algarve.

BOSTON, March 13 -- Nearly every night this winter some 780 buses owned by the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority have been sitting empty outside car barns, their engines idling and consuming more than $200,000 worth of fuel.

DRIGHLINGTON, England, March 13 -- The sound of the Drighlington parish church bells ringing out in practice every Monday evening has brought discord to this Yorkshire village. People complain that the noise wakes up babies, drowns the television and interferes with children's homework.

To the Editor: President Sadat's supposed readiness to make peace with Israel appears to be more tactical than substantive. While the pronouncement of the heretofore banned word -- "peace" -- by an Arab leader is welcome, the revised vocabulary has not been coupled by a willingness to negotiate any of the complex issues of the Arab-Israeli conflict.

The mushrooming promotion, prescription and use of mood-and mind-affecting drugs -- stimulants, sedatives, tranquilizers and the like -- are drawing critical scrutiny from the Federal Government and the medical profession.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., March 13 -- More than one-third of the residents of this village and its environs have petitioned the area's leading theater chain to show more "family" motion pictures and fewer films rated 'X" and "R."

WASHINGTON, March 13 (UPI) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd Jr., of Virginia has introduced a resolution for the posthumous restoration of United States citizenship to Robert E. Lee, the Confederate General, who pledged his allegiance to the Union four months after the Civil War ended.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 13 (UPI) -- Mike Hole of Britain rode New Zealand-bred Broker's Tip II to a Canadian victory today, defeating 13 rivals in the $52,175 Canadian Turf Handicap at Gulfstream Park.

PLATTSBURGH, N.Y., March 13 -- Rockwell Kent, whose rugged landscape paintings and memorable book illustrations won him an international reputation, died in the Champlain Valley Physicians Hospital Medical Center today after having suffered a stroke earlier this month.

ON the night of June 12 last year, toward the end of the British election campaign, a group of reporters met Edward Heath as he came off the stage at a noisy Conservative party meeting in Manchester. One of them gave him the news: the latest public opinion poll, just released by The Daily Mail, showed the Conservatives a staggering 12.4 per cent behind Labor.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 13 -- Maeve, a timid 9-year-old child, hears a loud noise on the street and faints. Emily, 10, suffers recurrent nightmares that her parents are shot. Ten-year-old Marie recalls the rioting and has an epileptic fit.

Dr. Jordan Woodcock, a veterinarian from Katonah, N. Y., whose family equine interests go back to the gaslight era in England, has been appointed administrator of the American Horse Shows Association's new drug-prevention program.

HAZARD, Ky., March 13 -- Charles Finley, the operator and part owner of the mine where 38 miners died Dee. 30, denied today any knowledge of nonpermissible explosives or other dangerous practices in his mine.
Professor James Hitchcock's thoughtful article, "A Short Course in the Three Types of Radical Professors" (Feb. 21), is misleading in at least two respects.

THERE are two catalogues for the Hayward Gallery's ambitious exhibition, "Art in Revolution." One is strikingly designed in red, black and white, profusely illustrated, and contains a number of informative, enthusiastic essays.

By the year 1980, 150,000,000 kilowatts of electricity will be generated by nuclear reactors in the United States. This astonishing triumph of nuclear energy comes just as we have become sensitive to the environmental side effects of technology. As a consequence, nuclear power is caught in noisy controversy: the proponents of nuclear energy claim it is clean, safe, and necessary; its opponents claim it is unclean, unsafe and unnecessary.

EVERY suburban community seems to have its own self-appointed "horticultural expert." Advice is dispensed unsolicited, and may or may not be authoritative.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., March 13 (UPI) -- Former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy, Democrat of Minnesota, believes a third-party candidate could perform a service to the American people and play an important role in the 1972 Presidential election.

AMHERST, Mass., March 13 -- Penn State dominated the Eastern Intercollegiate Gymnastics League championships by winning 13 places in the individual events today at Curry Hicks Field House at the University of Massachusetts.

ALBANY, March 13 -- The legislator listed as H. Posner made his weekly return home from the State Assembly two days ago with no certainty that any of his pet pills would ever shine in the leaders' eyes.

Is Joseph Verner Reed for real? Shakespeare wrote for his time; Peter Brook directs for ours, so that we have the best of both worlds. I have seen many different productions of "A Midsummer Night's Dream," and Brook's is by far the clearest and most entertaining.

Down to earth -- that's what children's clothes are this season. And they are all American in spirit with a strong Western and American Indian influence. There are overalls right off the farm, breezy cowboy shirts, shorts and knickers, and tough, knockabout denims for active kids on the go like Laura, left, who cartwheels into a happy summer in her denim overalls and striped cotton T-shirt.

ALBANY, March 13 -- For the first time in 20 years, the state may have to use money in the tax stabilization reserve fund, its "rainy day" account, to avoid a deficit during the fiscal year ending March 31.

A 12-story building on West 44th Street that once housed the Yale Club has been deemed surplus property by the United States Government and donated to Touro College, a new nonsectarian liberal arts college that will stress the Jewish heritage, western humanities and the sciences in its curriculum.

SAN JUAN, Texas, March 9 -- Last Sunday was an almost perfect spring day along the Rio Grande, the meandering river that marks the border between Texas and the Republic of Mexico. The north wind still had a tinge of winter in it but in the sunshine it was almost hot.

HONG KONG -- As the United States-supported South Vietnamese drive into Laos pushed ahead last week, the question again was raised here and in various world capitals: Will Communist China intervene in Indochina?

A major technological advance in Hollywood's methods of producing films and tapes for television and motion pictures is only weeks away with the commercial introduction of an electronic computerized system for editing visual material.
The Canada Dry Corporation announced yesterday that it was beginning its Operation Ecology, which will call for the use of recycled materials in all its packaging and in business stationery.

UNDER the aegis of the United Nations, 1971 is being observed, more or less universally, as the "Year of International Support for Refugees." The United Nations issued three stamps for the occasion on March 12. Other nations are planning similar issues to stimulate donations to refugee-aid organizations.

The barometer for University of Michigan basketball success is Cazzie Lee Russell Jr., now of the New York Knickerbockers. This season, Henry Wilmore, a youngster from Harlem, has revived the good old days at Michigan when the public address announcer used to say, "Cazzie R-r-r-russell," and the crowds went wild.

ALBANY, March 13 -- As legislators try to outdo one another in chopping away at Governor Rockefeller's proposed $8.45 - billion budget, some are questioning the necessity of the plethora of patronage-rich special committees and temporary commissions created by the Legislature with appropriations of about $2-million a year.

Constant readers of the stock tables will notice a change this week when the newspaper listings of price ranges for the year switch from the highs and lows for 1970-71 to those for 1971 alone.
