PARIS -- The settling of international interest rates has produced a remarkable surge in new-issue activity in the Eurobond market as corporations, international agencies, municipalities, and Governments -- including the Communist Government of Hungary -- consider borrowing in Western Europe to meet growing capital needs.

WHEN "My Little Chickadee" opened here in 1940, Frank S. Nugent, then the motion picture critic of The New York Times and a man who, on most occasions, displayed both wit and a sense of critical proportion, was reminded of a Noel Coward line about two empty paper bags belaboring each other, apparently in reference to the stars of the film, W. C. Fields and Mae West. Nugent then switched metaphors.

The extremely disturbing and very well written article, "Is the Mediterranean Dying?" (Feb. 21), by John Cornwell, calls for comment. It will be interesting to find out whether under International Law -through a case presented to the World Court at The Hague -- a country like Italy or, for that matter, the United States could be indicted for seriously damaging the ecology of the large lakes, the seas and the oceans.

Yesterday afternoon at the Forum Theater in Lincoln Center, the Little Theater of the Deaf presented "Journeys," a show that is instructive for the hearing and entertaining for the deaf and also has a theatrical life of its own.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The National Association of Securities Dealers, in a partial reversal of an earlier stand, has agreed to determine whether its new, automated stock price quotations system, NASDAQ, should be used by brokers who make off-floor markets in stocks that are listed on exchanges.

ALBANY, March 14 -- After-hours bottle clubs where scores of thousands of bibulous night people slake extra-long thirsts would be subject to tighter licensing and revenue regulations under changes being sought by the Attorney General's office.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 14 -- Jerry Koosman became the first New York Met pitcher to work five innings today -- and the first to throw home-run balls in consecutive innings -- as the Philadelphia Phillies defeated the Mets, 3-2.
To the Editor: I would like to propose a simple solution to the problem of finding additional monies needed to run our schools in an orderly, educationally sound manner.

To the Editor: In the light of Senator Jackson's TV interview as reported on March 7, there is obviously some speculation that Senator Jackson is measuring public attitude to a possible candidacy of his for Presidential nomination by the Democratic party in 1972.

BONN, March 14 -- Shortly before midnight last Dec. 15, a 51-year-old native of Poland named Andrzej Przewoski sat languorously in a ground-floor monitoring studio of the Radio Free Europe building in Munich listening simultaneously to two regional broadcasts from Poland.

To the Editor: Bernard J. Lasker's solicitude for America's stockholders (of which I am one) and his desire to shield us naive folk from the sinister hazards of horse race betting warm my heart. [Editorial March 8.] I think, however, that Mr. Lasker might, on closer inspection, find unwelcome resemblances between Wall Street and the race track.
WILMINGTON, N. Y., March 14 -- The United States finally bombed its way to direct hits today in the three-day World Student Alpine Racing Trials.
MILL RUN, Pa. -- Even obscured by the swirling snow, Frank Lloyd Wright's multi-decked house called Fallingwater seemed majestic.

While New York Hota, leader in the North Group of the German-American Soccer League, scored a close victory over Gottschee yesterday, the German-Hungarians bowed to the Greek-Americans and allowed Elizabeth to take over first place in the South Group.

To the Editor: In a Feb. 20 letter, the director of the Family Planning Program of the Office of Economic Opportunity took issue with an earlier Times editorial entitled "Slowdown on Family Planning," which deplored the fact that in its fiscal 1972 budget the Administration was only seeking partial implementation of the Family Planning Services and Population Research Act of 1970.

BERLIN, March 14 -- The Social Democrats suffered losses, but retained a majority in West Berlin's parliament, in elections today that were widely considered a test of Chancellor Willy Brandt's policy of seeking to improve relations with the Soviet bloc.

New York City's relief rolls have risen 12.2 per cent in a year and Long Island's welfare rolls, swelled by defense cutbacks and other economic troubles, have far outpaced the city's increase in proportion -- surging 30.7 per cent.

" The Barber of Seville," absent from the New York City Opera's repertory since 1968, returned yesterday afternoon with a new conductor (Giuseppe Morelli), a new Almaviva (Jerry Jennings) and a new Basilio (Ara Berberian).

President Nixon has angrily rejected the Japanese plan for restricting textile exports to this country -- a plan submitted in response to an initiative by Chairman Wilbur D. Mills of the House Ways and Means Committee. Mr. Mills, a man not easily pleased, had welcomed the Japanese plan as one that might eliminate any strong Congressional push this year for compulsory import quota legislation.
The Ed Sullivan Show will end its record 23-year run this season, industry sources said last night.

ALBANY, March 14 -- The cost of providing welfare and Medicaid assistance for 1.8 million people throughout the state in 1970 was a record $3.27-billion, an increase of $347.8-million over 1969, state welfare officials announced today.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (Reuters) -- The State Department is expected to announce early this week the elimination of restrictions on travel by Americans to Communist China, informed sources said today.

To the Editor: If Mayor Lindsay switches from the party of Abraham Lincoln to the Democratic party, it would smack too much of opportunism in his quest for the Presidency. Anyone who would appear so obvious and anxious to become the President would already have two strikes against him in the eyes of the public.
Catholic Charities of New York will open six new centers this year for the treatment of high school drug addicts, the director of the organization said yesterday.

When an Army major was transferred from the New York area to Japan last summer, he left one daughter here in college. Within a month she had dropped out and gone with her boyfriend to the East Village, where they took up residence in his car. Soon both were far into the dope scene.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Ch. Eastward Liontamer of Elster, the country's top chow chow for the last three years, was named best in show at the National Capital Kennel Club's 58th event today.
ALBANY, March 14 -- Governor Rockefeller asked the Legislature today to authorize financial assistance to local governments to help them buy equipment for the disposal of solid wastes.
DETROIT, March 14 -- A group of medical students here has proposed that students who need money indenture themselves to towns that need doctors in exchange for college expenses.
ALBANY, March 14 -- Like the genie let out of the bottle, Governor Rockefeller's $8.4-billion state budget with its staggering $1.1-billion tax package hangs over the current legislative session.

HARRIMAN, N. Y. -- For five days last week, 57 college presidents, and the representatives of 10 more, dwelt in baronial style in an elegant country mansion here while they grappled with what is to many of them the paramount issue of the day: How their institutions can survive the financial crunch that is upon them.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. -- Many people who are willing to concede that the railroad must be brought back to life are chiefly thinking of bringing this about on the very terms that have robbed us of a balanced transportation network -- that is, by treating speed as the only important factor, forgetting reliability, comfort and safety, and seeking some mechanical dodge for increasing the speed and automation of surface vehicles.

MERCEDES, Tex., March 10 -- This was the year that Mrs. Marta P. Cotera had hoped to spend in Europe with her husband. Instead, she found herself installed on the second floor of a falling-down mansion in the Rio Grande Valley of Texas, trying to put together a makeshift library for a controversial new education center for Mexican-Americans.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 14 (AP) -- Six hundred British soldiers, helped by helicopters, carried out today what was described as the biggest security operation in the last two years of strife in Northern Ireland.

AARE, Sweden, March 14 (UPI) -- Jean-Noel Augert, world slalom champion, gave the French consolation for their defeat in the Alpine skiing by beating the World Cup victor in today's slalom, the last event of the 1970-71 series.

Derek Walcott's "The Dream on Monkey Mountain," which the Negro Ensemble Company presented last night at the St. Marks Playhouse, is a beautiful bewildering play by a poet. Mr. Walcott, a black Trinidadian, rightly sees the English language as one of his ethnic inheritances, and he fell in love with it in a way that few people can.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., March 14 -- The State Legislature has decisively defeated for this year a strong attempt to halt the spread of strip mining throughout West Virginia, but the fight appears to be far from over.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 14 -- When Sue Cochran, a 19-year-old sophomore at Radcliffe College, graduates, her degree won't be from the all-girl school but from its all-male affiliate, Harvard.

ESSEX, Conn., March 14 -- Forty-nine pleasure boats, including a new yacht valued at $250,000, were destroyed by fire here this morning after an explosion in the main storage and repair building of a shipyard.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., March 14 (AP) -- A national conference on the judiciary agreed today that all state court judges should be appointed to long terms by a nonpartisan commission rather than elected. The judges would be subject to removal if they did not do the job.

Frederic Waldman and his Musica Aeterna Orchestra usually specialize in rarely encountered music, but they made an exception at Carnegie Hall Friday night, with a program listing such staples of the repertory as Rossini's "Silken Ladder" Overture, Schubert's Fifth Symphony and the Mendelssohn Violin Concerto.

The Supreme Court's 8-to-1 ruling upholding the right of Congress to limit draft exemptions for conscientious objectors to those who oppose all wars -- denying exemptions to objectors to particular wars -- resolves an agonizing constitutional dilemma by assigning broad priority to the security prerogatives of the state over the rights of individual conscience. There are weighty practical grounds for the Court's decision in the case of two conscientious objectors to the war in Indochina.

Bernard Zuckerman, an American master from Brooklyn, led a field of 23 players in the Continental Experts seven-round Swiss system by winning with the score of 6 1/2-1/2 at the Hotel McAlpin. Second spot was taken by Lubomir

The mission of Pioneer F -- the spacecraft that will be launched next year to visit giant Jupiter and send back photographs and scientific data -- opens some of the most exciting vistas yet in the entire space program. If accomplished -- and there are many extraordinary hazards to be overcome -- this mission would mark a major advance in man's understanding of a hitherto unpenetrated section of the solar system.

BUFFALO, March 14 -- Senator James L. Buckley's ready smile vanished for an instant the other day when a newsman in Washington asked why he had been keeping such "a low profile" since taking office seven weeks ago.

FORT BENNING, Ga., March 14 -- The jury in the court-martial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. must convict or acquit him of premeditated murder, murder or voluntary manslaughter in the alleged mass killing of Vietnamese civilians at Mylai, the military judge said today.

The Republic Corporation, a diversified industrial company based in Los Angeles, reported yesterday a net loss of $22,216,000 in its first fiscal quarter, ended Jan. 31, in contrast to an operating profit of $1,778,000, or 20 cents a share, in the year-earlier period.

WORCESTER, Mass., March 14 (AP) -- Fire swept through a five-story apartment-business complex near the downtown section tonight, killing four persons and injuring 19 others, the police reported. The police said most of the injured had been treated for smoke inhalation.
Local presidents of the United Steelworkers of America accepted new three-year contracts last night with three major can manufacturers, thus ending a 28-day strike against the companies.
HAZARD, Ky., March 14 -- "They've ruined me. I'm going to retire under a cloud. But I don't mind for myself. I just don't like what they did to that boy."

ATLANTA, March 14 (UPI) -- Two national health agencies warned yesterday that special care must be exerted in the use of an intravenous drug product, apparently contaminated by a faulty bottle cap, that has been connected with nine deaths in hospitals across the nation.

MOSCOW, March 14 -- The Chief Designer of Spaceships was quoted today as saying that the Soviet Union was preparing another manned orbital flight of long duration as a prelude to the creation of a permanent space laboratory.
SMITHTOWN, L. I., March 14 -- The body of an 18-year-old girl, who had been reported missing by her parents on the night of March 3, was found in a wooded area here by two boys yesterday afternoon.

The carefully orchestrated performance of The Conversion of John Lindsay (Aurelio, Opus 2) combined with the silence of New York Democrats who reject the suggestion that Lindsay become the Democratic candidate for President in 1972, has left the impression that all that is needed is for Mayor Lindsay to say "I do" and the New York Democratic party will make him its candidate.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (UPI) -- Adm. Thomas H. Moorer, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said today that the South Vietnamese strike in Laos was "just about at the peak" and had "severely disrupted" North Vietnam's military operations.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 14 -- The old Denny McLain and the new Denny McLain were on display at Fort Lauderdale Stadium today as the Washington Senators whipped the Yankees, 7-4, extending New York's losing streak to six games.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy has estimated that at least 25,000 civilians were killed in the war in South Vietnam last year and that 100,000 were wounded.

The annual guessing game is on: Is there a team capable of stopping the University of California, Los Angeles, from winning a fifth straight national championship? Is Marquette the team to do it? Or will it be South Carolina? Is there a sleeper in the field?
DACCA, Pakistan, Monday, March 15 -- Sheik Mujibur Rahman announced early today that he was taking over administration of East Pakistan.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. has appealed directly to Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird for a fuller explanation of the Army's three-year surveillance of civilians that the Pentagon says ended last year.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (UPI) -- There were 301 Americans with incomes of more than $200,000 who paid no income tax for 1969, according to data released today by Representative Henry S. Reuss, Democrat of Wisconsin.
The credit markets became convinced last week that interest rates once again are headed downward.
ATLANTA, March 14 -- A New York foursome led the field of 70 teams into the final session of the Men's Team Championship here tonight at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals.

WESTON, Conn., March 14 -- David Distler, a 16-year-old high school student from Larchmont, N. Y., rode Alot to the regular working hunter division A championship and captured the Maclay Trophy today at the Nimrod Farm's horse show.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 14 -- Arnold Palmer won his second tournament within a month today and became golf's leading money winner of the year with a thrilling one-stroke victory over Julius Boros in the Florida Citrus invitation.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 14 -- Suleyman Demirel, forced out of office as Premier by an armed forces ultimatum two days ago, called on his parliamentary supporters today to back him and his ruling Justice party in the present constitutional crisis.

TOKYO, March 14 -- After their initial shock over the stern tone of President Nixon's statement rejecting the Japanese plan for unilateral restrictions on textile exports to the United States, leaders of industry and government in this country have settled down to await the outcome of the President's contest with Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee.

BRUSSELS, March 14 -- The Common Market Commission is to tell the Continental Can Company, Inc., of the United States that its ownership of two companies making cans in Germany and the Netherlands gives it an "abusively dominant" position on the market in northern Europe.
A defunct movie palace in the Bronx -- the old Fairmont Theater at 708 East Tremont Avenue -- will in the near future house a little museum, an innovation in the area.
FAYETTEVILLE, N. C., March 14 -- With a gusto once reserved for cadence counts, the battalion of young soldiers raise their voices in a lusty refrain:
PARIS, March 14 -- One of the molecular biologists who "cracked the code of life" argues that science can now answer the question: Was God throwing dice when he made the universe?

SAIGON, March 14 (AP) -- An American fighter-bomber mistakenly attacked South Vietnamese ground troops in Laos today, in the fifth accidental bombing of the campaign against the Ho Chi Minh Trail, a United States military spokesman said. Ten paratroopers were killed and 12 wounded.

WASHINGTON, March 14--A Soviet academic periodical has portrayed Associate Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court as an "apostle of liberalism" who has lost his faith in democracy in a censored and distorted version of his latest book.
PITTSBURGH, March 14 -- "Hedge" buying of steel continued last week but it was not clear what aspect of the future was worrying users the most.

Ten Wheel Drive performed "Little Big Horn," a rock oratorio written by Aram Schefrin and Michael Zager of the group, at Carnegie Hall yesterday. Assisting were the American Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Stephen Simon, and a small chorus.

Laurence Wilson, the pianist who played at Tully Hall yesterday afternoon, has a very pleasing command of his instrument. His tone is velvety, his rhythm forthright and even, and he has an excellent ear for sonority, big and small.

LONDON March 14 -- The state-owned British Steel Corporation is running into serious financial problems, and some of its long-range expansion programs are being questioned by the Conservative Government.

Since Benjamin Britten's "Les Illuminations" is a song cycle that seems to grow more beautiful with each passing year, and because Phyllis Curtin is a particularly fine interpreter of the work, it is reasonable, if a bit surprising, that Andre Kostelanetz should have featured it and her for the second time in three years in one of his Saturday-night concerts with the New York Philharmonic.

ATLANTA, March 14 -- The Atlanta Hawks, who will probably be the Knicks' opponents in the first round of the National Basketball Association playoffs later this month, did New York a good turn today by defeating the Philadelphia 76ers, 108-101.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- Senator Robert J. Dole of Kansas, the Republican National Chairman, accused the Democratic party today of "adopting the fashionable code of the New Left, radical exhibitionism."

Recently, the heads of 10 regional discount-store chains around the country met in New York. Purpose: to discuss the advisability of founding a new, national chain of discounters with annual sales in excess of $600-million. Reason: to obtain through a merger better protection in each company's area against new competition and to obtain better financial leverage.

SYDNEY, Australia, March 14 (AP) -- Ken Rosewall of Australia took advantage of Arthur Ashe's 13 double faults and beat the American, 6-1, 7-5, 6-3, today for the $10,080 first prize in the Dunlop Australian open tennis tournament.

DACCA, Pakistan, March 14 -- Most busy officials display a certain amount of tension and preoccupation, but not Sheik Mujibur Rahman, the Bengali nationalist who has emerged in recent months as the undisputed leader of the people of East Pakistan.
WHITE PLAINS, March 14 -- Five days a week Therese Lazzaro of Wassaic, N. Y., teaches physical education at New Milford High School. On weekends she gets her exercise at dog shows.
With St. Patrick's Day fast approaching, the city's parade season is about to open. Another round of disruptions of urban life and traffic -- increasingly numerous each year -- will soon begin.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- New York City is not alone; the school system of nearly every large city in the country is in desperate financial straits, and budget deficits, teacher layoffs and reduced services in the schools are the rule rather than the exception.

LISBON, March 14 -- General Kaulza de Arriaga, the military commander of Portugal's East African territory, says that his forces have sealed off the main guerrilla infiltration points along the Tanzanian border and captured the insurgents' principal bases in northern Mozambique.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Nixon Administration will endorse "no fault" automobile insurance this week, urging states to adopt the system that covers injuries and losses directly regardless of the cause of an accident.
If there were no need for concern about the preservation of a beautiful voice, unreserved rejoicing would be in order for Shirley Verrett's triumph at the Metropolitan Opera Saturday afternoon.

In explaining why he was proposing an $880.7-million tax increase, Mayor Lindsay cited three basic reasons for increases in costs over which he would seem to have little control. But some Councilmen and budget experts have raised questions about this concept.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Following are the votes of delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the week ended yesterday:

Five dances by as many young choreographers had one thing in common in the Choreoconcerts series Saturday afternoon at the New School -- rejection of live and taped music in favor of silence or the voice, in words or without.

England had first crack at it, then Canada. Now the same correspondence course will bestow its Grand Diplome in this country to students who learn to cook in their own kitchens "in the manner of the great French chefs."

To the Editor: In a recent letter, David A. Kirkwood compared the political coattails of Senator Edmund Muskie with those of Senator Edward Kennedy to Mr. Muskie's advantage, pointing out that Senator Muskie had been able to pull a Democratic Governor through to victory in Maine while Senator Kennedy had failed miserably to elect a Democratic Governor in Massachusetts.

The city and state governments, which are now tightening their belts to meet a fiscal crisis, face at least one expenditure whose relentless growth cannot be curbed, not now and not for at least 20 years.

SOFIA, March 14 (UPI) -- The second European indoor track and field championships ended today with a total of three world records bettered. About 300 athletes from 23 nations competed in the two-day meet.
IBADAN, Nigeria -- Dr. James C. Moomaw sloshed across a tiny rice paddy in his high rubber boots, picked a couple of grains from a yellowing stalk, and scratched them with his fingernail.
A backlog of over 700 criminal cases has been reduced in Federal Court here by prosecutors and judges who expect to dispose of the remaining cases within six months.

TEL AVIV, March 14 -- Three empty oil tankers were blown ashore during the night in a 50-knot gale at the Mediterranean terminal, at Ashkelon, of the Elath to Ashkelon pipeline. All crews were reported unhurt.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 14 -- After two months as State Superintendent of Public Instruction, Wilson C. Riles has evolved a fancy tightrope walk that he hopes will keep him out of conflicts that would prevent the reforms he hopes to achieve in state support of local schools.
In a probable preview of the first round of the Stanley Cup playoffs, the Rangers and Toronto Maple Leafs mauled each other last night in a game that had startling plays and outstanding goaltending.
PARIS, Monday, March 15--Opposition parties appeared early this morning to have withstood a challenge from supporters of the Pompidou Government in elections yesterday in 37,713 municipalities.

ROME, March 14 -- Pope Paul VI today reiterated the Vatican's long-standing demand for a role in any international decision on the status of Jerusalem and Christianity's other shrines in the Holy Land.
Robert Hamilton cultivates a suave, lyrical piano tone and a spontaneous musical approach, qualities that helped make his Town Hall recital late Saturday afternoon a generally pleasant occasion.

WASHINGTON -- Because of the ground invasions into populous areas of Cambodia and Laos and the poundings from the air that have reached a tempo of a thousand sorties a day, a new vale of tears is flowing across Southeast Asia.

The president of the Board of Education, Murry Bergtraum, declared yesterday that the board would accept greater municipal controls over its budgeting procedures if those controls did not extend to educational policies.

JERUSALEM, March 14 -- Premier Golda Meir moved today to try to head off an internal challenge to her Government over the issue of whether the leadership had become too conciliatory in the international efforts for an Arab-Israeli settlement.

Led by Alfred Vialet's 23 points, DeWitt Clinton High of the Bronx beat highly favored Boys of Brooklyn in the third overtime period, 63-61, for the Public Schools Athletic League basketball championship yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Your emerging interest in the 1972 Democratic nomination -- the proto-candidacy, as they call it -- should be welcomed by all those critical of the proposal for an American supersonic transport. No irony is intended.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- State governments must overhaul their "unequal and mismatched" methods of aiding overburdened inner-city schools, a group of business executives urged today.
NEW DELHI, March 14 -- West Bengal voters have failed to give a majority mandate to any one party for forming a state government there.
Automobile insurance rates, advancing steadily almost everywhere, will rise still further before very long.

DUBLIN -- The International Theater Festival now running in Dublin has more significance than any of its 12 predecessors, for it introduces a new policy in national image-building on the part of those who regulate such things.
Facing up to one of the major questions of the day in the agency business, the American Association of Advertising Agencies has issued a position paper on the full-service ad agency.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- William D. Ruckelshaus, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, has asked the Interior Department to hold up a right-of-way permit for a trans-Alaska oil pipeline pending a thorough study of the environmental advantages of a route through Canada.

BRUSSELS, March 14 -- At the new Forest National arena here, Rudolf Nureyev is dancing in a long duet especially created by Maurice Bejart for him and Paolo Bortoluzzi, leading man of Bejart's 20th-Century Ballet.
The City Housing and Development Administration has proposed construction of 2,600 apartments for low-income and middle-income families in Yorkville.
The Bronx police yesterday arrested a 21-year-old student whom they described as a "major distributor of drugs on the New York University campus."
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Federal Trade Commission has notified Congress that it may revive a regulation requiring a stiff health warning in cigarette advertisements.

Six months ago, Davey Feld was carried out of Madison Square Garden by a squad of special policemen before a crowd of more than 10,000 waiting to watch the main event between Floyd Patterson and Charlie Green. Feld had been appointed by the New York State Athletic Commission to referee the bout, but at the last minute Patterson supposedly refused to come out unless Feld was replaced.

The presidents of the news divisions of the three major television networks were divided yesterday in their opinions of the proposal made last week by Fred W. Friendly for creation of an electronic news service.

Yes, more books on our education crisis. I know: the business of producing such books is threatening to become the very assembly line that students as well as the authors of such books are rebelling against. But if these four are representative, the cumulative effect of such monotony will be to make increasingly plausible an assumption that our present school system refuses to acknowledge -- that children are to be trusted.

PASADENA, Calif., March 14 (AP)--A young astronomer at the California Institute of Technology has discovered long-sought evidence that mysterious quasars--intensely bright, star-like objects-- are as distant as they seem.

WASHINGTON, March 14--The Fairchild-Hiller Corporation and Washington-Tele-Communications, Inc., announced today that they planned to ask permission tomorrow from the Federal Communications Commission to construct and operate domestic communications satellite systems.

When President Franklin D. Roosevelt and Senator George W. Norris conceived the Tennessee Valley Authority in 1933, they had a much more spacious concept than merely the generation of cheap electricity. They envisaged a vast undertaking which would conserve the land and water, redeem the scars of exploitation, and nourish rural and small-town life in one of America's great river valleys. Their dream has largely been realized.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 14 -- South Vietnamese forces in Laos fought two stiff battles over the weekend, an army spokesman said today.

An intrepid team of collectors of folk songs and traditional ballads, Sandy and Caroline Paton, dug deep into their song-bag Saturday night to create a wide ranging program at the 92d Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association.

In a move that could affect the Rangers a month from now, the Chicago Black Hawks yesterday called up an amateur goalie named Gilles Maloche to replace Gerry Desjardins, whose left elbow was broken in two places against the St. Louis Blues on Sunday.

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 15 -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation is studying the possible link between Thursday's campus rioting here and a bomb placed in the local Selective Service office two weeks ago.

The London Stock Exchange closed narrowly mixed in quiet trading yesterday. Dealers were described as cautions over Britain's general economic situation, and over the Government's latest set of unemployment figures which are due to be published Thursday.

LONDON, March 15 (AP) -- The International Coffee Organization ordered today a second cut of 1.5 million bags in 1970-71 coffee-export quotas. The first cut, of 1.5 million bags, took place 15 days ago when the composite daily price fell below 48 cents a pound and triggered first-stage quota cuts.

On March 7, in New York City, President Shazar of Israel was reported to have spoken of Jerusalem as a Jewish city and the capital of Israel. By doing so he seems to ignore 2,000 years of history and to deny all the political and spiritual rights of Christians and Moslems to that city.

MEXICO CITY, March 15 (Reuters) -- Mexico charged tonight that North Korea had trained a group of young Mexicans in terrorism and guerrilla warfare and sent them home to fight for the establishment of a "Marxist-Leninist regime."

The city is seeking rate increases designed to bring it 41.3 per cent more revenue for the water it provides for 38 communities outside the city, mainly in Westchester County. The increases would total about $1,227,000 a year, from $2,969,000 under current rates to $4,196,000.
Earl Foreman of the Virginia Squires defied the four-year college no-tampering rule yesterday by selecting three undergraduates during the American Basketball Association draft.

On the average, Americans eat about 65 pounds of pork a year, so the fact that pork prices have remained at reasonable levels is pleasant news for the housewife. To add an international touch to pork on the menu, here are recipes that have their origins in Germany, Spain and China.

"King Heroin" is returning home to Harlem with something new added, a showcase of its own, the St. Philip's Community Theater, 207 West 133d Street. Starting tomorrow night, a two-week engagement will enable New Yorkers to see a play which has drawn acclaim as a study of drug addiction.

ATLANTA, March 15 -- Two New York teams playing the Precision System scored victories last night in the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals, in spite of an official change of heart that barred the use of two features of the system.
TOULOUSE, France, March 15 -- This city was paralyzed for nine hours today as a gang caught in a bank holdup traded off some of their hostages for $76,600 and a path of escape.

LISBON, March 15 -- Policemen with rifles and dogs charged a peaceful demonstration of nearly 3,000 saleswomen tonight in front of the Portuguese National Assembly and dispersed the crowd in two minutes.

ATHENS, March 15 -- The Athens special military tribunal today found four men guilty of having attempted to overthrow the Greek Government by setting up a guerrilla group called The National Antidictatorial Army. Three of them were jailed.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Treasury bill rates were mixed at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.
The State Senate has demonstrated its remoteness from reality by passing a bill permitting local school boards to institute junior Reserve Officers Training Corps in the high schools.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 15 -- It's Ralph Houk's credo that to "accomplish what we set out to accomplish in spring training, we have to sacrifice certain things."

Bernice Gera filed a $25-million suit yesterday against organized baseball because, in the words of her attorney, Mario Biaggi, a Democratic Representative, it has "virtually destroyed her career as a baseball umpire." The suit was filed in Manhattan Supreme Court.

VIENTIANE, Laos, March 15 -- The tough and fierce Meo mountain tribesmen of Laos, retreating before the North Vietnamese invaders, are nearing the end of the mountains and the limits of their strength. Their survival in their traditional pattern of life has become a matter of concern to them and to their friends.
Bond prices rose and interest rates declined yesterday, largely because of all the optimistic credit market analysis that was published over the weekend.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- New York and California Democrats sued their party today to apportion 1972 national convention delegates according to a one-Democrat, one-vote formula. They said that this would liberalize the convention, affect the presidential race and discourage third-party movements.

The Bank of America, San Francisco; the Security Pacific National Bank, Los Angeles, and the United California Bank, Los Angeles -- respectively the nation's largest, ninth largest and 15th largest banks -- reduced yesterday their prime lending rates on business loans to 5 1/4 per cent, their minimum rates on home-mortgage loans to 6 3/4 per cent and the rate they pay on passbook savings to 4 per cent.

The Long Island Railroad said yesterday that it would introduce a "tamper-proof" weekly commuter ticket on April 17. The ticket is designed to stop some of the cheating that a state audit indicated recently might cost more than $9-million a year in lost fares.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Following are the listings of this week's events of interest. All admissions are free unless otherwise indicated, though Special credentials may be required in some instances. Best phone ahead to make certain.
CALCUTTA, India, March 8 -- Sheik Mujibur Rahman, the East Pakistani leader, who is a Moslem, has become a folk hero to the Hindus of West Bengal, in India.
Mayor Lindsay officially opened yesterday what he called the nation's first public school that will seek to rehabilitate former addicts while they continue their high school education.

LOS ANGELES, March 15 (AP) -- Eight states filed suit in United States District Court today, charging that major American Automobile manufacturers have conspired since 1953 to delay the development of atnipollution devices.

ALBANY, March 15 -- Governor Rockefeller announced today that he had decided to reduce his state budget proposal by at least $300-million so he could trim proposed tax increases and avoid "disastrous" economic effects.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- The House Appropriations Committee approved today, 26 to 15, funds for continued development of a supersonic civilian aircraft.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 15 -- Tom Seaver missed five days of spring training when he returned home to await the birth of his first child but in his second appearance on the mound today he proved he is right on target for his big assignment on opening day at Shea Stadium April 6.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- Earl F. Cole, a former general accused of aiding allegedly corrupt American business enterprises in Vietnam, is represented by a Washington law firm closely linked to lawyers representing other major figures in the case, Senator Charles H. Percy said today.
CLEVELAND, March 15 -- The first suit against a Federal housing law that has allegedly blocked suburban low-income public housing was filed today in United States District Court.
MONTREAL, March 15 (Canadian Press) -- Bell Canada reported 1970 net income of $133.3-million, or $3.52 a share, up from $113.7-million, or $3.20 a share in 1969.

In one of the most effective passages in E. M. Beekman's "Lame Duck," his unhappy hero, Hugo Lenz, makes a tentative date with a girl he had met at a party. Come ahead she says when he calls, although I can't guarantee I'll be in. Hugo treats it as a promise, though, and acts on it.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- President Nixon believes that the "fundamental cause" of unrest among American youth is not the war, poverty or prejudice, but "a sense of insecurity that comes from the old values being torn away."

Black, Chinese and Indian publishing companies, springing up across the country in response to what they consider the racism of the traditional publishing industry, are seeking control of their respective ethnic images as a major goal.
MADRID, March 15 -- Spain and the Soviet Union are on the verge of signing their first trade agreement since the Spanish Civil War.

NEWARK, March 15 -- Superior Court Judge Samuel Allcorn Jr. turned down a petition this morning for the release of the three officers of the Newark Teachers Union from jail as a possible step toward ending the six-week-long teachers strike here.

The National Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System Foundation will join the Ford Foundation in sponsoring the fourth national summer program at Columbia University designed to train members of minority groups for careers in broadcast journalism.

Assistant Secretary of Defense Robert Froehlke has acknowledged the presence of a military intelligence agent on New York University's Washington Square campus in a letter to a university administrator dated March 10, it was disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The Ides of March, 1971, mercifully failed to produce anything as dramatic as the stabbing of Julius Caesar in 44 B.C. or the abdication of Czar Nicholas in A.D. 1917. But they were not without portent, starting with President Nixon's declaration, during an extraordinary two - hour television interview, that he was not at all concerned about his image or modest standing in the opinion polls.

The heads of the nation's largest banks -- which enjoyed sharp increases in profits in the recession year of 1970 -- generally were rewarded with higher salaries last year. This was the principal conclusion to emerge from the annual survey by the New York Times of compensation of senior banking officials.
PROVINCETOWN, Mass., March 14 -- This little town at the tip of Cape Cod, which pokes out into the Atlantic Ocean like a beckoning finger, has always been a sort of haven.

North Carolina and Louisville, which just missed winning conference titles, and Duke and Purdue were selected yesterday to complete the field of 16 teams for the National Invitation Tournament, which begins Saturday morning at Madison Square Garden.

One juror was selected yesterday as the new trial for Mrs. Alice Crimmins, charged with murder and manslaughter in the death of her two small children in July, 1965, opened in Queens Supreme Court yesterday.
The number of narcotics addicts on New York City's relief rolls grew during the last year by nearly 900 a month, according to the Department of Social Services.

Dan River, Inc., a leading producer of textiles, announced yesterday in Greenville, S.C., that it was cutting its personnel by about 3 per cent in a major cost-cutting move resulting from unprofitable operations.

PARIS, March 15 -- France, until now dependent on the United States for her enriched uranium, announced today that she had concluded an arrangement with the Soviet Union at a lower price that had no political strings attached.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. -- The process that has been undermining our transportation system, with the progressive elimination of all but motor vehicles and jet planes, is what the biologist, William Morton Wheeler, described in organisms as "de-building."
Most issues on the American Stock Exchange advanced yesterday as the exchange's price index surged to its highest closing level in almost 14 months in active trading.

FORT BENNING, Ga., March 15 -- The Government prosecutor in the court-martial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. held a photograph of corpses of women, children and babies before members of the jury today and asked if they really expected Lieutenant Calley to admit that these were the "enemies" he killed at Mylai.
HOLLYWOOD -- Hollywood society, and there is such a thing, has a structure and ritual all its own.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 15 -- A study of this century's great advances in social science has found that the most important social research in the last four decades has tended to emerge from large teams of scholars working in major intellectual centers.
KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., March 15 -- President Nixon extended the concept of disaster relief today to include aid to migrant workers unemployed as a result of crop failures.
There were plenty of things to notice in Arnold Scaasi's spring couture collection if you took your eyes off the short pants.

BUFFALO, March 15 -- Senator James L. Buckley urged western New York business leaders today to return to "volunteerism" so that private groups could help solve the area's problems before a distant level of government tried to do it for them.
The Tartan Stable's Lonesome River gained the victory in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday, although he finished second in the six-furlong sprint for older horses.

A State Supreme Court jury in Brooklyn yesterday acquitted an insurance broker of charges of murder and assault, resulting from an incident in which he said he had been harassed by neighborhood youths.

CHICAGO, March 15 (AP) -- The Cosmopolitan National Bank disclosed today that more than $6-million in its funds were missing and had possibly been embezzled by a bank bookkeeper working with a long-time customer.
City Councilman at Large Michael J. Lazar, Democrat of Queens, yesterday was named chairman of the new Taxi and Limousine Commission by Mayor Lindsay.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 15 -- A plan to realign each of baseball s major leagues into three four-team divisions, something like the way pro football is divided, is under study, Joe Cronin said today.

Mohawk Airlines, Inc., said yesterday that the Chase Manhattan Bank had agreed to recommend to the airline's creditors -- of which it is one -- that they grant the company until March 29 to clear a $3.4-million default on interest and principal.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 15 -- Ismet Inonu, the elder statesman of Turkish politics, rebuffed the chiefs of his country's armed forces today by saying that their intervention in Government affairs Friday had so damaged the parliamentary system that it could be healed only by new elections.
A band studded with legendary jazz musicians, Franz Jackson and his Chicagoans, made a rare appearance in New York Sunday afternoon at Downbeat, Lexington Avenue at 42d Street.
Irwin Winston didn't miss the bus. He caught it and rode it to fortune and glory.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- Two medical advisory groups reported today that methadone maintenance -- daily doses of the syntheitc narcotic methadone to combat heroin addiction -- was not feasible in the office practice of private physicians.

Because of the recession, the Museum of Modern Art has canceled plans for a $35-million public fund-raising drive and has suspended indefinitely all new building projects. Instead, it will try to raise $21.5-million in endowment funds from trustee, corporate and other sources and do some remodeling of its premises.

On March 9, you reported that Mayor Lindsay had characterized my emergency proposal to guarantee teachers for our children as "financial juggling." That same day, I issued a statement responding to that characterization. Your paper printed only part of my statement.

Settlement terms in the month-long strike against three major can manufacturers make it evident that the wage-price spiral is moving unslowed into 1971. The new three-year pact, clearly a pattern-setter for forthcoming pay talks in aluminum, copper and steel, duplicates -- and in some respects expands -- the substantial gains auto workers won last year in their contracts with the automotive Big Three.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, March 16 -- South Vietnamese troops abandoned a fire base in Laos under heavy enemy pressure overnight, leaving behind their artillery pieces, military sources said today.

Angela Talbot, a Massachusetts soprano whose pioneering spirit and ingratiating personality outshine her modest vocal attainments, minimized her weaknesses and maximized her strengths at Carnegie Recital Hall Sunday night, thereby turning her New York debut into one of the freshest, most imaginative song programs of the season.

Thousands of mourners moved solemnly through the stately Riverside Church yesterday to view the body of Whitney M. Young Jr., executive director of the National Urban League, who died last week in Lagos, Nigeria.

John Fischer, editor in chief of Harper's Magazine for 12 years until four years ago, has been called out of retirement to act as the periodical's interim editor, William S. Blair, its publisher, anounced yesterday in a memorandum to advertisers.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Administration officials have offered Dr. Edmund D. Pellegrino, dean of the State University Medical School at Stony Brook, L. I., the position of the Government's top medical officer, sources at the Department of Health, Education and Welfare said today.

PORT JEFFERSON STATION, L.I., March 15 -- The immediate necessity for nuclear power was challenged today by Dr. James D. Watson, the Nobel Laureate, as the Atomic Energy Commission resumed its hearing here on an application for the construction of Long Island's first nuclear power plant.
The First Boston Corporation, for many years one of the nation's leading underwriters of securities, has applied for membership on the New York Stock Exchange.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Many states are defying, ignoring or otherwise not complying with President Nixon's call for states to suspend their support of construction industry wages.

Strikes at two major operations of the Data Corporation and the effects of the General Motors strike contributed to the sharply lower sales and earnings for the six months ended Feb. 28. J. E. Martin, chairman, in reporting the results yesterday noted that there was a marked gain in the second quarter over the first three months of its current fiscal year.

There was no cake in sight to be cut, but everyone present shared in the gift: chamber music performed with the kind of transcendent skill and dedication that has become the hallmark of Alexander Schneider's New School Concerts.
The City Center will sponsor a special season by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater at its West 55th Street theater from April 27 through May 9.
Rod Laver and Roy Emerson returned here yesterday following a three - week, 30,000-mile trip in search of tennis riches.

VIENNA, March 15 -- United States and Soviet delegations met in the palace of the Austrian President here today for the formal opening of the fourth round of their talks on the limitation of strategic nuclear arms.

DACCA, Pakistan, March 15 -- President Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan arrived here today to study the situation in East Pakistan and to hold talks that are likely to determine whether this eastern part of the Pakistani nation will break away from the west and become a separate country.

ROME, March 15 -- A new political grouping, echoing the "silent majority" theme that has been heard in the United States, has taken root in Italy. It says it expresses the long-muffled feelings of the majority of Italians who are tired of disorders and abhor violence.

Mayor Lindsay's selection of City Councilman Michael J. Lazar as chairman of the newly created taxi commission comes as a distinct disappointment. It brings to the helm of a vital agency, at the very moment of its birth, an innocuous but ineffective local politico.

Representative Mario Biaggi, Bronx Democrat-Conservative, called yesterday for an investigation into the alleged widespread sale and use of drugs at the Navy's correctional center in Brooklyn and the United States Naval Hospital in St. Albans, Queens.

MOSCOW, March 15 -- The Soviet Union today named Vasily I. Drozdenko, a ranking Ukrainian Communist party official, as the new Ambassador to Rumania in a move seen as part of an overhaul of Soviet diplomatic representation in several countries of Eastern Europe.

During one of the final and most hectic days of last year's session of the State Legislature -- when both houses were passing more than a bill a minute -- a single phrase was deleted from a complex pension law, raising the potential death benefits for legislative leaders and some state executives to levels of $250,000 to $500,000 and more.

Not since the Hatfields and the McCoys were feudin' and fussin' at the Big Sandy in Kentucky has there been a struggle involving the Blue Grass State like the one expected Thursday night when Kentucky and Western Kentucky level their sights on one another in the second round of the National Collegiate basketball tournament.
Jeffery Siegel, pianist, did double duty with the National Symphony at Philharmonic Hall on Sunday.

The National Endowment for the Arts is preparing to ask Congressional approval for a major matching-grant program in support of American opera companies. The ambitious program, part of an Administration plan for spending $60-million on the arts and humanities in the coming fiscal year, is comparable in scope and significance to the $3.5-million allocation of Endowment funds last year to 73 major and metropolitan symphony orchestras in 38 states.
A bill to require unit pricing of most items sold in grocery stores in the city was passed last night by the City Council, after the courts had blocked such a requirement under existing statutes.
CRACOW, Poland, March 10 -- The tall apartment house on the outskirts of this historic city looks like any other, but it is a girls' dormitory, and largely filled with foreigners.
Two chiefs of service at St. Vincent's Hospital said yesterday they would probably be forced to abandon important programs because of an unexpected halt in Federal financing.

LONDON, March 15 (UPI) -- Henry Cooper risks his European, British and Commonwealth heavyweight titles against Joe Bugner at Wembley tomorrow night in a battle between an old lion and a young warrior.

MOSCOW, March 15 -- The Soviet Union, thrust into the automobile age with the opening of the gigantic Fiat plant on the Volga River, finds that planners have overlooked one small detail: how to get the thousands of cars from the assembly line into the hands of the lucky buyers.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Industrial production declined in February following the auto-strike rebound of December and January, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Herbert Itkin, a key informer and prosecution witness in corruption cases, pleaded not guilty in Federal Court here yesterday to conspiracy, bribery and theft charges filed by a New York County grand jury in 1967 and 1968.

CHICAGO, March 15 -- "The most critical problem is getting white teachers who are coming not to work out their own problems, but to give to the program," an administrator from a predominantly black college remarked.
A series of class-action damage suits were filed yesterday against the Occidental Petroleum Corporation. Additional suits are expected to follow.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- A system analysis specialist, who is an environmentalist, has been rejected by the White House as head of an Environmental Institute, which President Nixon proposed to Congress last month.

Your recent editorial on "Mr. Nixon's Health Plan" was most disappointing in its failure to address itself to the needs of the largest single group of sick individuals in the nation -- those suffering from emotional and mental illness.

The State Racing Commission released its annual report to the Secretary of State yesterday. The loose-leaf volume of 58 pages is a comprehensive explanation of the operations of all phases of the 1970 thoroughbred activity in this state at the New York Racing Association's tracks -- Aqueduct, Belmont Park and Saratoga -- and the privately owned Finger Lakes at Canandaigua.

PARIS, March 5 (AP) -- Gaullists and leftists made some gains in the first round of France's municipal elections yesterday at the expense of the small centrist and rightist parties. Runoffs will be held next Sunday in those districts, including all of Paris, where no slate got a majority.
TRIPOLI, Libya, March 15 (Reuters) -- Four Arab oil-exporting countries warned tonight they would cut off supplies if Western oil companies refused to meet Libya's demand for higher prices.

NEWARK, March 15 -- Simone Rizzo DeCavalcante, reputedly one of the top figures in organized crime in New Jersey, was sentenced in Federal Court here this evening to five years in prison on charges of having been the mastermind of a $20-million-a-year interstate gambling syndicate.

LONDON, March 15 -- Henry Ford 2d was wooed today by Prime Minister Heath and his three top economics ministers at a luncheon at 10 Downing Street. But the chairman of the Ford Motor Company later reaffirmed his view that industrial chaos was discouraging further Ford investment in this country.

The economic arguments against the supersonic transport continue to pile up. In testimony before the Senate Appropriations Committee, Prof. George W. Rathjens of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology warned Congress against buying "a pig in a poke." He demonstrated that design changes intended to reduce the SST's severe noise level would almost certainly mean such increases in the plane's weight and operating costs that it could not be a profitable plane.
Who would have thought six months ago that leading stock market pundits today would be saying that the market looks a little high, that it's time for a consolidation -that sort of spoilsport talk?

WASHINGTON, March 15, (Reuters) -- Representative Wilbur Mills, Democrat of Arkansas, said today he plans to stand firm against President Nixon's move for legislation to impose mandatory quotas on textile imports.

Joseph Krozak, a 49-year-old executive of a bill-collecting business that handled Medicaid payments, was convicted last night of lying when he denied that he had made payments to employes of the city Social Services Department.

The city's plan to modernize the traffic signals at 700 intersections in Manhattan came a step closer to fruition yesterday when Governor Rockefeller announced a grant of $1.6-million to buy new signal equipment.

The Securities and Exchange Commission and the American Stock Exchange announced severe disciplinary actions yesterday against three stockbrokers accused of manipulating the shares of L'Aiglon Apparel, Inc., on the Amex. At the same time, the S.E.C. revoked the broker-dealer registration of Brand, Grumet Seigel, Inc., the brokerage house where the three men worked and where the alleged manipulation took place.
"Every once in a while still get a flash," said Marvin Z. yesterday at the first annual Gamblers Anonymous seminar in the metropolitan area.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., March 15 -- Adelphi University's board of trustees announced today that it had accepted the resignations of the president and two vice presidents.

At a press conference in the Blue Room at City Hall yesterday, Mayor Lindsay, who wore a yellow shirt and maroon and white tie, announced that he had nominated as the city's first taxicab commissioner Michael J. Lazar, who wore a yellow shirt and a red and white tie.

SYDNEY, Australia, March 15 -- Prime Minister William McMahon, passing his first parliamentary test since taking office five days ago, defeated a motion of no confidence in his Government in the House of Representatives today.

Sander Vanocur, a correspondent for National Broadcasting Company News, will become anchorman of the 6 P.M. newscast of WNBC-TV, Channel 4, a station here owned by NBC. The announcement was made jointly by Reuven Frank, president of N.B.C. News, and by Theodore Walworth, vice president and general manager of WNBC-TV.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- Pleading unbearable losses, Northeast Airlines has asked the Civil Aeronautics Board for some guidelines for the future now that Northwest Airlines has withdrawn from its merger agreement.

Johnny Mercer has written the lyrics for so many memorable popular songs that he had to sing them in medleys to even scratch the surface of his remarkable output as he traced his songwriting career Sunday night at the 92d Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association. Mr. Mercer's appearance was part of the Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. series on "Lyrics and Lyricists."

Directors of Ling - Temco - Vought, Inc., made their first move yesterday to divest the company of its holding in Braniff Airways, Inc., by approving a plan for a nationwide underwriting group to make a secondary public offering of 4.5 million shares of Braniff special Class A stock.
DES MOINES, Iowa -- After a bumper corn crop, perhaps the most revered thing in the State of Iowa is a champion girl basketball player.
TRENTON, March 15-- Gov. William T. Cahill proposed legislation today to improve the living and working conditions for migrant farm workers in New Jersey this summer.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Representative Wilbur D. Mills, who as chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee was an architect of Medicare and Medicaid, will put together a national health insurance bill this spring, Congressional sources said today.

Citing his concern that commercial interests would dominate the development of cable communications and deny access to the medium by minorities and the poor, the Rev. Everett C. Parker announced yesterday that the United Church of Christ would begin an advisory service designed to inform citizens of their rights with regard to CATV.

ALBANY, March 15 -- Governor Rockefeller doesn't back down easily or often but he has convinced even the skeptics here that he is indeed retreating from the record-breaking $8.45-billion budget he proposed six weeks ago and its staggering $1.1-billion tax package.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 15 -- "When Richie Allen was with us last spring," Dal Maxvill of the St. Louis Cardinals was saying in St. Petersburg the other day, "there were times when we wondered if his line drives would hit that building over there and turn it around."

State Banking Superintendent William T. Dentzer Jr. took strong exception yesterday to a charge by Assemblyman Franz S. Leichter that the State Banking Department served the banking industry rather than the public.

More than 800 Dalton School parents jammed into the school gymnasium last night for a meeting that ended, after nearly 3 1/2 hours of high-decibel and often hot-tempered rhetoric, with a decision to vote on the matter at issue by a mail ballot sent to the parents at home.

The minimum original margin requirement for the purchase of silver futures contracts was lowered yesterday to $1,000 by the governors of the Commodity Exchange, Inc. (Comex). The previous margin was $1,500.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The United States today lifted its ban on travel by Americans to Communist China and disclosed that it was working through private diplomatic channels to bring Peking's Ambassador back to the Warsaw talks interrupted more than a year ago.
LOS ANGELES, March 15 (UPI) -- Oscar Bonavena, a heavyweight boxer from Argentina, suffered a broken left wrist in a minor traffic accident early today and will not be able to fight for four months.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- A Senate-House conference committee approved today a 10 per cent across-the-board increase in Social Security benefits, but it cut from the bill that the Senate passed last Friday the proposed new monthly minimums of $100 for individuals and $150 for couples.

Resumption of the strategic arms limitation talks (SALT) in Vienna yesterday finds both the Soviet and American delegates dug into rigid positions on non-essential issues. The deadlock that emerged after 55 sessions could well frustrate any chance of meaningful agreement unless both sides face up to the illogic of their respective stands.
BALTIMORE, March 15--A majority of Roman Catholic priests in this country now oppose mandatory celibacy, Dr. John P. Koval, a sociologist at the University of Notre Dame, reported tonight.
PARIS, March 15 -- France -- indeed, all Europe -- has now heard of Billy Backus.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 15 (AP) -- The group of women's liberationists who seized a Harvard University building nine days ago ended their occupation at 3 P.M. today, leaving as the Cambridge police prepared to oust them. There were about 50 women in the group, plus a few children.

BRIDGEPORT, Tuesday, March 16 -- A Connecticut state official charged in a public hearing yesterday that the Bridgeport police had blocked an independent investigation into five cases of alleged police brutality and that "the minority community has largely lost confidence in the Police Department."

The Stern Metals Corporation has elected Martin H. Dubilier chairman. Mr. Dubilier, formerly president and chief executive officer of Kearney-National, Inc., succeeds Jerome Kohlberg Jr., who has been named chairman of the executive and finance committees.
You could almost hear the hooves thudding through the canyon of Wall Street yesterday.
Glyn Jones, in a Feb. 27 letter, defended the proposal for an all-volunteer army.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 15 -- Gov. Ronald Reagan's welfare reform program, which he has said will cut $740-million from this state's public assistance and Medicaid bills, was introduced into the California Legislature today with five Republican sponsors.

ALBANY, March 15 -- The State Senate voted today to increase the membership of the New York City Board of Elections from four to ten and to give representation to the Bronx, Queens and Staten Island. The bill now goes to the Assembly.
The Knicks, with first place in the National Basketball Association's Atlantic Division finally secured, announced plans for the distribution of playoff tickets yesterday.
SAIGON, March 16 -- The allied base at Khesanh came under intense shelling yesterday, forcing American helicopters based there to scatter into the sky.
Franz Josef Strauss, the West German political leader and former Finance Minister, was robbed of more than $180 by two women early yesterday morning outside the Plaza Hotel.

Pedro Morales of Culebra, Puerto Rico, pinned Black Jack Mulligan in 14 minutes 12 seconds of their wrestling exhibition last night at Madison Square Garden. The victory enabled the 241-pound Morales to retain his title, billed as the World Wide Wrestling Federation heavyweight championship.
MINEOLA, L. I., March 15 -- A committee appointed by Republican members of the Nassau County Board of Supervisors today recommended offtrack pari-mutuel betting in the county subject to a referendum.

BOSTON, March 15 -- Although there is no specific reference to it in the proposed legislation, the future of Massachusetts's 6,000-acre Hockomock Swamp is involved in the fate of Senate Bill 780, which is scheduled for a hearing tomorrow in Room 473-A of the State House at 10 A.M.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, Elliot L. Richardson, said today that the nation "must develop the means of controlling the potential for harm inherent" in the Government's computerized data banks of information on citizens.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The General Accounting Office accused the Nixon Administration today of improper handling of funds designed to ease school desegregation.
ATLANTA, March 15 -- An Army officer preferred formal military charges today against a general and a colonel he has accused of ignoring reports of alleged atrocities in South Vietnam in 1969.
DETROIT, March 15 -- Sales of new cars from March 1 to 10 were ahead of the similar week last year, but the General Motors Corporation made up the biggest gain.

The Feb. 22 news analysis "Nixon and the Suburbs" reads like the heroic saga of President Nixon's almost singlehanded struggle to preserve sanity, law and freedom in a land whose courts are on a self-anointed mission to level everyone and everything down to the lowest common denominator in the name of "equal protection of the law."

JERUSALEM, March 15 -- Premier Golda Meir's Government headed defiantly today into a barrage of criticism, foreign and domestic, accused of being both too rigid and too flexible in defining its terms for peace.

Christopher Hampton's "The Philanthropist" is a good, funny, literate and literary play. The latest in this season's parade of British theatrical invaders, it opened last night at the Ethel Barrymore Theater.

PEKING -- The children of the Western world hear that Jesus is the best of all men. Jesus loves even his enemies, and when His face is slapped turns the other cheek. The religion He has founded is that of Love. Jesus should be the model for all good little boys and girls, says the nice kind teacher before she hurries off to vote for an increased military budget.

CORDOBA, Argentina, March 15 (UPI) -- Thousands of striking workers took over parts of Cordoba tonight, burning and looting amid clashes with the police and causing a crisis for the Government of President Roberto Marcelo Levingston.
A $1.6-billion construction budget for 1971-72, a record, was adopted unanimously last night by the Board of Estimate and the City Council, but only after several hours of wrangling.

A hearing officer recommended yesterday that the Waterfront Commission revoke the temporary stevedore license of the Erb Strapping Company and deny it a permanent one because of the company's associations with members of organized crime.

As a vote in both the House of Representatives and the Senate Appropriations Committee on the supersonic transport plane nears, the Administration and its business and labor union allies in the aircraft industry have joined in a major propaganda drive to squash the public's doubts.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Republican national chairman said today that President Nixon would approve the campaign spending legislation that Congress sends him this year.
Strengthened police patrols, both uniformed and plain-clothes, toured the district between Times Square and Central Park yesterday in a drive against prostitutes.
His voice was soft and warm like a summer breeze on Galway Bay and there was a bit of a tear in his eye as he spoke of the new ad campaign for Irish International Airlines.
The bull market thundered ahead yesterday as volume rose to 22.27 million shares, making it the fourth busiest session on record at the New York Stock Exchange.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 16 (AP) -- Artis Gilmore, Jacksonville's all-America performer, today signed a contract, considered to be worth $1.5-million with the Kentucky Colonels of the American Basketball Association.

JERUSALEM, March 16 (Reuters) -- Following in an unofficial translation from the Hebrew is an excerpt from a speech given today in the Knesset (parliament) by Premier Golda Meir, dealing with the interview she granted last week to Louis Heren of The Times of London:

MINEOLA, L. I., March 16 -- Nassau County announced today that it would study a new method of payment for welfare clients in which funds would be deposited every two weeks in a bank of their choice, instead of their receiving checks.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -Leaders of the health insurance business told Congress today that the best means of financing national medical care was through private industry. However, New York City unions complained that their members were being shortchanged and urged Federal coverage.

The New York Philharmonic will inaugurate a series of nine concerts for members of various unions and their families that will take the orchestra into union-meeting halls for the first time in history.
The following tributes were paid yesterday to former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey:

HONG KONG, March. 16 -Communist China announced today that it had orbited its second earth satellite on March 3. The Chinese announcement came nearly two weeks after the launching was detected by the North American Air Defense command and reported by the Pentagon.

The city has obtained judgments totaling $122,000 against 375 scofflaws who have received three or more parking tickets since July 1, Transportation Administrator Constantine Sidamon-Eristoff reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (UPI) -- The House Armed Services Committee voted today to extend the draft until June 30, 1973, and to give President Nixon authority to abolish deferments for undergraduate college students.

Joe Frazier was admitted to St. Luke's Hospital in Philadelphia yesterday for what his physician described as "high blood pressure" related to the world heavyweight champion's "commitments" following his strenuous victory over Muhammad Ali last week at Madison Square Garden.
ROME, March 16 -- Judicial sources said today that Italy's highest court was about to remove a legal ban on any form of public information on birth control.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -The long-submerged differences between Israel and the United States over the shape of a final settlement in the Middle East were fully exposed today in the almost simultaneous statements by Premier Golda Meir and Secretary of State William P. Rogers.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -The Judicial Conference of the United States has voted to reduce the size of juries in Federal civil trials below the traditional number of 12.

Simon and Garfunkel, the pop-rock duo, walked away with the three most prestigious Grammy Awards for 1970, given annually by the 3,500 members of the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences. The members are musicians, conductors, singers, arrangers, producers and other members of the recording industry.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 16 -- The necessity of raising taxes cost at least a half-dozen Governors their jobs last November, and governorships are coming to be regarded among politicians as dead ends.

Economists are generally regarded as compulsive promoters of economic growth for its own sake. But more and more economists are coming to feel that the most important, unsolved problem facing their profession is how to reduce or prevent the undesirable consequences of growth -- such as choked high ways, overcrowded airports, noise, foul air, polluted water, despoiled nature, urban sprawl, decaying central cities.

OAKLAND, Calif., March 16 -- The 7,000 - student Merritt College campus, which was closed today after nearly 100 black, chicano and radical whites took over administration offices, was to remain closed tomorrow -- less than a week before final examinations.

By a four-to-one decision, the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court reversed yesterday a Family Court order that a father had to support his daughter's hippie way of life, which he frowned on, and pay for her college tuition.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -Provision of long-term guaranteed loans for unemployed engineers, scientists and technicians was proposed today by Senator Edward M. Kennedy to help ease their conversion from aerospace and defense work to civilian projects.
The 5 1/2 per cent prime rate on business loans -- which was established at most large banks only last week -- continued to erode yesterday.
A new born baby girl found abandoned on a school bus in Brooklyn two weeks ago went home yesterday with her foster parents, the bus driver and his wife who already had five children.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- An independent product-testing organization reported today that blankets containing 35 per cent rayon catch fire in one second when exposed to a flame.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, March 17 -- South Vietnamese forward units in Laos have reportedly withdrawn five miles eastward toward their own border under increasing enemy pressure.

ROME, March 16 -- A group of Catholics of the Ukrainian Rite from the United States charged here today that the Vatican was sacrificing their church for the sake of closer relations between the Papacy and the Kremlin.
SAN RAFAEL, Calif., March 16 -- Attorneys for Angela Davis argued today that murder, kidnap and criminal conspiracy charges lodged against her should be dismissed.
PARIS, March 16 -- France's commercial air fleet of 158 planes will resume service tomorrow after a 26-day interruption caused by a labor dispute.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N. Y., March 16 -- Sleepy Hollow High School was closed at 10 o'clock this morning and the 1,150 students sent home after racial tension threatened to become "unmanageable," according to school officials here.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 16 -- Executives of the BankAmerica Corporation, the parent holding company of the Bank of America, came to their annual meeting of stockholders here today prepared for criticism. The Columbia Broadcasting System formally announced last night the expected sweeping changes in its fall television schedule. WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The most serious problem in Washington today -- because it affects most other problems -- is the decline in honest argument. VIENNA, March 16 -- The United States and the Soviet Union restated their positions on the limitation of strategic nuclear arms today as they held the first working session of the newly begun fourth round of their talks.

ALBANY, March 16 -- The state paid $58-million more in unemployment insurance benefits in January and February than it did in the same period last year, Controller Arthur Levitt reported today. Sources in the Controller's office said this reflected a sharp surge in layoffs.

TRENTON, March 16 -- Gov. William T. Cahill announced today that the six New Jersey commissioners of the Port of New York Authority had agreed to seek a restoration of their policy-making power that the Governor contends has been largely taken over by the authority's Executive Director, Austin J. Tobin.

AUSTIN, Tex., March 16 -- Leaders of the American oil industry told the Texas Railroad Commission today that they expected a growth of 4.8 per cent to 5.6 per cent in demand for oil and its products in the United States this year.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., March 16 -- Thomas E. Dewey, Governor of New York for three terms and twice the Republican nominee for President, died about 3:30 P.M. today while alone in his room at the Seaview Hotel in this resort town north of Miami Beach. He was 68 years old.

Negotiations for control of the Security National Bank, a $1-billion institution based in Huntington, L. I., are "fluid" at the moment, Patrick J. WASHINGTON, March 16 -Legislation providing a 10 per cent increase in Social Security benefits for 26 million retired people was rushed through both houses of Congress today and sent to the White House.
