Miss Jan Blackburn Washington, daughter of Lieut. Col. Richard B. Washington, U.S.A. retired, and Mrs. Washington of New Milford, Conn., was married yesterday in a civil ceremony in Darmstadt, Germany, to Karsten Gunther Stodte.
Dr. Robert E. Marshak, the president of City College, officially endorsed yesterday a student-faculty report that called for the use of the police to rid the campus of drug pushers.

Faculty members and students at Columbia University have written a letter to the university president urging him to assure that Charles Wuorinen, the winner of the 1970 Pulitzer Prize in musical composition, and three other music professors are retained by the school.

Although all four division leaders have clinched their positions, seven teams in the National Basketball Association are still in contention for three divisions' second playoff berths. Two other teams are hoping to establish playoff home-court advantages during the remaining games.
MOSCOW, March 17 -- The Soviet Union announced today the start of operations of its largest blast furnace, capable of producing up to two million tons of pig iron a year.

Your March 10 editorial on the AliFrazier fight was excellent in every respect but its conclusion. If history is to be our reference, the propensity of masses to be spectators at events of dehumanizing violence is indeed indicative of a society in decline. But to outlaw professional boxing by legislative fiat would be to treat the symptom and not the cause.
Bellevue Hospital has closed its psychiatric prison ward to new admissions until what the hospital described as the "dangerous overcrowded situation" there is alleviated.

Chess openings -- deployment patterns -- have been the subject of study for centuries. A manuscript on the openings discovered in the 19th century is now at the University of Gottingen, Germany. It was written in 1490.

DACCA, Pakistan, March 17 -- Carrying all their belongings of value, their children balanced on their hips and cradled in their arms, nervous Bengalis are fleeing West Pakistan. Equally nervous Punjabis and other West Pakistanis are fleeing East Pakistan in reverse.
New York City's infant mortality rate dropped to a record low in 1970, the Health Department reported yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, March 17 -While his physician searched today for a possible kidney ailment, Joe Frazier, relaxing upright in his hospital bed, listened to rock music, dispatched a visitor for an Afro comb, munched on watermelon, considered a motion-picture offer and spoke vaguely of retirement.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (UPI) -- Officials of two Federal agencies acknowledged today under questioning by members of a House subcommittee that there were shortcomings in their enforcement of laws banning potentially harmful food additives.

Everything came up roses for the American Basketball Association last night on its second foray into Madison Square Garden, the most prestigious basketball arena in the world and the stronghold of the more established National Basketball Association.

Frank Graham Jr. in a Feb. 20 Op-Ed article, "DDT Is Still Too Much With Us," has much to say regarding the protection of bird life. But he is evidently more interested in fingerpointing and sensationalism than in journalistic accuracy.

WASHINGTON, March 17--A study of defense industry profits released today by the General Accounting Office reports widespread inefficiency and disregard of cost factors by defense contractors.

Chances are now "two to one" that a "dull" and "disappointing" business performance in the first quarter will lead the Administration to propose an immediate tax cut, Alan Greenspan said yesterday.

SAN JUAN, P. R., March 17 -A third-year student at the University of Puerto Rico was arrested today and charged with the slaying of the commander of the riot police last Thursday during rioting on the Rio Piedras campus.

Y., March 17, -- Educators and education broadcasting specialists have been meeting at the Sterling Forest Conference Center this week to plan a venture that would adapt the techniques of the "Sesame Street" television programs to reach deficient high-school, and first-year college students, and high-school dropouts.

The death of Whitney M. Young Jr. is a grievous loss to America -- white and Negro. Your news and editorial coverage was properly generous, but I would like to comment on some implications in the obituary.

At the start of the annual meeting yesterday of the Loews Corporation, Laurence A. Tisch, chairman, announced that profits for the second fiscal quarter soared more than 100 per cent. After that, it was all anticlimactic.
TORTOLA, British Virgin Islands, March 18 (AP) -- For many British and French islands in the Caribbean this is election year, and tourism, which is suffering, may never be the same again.

BOGOTA, Colombia -- The American way of life is a much battered aphorism that has been sadly tarnished by hostile propaganda both inside and outside the United States. With more than a touch of a sneer it has come to imply a kind of dislike for U. S. policy in Latin America where adversaries stress our inability to find quick solutions to burgeoning urban, race and ecological problems.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (UPI) -- Dr. John L. Avery of Silver Springs, Md., was charged with assault with attempt to rape yesterday after a deputy county medical examiner testified that he and a woman detective had watched the attempt on a television receiver in an adjacent apartment.

Pan American Airways, Inc., announced yesterday that Donald M. Kendall James A. Linen 3d and Thomas J. Watson Jr. have been named to the board of directors. Mr. Kendall is president and chief executive officer of Pepisco, Inc.; Mr. Linen, chairman of the executive committee of Time, Inc., and Mr. Watson is chairman of the International Business Machines Corporation.

RALEIGH, N. C., March 18 -Villanova slammed shut the book on Fordham's fine success story of this basketball season tonight by beating the spunky, small Rose Hill mob, 85-75, in the Eastern Regional semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

The Federal Reserve System appears to have embarked on a deliberate effort to prevent short-term interest rates from falling further, while at the same time continuing to push the cost of long-term borrowing downward.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 18 -There was some concern tonight when Willis Reed went to the bench after the opening 10 minutes. But the big Knickerbocker center returned in the sticky closing minutes of regulation play, then hit two long jumpers to start the overtime period o help New York beat Phoenix, 131-123, and eliminate the Suns from the playoffs in the Midwest Division of the National Basketball Association.

A study sent yesterday to the White House, the Department of the Interior and the State Department asserts that a crude-oil price increase of 48 cents a barrell will be needed to encourage enough domestic oil exploration so that United States dependence on Middle East sources can be limited to 10 per cent of total demand through 1985.

NEW HAVEN, March 18 -Subpoenaed just 40 minutes before the court session began, the first witness in the murderkidnapping trial of Bobby G. Seale and Ericka Huggins testified today that Mrs. Huggins was in the room at Black Panther headquarters here while Alex Rackley was being beaten with a stick.
Three Staten Island families who shared a $1 ticket won a top prize of $100,000 in the state lottery drawing yesterday at the Port of New York Authority bus terminal, Eighth Avenue and 40th Street.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -William D. Ruckelshaus, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, said today he had decided that the pesticide DDT and the herbicide 2, 4, 5-T were not "imminent" hazards to humans.

Michael Tilson Thomas's program with the Boston Symphony, in Philharmonic Hall on Wednesday evening, was an example of unusual and even defiant juxtapositions. Bach and Schoenberg; intermission; Stravinsky and Tchaikovsky.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- President Nixon asked Congress today to send $2.56-billion in Federal funds to states and cities to help build a "balanced" transportation system that would reduce dependence on the automobile.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 18 (AP) -- The United States command said today that 45 Americans were killed in combat in Indochina last week, an increase of one over the previous week. It listed 156 Americans wounded, compared with 434 the week before.

MOSCOW, March 18 -- An appeal attributed to two dissidents in a Leningrad psychiatric prison hospital contends that drugs are being administered forcibly to inmates in an effort to have them change their political beliefs.
A 241-count indictment was returned by a Manhattan grand jury yesterday against Dr. Frederick Fisher, a dentist, for allegedly falsifying Medicaid claims against the city.

Earnings of the British Petroleum Company declined 6 per cent last year from 1969 although the fourth quarter showed a gain of 54 per cent in profits, according to the company's annual report issued yesterday.

TAMPA, Fla., March 18 -- Although the Baltimore Orioles won the last World Series in emphatic style, the one fella who turned it into something of a personal triumph was Sparky Anderson, then the rookie manager of the Cincinnati Reds. Suddenly exposed to nationwide scrutiny for the first time, the chief mechanic for the Big Red Machine handled a difficult role in such refreshing fashion that he won friends and admirers in wholesale lots.
The chief prosecutor in the murder and manslaughter trial of Mrs. Alice Crimmins declared yesterday that the 32-year-old woman had confessed to the July, 1965, killing of her two small children.

" Steps Toward a New Consciousness" is the title of a program of short films that, according to David Bienstock, the Whitney Museum's film program director, attempt to communicate and make visible some of the experiences of the new American spiritual revolution.

William Irwin Thompson is a barely-over-30 cultural historian from California, with the mind of a scholiast and the imagination of a William Blake. He teaches at York University in Toronto, which is lucky for Canada. His only previous book was "The Imagination of an Insurrection: Dublin, Easter 1916," which I haven't read but intend to at once.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- The Soviet Union has again protested harassment by the Jewish Defense League and requested that the Administration "assure normal working conditions" for the Soviet Embassy and its personnel here.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -The impasse that has delayed the filling of 10 Federal judgeship vacancies in the New York City area was broken today with an apparent agreement on the nomination of at least three District Court judges.

BALTIMORE, March 18 -- If the Roman Catholic hierarchy fails to heed the latest call for reform in the life of the church, the exodus of priests from the ministry may increase, the Rev. William F. Graney, executive director of the National Federation of Priests Councils, said today in an interview.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 18 -- A provision in a draft electoral law to limit the number of candidates in the October presidential election was defeated today by a large vote in the Senate.
The restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored where indicated.

A hostile appraisal of the city's master plan by the metropolitan chapter of the American Institute of Planning has enmeshed that organization in an internal dispute amid charges that the chairman of the City Planning Commission is trying to block the adverse report, or at least have it watered down.
The stock market appeared to be consolidating some of its recent large gains yesterday as the list made a modest advance in active trading.

Preliminary discussions have been held by representatives of regional stock exchanges about the possibility of uniting their markets electronically, according to Elkins Wetherill, president of the Philadelphia-Baltimore-Washington Stock Exchange.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -The Nixon Administration sent to Congress today a bill to renew the Office of Economic Opportunity and Federal antipoverty programs for two years.

ATLANTA, March 18 -- The New York representatives were almost wiped out in yesterday's play here in the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship, the premier event of the American contract bridge league's spring nationals.

Your March 2 editorial on Chancellor Harvey Scribner and the school supervisors had an admirable purpose: to try to get the Chancellor and the supervisors to work together in the interests of better schools for our children. But its even-handed "both sides are to blame" approach hides a major aspect of the problem.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Gen. William C. Westmoreland has recommended that Maj. Gen. Samuel W. Koster and the general who was his assistant in command of the Army division involved in the alleged masacre at the South Vietnamese hamlet of Mylai 4 be demoted and reprimanded, Pentagon sources said today.
After a two-and-a-halfmonth interregnum, a new president and chief operating officer was named yesterday by the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation.
After five years of waiting and hoping, many of New York's elected officials are turning away from psychotherapy as a way to treat heroin addicts and are relying instead on chemistry.

BOSTON, March 18 -Vice President Agnew questioned the credibility of the Columbia Broadcasting System tonight and accused the national news media of "indifference" to earlier criticism of the network by a Government agency and a Congressional subcommittee.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 18 -- Although there are more gray hairs on Lindy McDaniel's head now than when he started pitching in the majors 16 years ago, there's no more fat on his body and no less enthusiasm in his mind.
Flamboyant, fast-talking and a daringly irrepressible maker of big deals, Leland Hayward was an almost legendary figure in the entertainment world.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 18 (UPI) -- Laffit Pincay Jr. rode five straight winners today, his third five-victory performance of the Santa Anita meeting, and Johnny Sellers piloted the 18-1 long shot Long Position to a head triumph in the feature race, the $27,650 San Simeon Handicap.
Two young men said to be college students were arrested last evening when they were allegedly driving through the Lower East Side with three home-made bombs and elements for making more.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -A House Judiciary subcommittee heard testimony today urging the repeal of the Emergency Detention Act that was enacted during the McCarthy era 21 years ago.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -Western members of Congress, asserting a proprietary interest in the Department of the Interior, have protested to the White House over the prospective nomination of an economist and systems analysis expert as Under Secretary of the department.
On St. Patrick's Day some 120,000 paraders marched proudly and many more watched and enjoyed the highstepping display, the bands and the admirable spirit of identification with past traditions.

After a bitterly disappointing season in which his team lost 20 of 25 games, Lou Rossini resigned yesterday as head basketball coach of New York University, ending a 13-year tenure. He had been under pressure from alumni distressed by N. Y. U.'s highest number of losses since the sport was instituted at the school in 1906.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 18 -- Cambodia today marked the first anniversary of the overthrow of Prince Norodom Sihanouk with a ban on public demonstrations, an air of vigilance and a display of flags on public buildings.

SAN RAFAEL, Calif., March 18 (AP) -- A judge said today that he had disqualified himself from the Angela Davis case because he was accused of prejudice and did not want to go "through any hullabaloo on it."

Mrs. Flora Ettlinger Whiting, widow of Giles Whiting, a manufacturer of Persian rugs, has left an estate estimated at $20-million to $25-million, according to a will offered for probate in the New York Surrogate Court.

In an expansion of a program begun last July, all newly admitted prisoners to the Manhattan House of Detention who are drug addicts will be detoxified with the aid of methadone if they so request, starting next Monday.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -Senior United States said today that they r tomorrow's conference between Secretary of State Rogers and Foreign Minister Eban as a first step in a protracted and complex diplomatic process.

The tortuous negotiations for new contracts covering the city's police, fire and sanitation forces enter what should be their last lap with appointment of a three-man impasse panel to make joint recommendations for resolving all three disputes.

An agreement in principle has been reached by G. D. Searle Co., Chicago, and Howmedica, Inc., New York City, for the merger of Howmedica into Searle. Under the agreement, shareholders of the New York company would receive 0.44 share of Searle common for each Howmedica share.
TRENTON, March 18 (UPI) -- The New Jersey State Insurance Department announced new Blue Cross rates today, averaging a 9.6 per cent increase -- roughly half of what had been sought.
A straight-set victory over Dennis Ralston sent a refreshed Rod Laver into tonight's final round of the Tennis Champions Classic at Madison Square Garden.

FORT BENNING, Ga., March 18 --The jury in the Mylai murder trial of First Lieut. William L. Dan Patch of the illustrious name registered a surprise victory in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. Competing against such well-known and established stars as Handsome Kid, Shining Sword, Climber and Jamestown Court, the Eleanor Lichtenstein representative scored by two lengths in the one-mile event.

ALBANY, March 18 -- Governor Rockefeller, in his latest fiscal retreat, has dropped plans for a community development bond issue of up to $10-billion that he had described in his annual message in January as one of his two "most important legislative objectives."
The city seized a shabby redand-white Volkswagen bus yesterday as its first hostage in a new crackdown on traffic-ticket scofflaws.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -Japan has been officially informed that the United States might in theory restrict textile imports through two provisions of existing law, but neither is under active consideration by the Government.

The United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York opened its 1971 drive for $150-million last night with pledges and cash gifts of $35-million to carry out programs to assist men, women and children in Israel and elsewhere.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 18 -- Foreign Minister Abba Eban of Israel met separately today with Secretary General Thant and Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring and restated his nation's determination to hold on to boundaries that it considers defensible.

COLORADO SPRINGS, March 18 -- The defending champion New York University fencing team was one of 12 schools to qualify all three of its fencers in today's opening round of the National Collegiate championships at the Air Force Academy. The final two rounds will be held tomorrow and Saturday.

With seven potential challengers waiting in the wings, the club's cup committee has tried to bar an up setting situation by informing the challengers that they'll have to set up elimination trials themselves.

It's been three years since her son was graduated from medical school, but Mrs. Albert Waldman was at Alumni Hall on First Avenue Wednesday night for the meeting of the Parents Association of the New York University School of Medicine.

The former husband of Mrs. Alice Crimmins testified yesterday that he had wanted to help his wife during her first trial for murder of their daughter, but said he felt differently now that she was being tried a second time.

MOSCOW, March 19 -- While the future of nuclear power in the United States continues to be obscured by controversy, the Soviet Union has decided after long hesitation to embark on an ambitious program of expansion of atomic generating plants.
CLEVELAND, March 19 (UPI) -- Kjell Isaksson of Sweden set a world indoor pole vault record of 17 feet 9 inches tonight in the Knights of Columbus track meet.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -The Nixon Administration was accused today of seeking to curtail public awareness of and citizen participation in next month's White House Conference on Youth in an effort to eliminate controversy.

SEBRING, Fla., March l9 -Despite the pain of a sprained right ankle, Mark Donohue broke the qualifying-lap record today to win the pole position for tomorrow's running of the Twelve Hours of Sebring. The race, which begins at 11 A.M., is the third of the 1971 series of 12 for the world manufacturers' championship.

SANTA FE, N. M. -- On the hogans of the old sheep herders of the Navajo people, in northern Arizona, the snow is heavy. It buries not only the sheep pastures but also the strip-mining machinery. The bulldozers that have been gutting the sacred Black Mountain, the "Female Mountain" of the Navajo's religious belief, are momentarily silenced.
MIAMI, March 19 -- Diplomats in the United States and Venezuela can relax. L'Affaire Fishel has ended, eradicating the threat of a cessation in friendly relations between the countries.

PRAGUE, March 19 (Reuters) -- Sixteen young radical leftists, who said they were opposed to Communist bureaucracy but not to Communism, were convicted of subversion today and sentenced to prison terms of one to four years.

Professional students of the Soviet Union were not surprised the other day to learn of the cynical distortion with which a Soviet "scholarly" magazine presented Supreme Court Justice Douglas's book to its readers. The technique of tearing material out of context by carefully eliminating all "unsuitable" passages is one long practiced by Soviet propagandists. Mr. Douglas is not likely to be the last victim.
The American Broadcasting Company announced its fall television schedule last night, killing 11 of this year's shows, including Lawrence Welk, and adding seven new programs.

ATLANTA, March 19 (UPI) -- Walt Hazzard scored 2 points with 24 seconds left in overtime tonight to lift the Atlanta Hawks to a 112-111 victory over the Chicago Bulls and a berth in the National Basketball Association playoffs.

Martha Anne Verbit, herself a Scriabinesque vision in a romantically gauzy gown of peacock-tail colors, made her New York debut at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday night in an allScriabin piano recital. Miss Verbit is tall, blond and extravagantly good-looking, and her playing proved handsome, too, on the whole, though occasionally labored and lacking in articulation.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -Informal polling of Senators showed gains for supporters of the supersonic transport today as the Senate scheduled a new and possibly final vote on the controversial airliner for next Wednesday.
MIAMI, March 19 -- The Yankees not only lost their 11th straight game tonight -- a 6-4 decision to the Baltimore Orioles -- but they also lost a player and a coach along the way.

As a Greek student who has had the luck temporarily to get out of his country for a course of studies here, I feel that it is only proper that Edward C. Diedrich receive a response to his March 3 letter. In it he comments on the letter of Prof. William V. Spanos about United States support for the Greek junta.
The new-issue market, where shares of companies that have never previously had public owners are traded, registered its third consecutive advance this week in fairly heavy trading.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- A decline in new orders for durable goods rounded out today a picture of relatively sluggish economic indicators for February.

The Walter E. Heller Inter. I national Corporation, a Chicagot based, worldwide commercial finance company with $990million in assets, emerged yes. terday as the leading contender to take over the Security National Bank, a $1-billion institution based in Huntington, L.I.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 19 (UPI) -- Don January, the 1970 winner, carded a fiveunder-par 67 today and tied for the second-round lead in the $125,000 Greater Jacksonville Open with Steve Melnyk, a hometown amateur.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -Three Soviet officials will arrive here on Sunday to spend two and a half weeks studying American use of computers in patent management and American licensing procedures.
Stock prices drifted downward in relatively slow trading yesterday, but the market had its share of individual movers.

Italy's Interior Minister insists there is no reason for the alarms that have been rife this week concerning a neo-Fascist plot against the Government. He will be right about that only if the democratic forces that participate in Premier Colombo's coalition or support it in Parliament can end their incessant bickering and close ranks quickly in the national interest.

MADISON, Wisc. -- Harold Rohr, known to everybody as Babe, has been a local symbol of hard-hat support for the Vietnam war. He is president of the Madison Building Trades Council. As an alderman a few years ago he fought the peace groups and opposed a referendum on the war.

The exhibition of drawings by Richard Diebenkorn, currently on view at the Poindexter Gallery, 24 East 84th Street, brings us a large selection of the work he has done in this medium since his last New York show in the fall of 1969.

Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange climbed 1,198,876 shares in the month ended March 15 and reached a total of 20,758,529 shares, the highest since Dec. 13, 1968, the month the bull market reached its apex.
A former assistant state attorney general and two other Long Island lawyers were found guilty here yesterday of conspiracy to extort and attempted extortion.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -For the time being, at least, the controversy over the Vietnam issue has abated on Capitol Hill.

PARIS, March 19 -- The French national broadcasting system, possibly the most talkative in the world, has in response to popular demand decided on a cautious experiment. For a week, there will be music without commentaries on its least-heard radio network, France-Musique.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -The nationwide rise in consumer prices moderated further in February, making two months of considerably less inflation than there was in most of 1969 and 1970, the Labor Department reported today.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 19 -- The New York Mets got their last look at the Pittsburgh Pirates today before the pennant race opens and they saw more signs that the summer of 1971 might be as troublous as the summer of 1970.
CARLISLE, Pa., March 19 -PPG Industries today announced plans to build what is believed to be the world's largest floatglass plant at a cost of more than $50-million.

Two young men arrested Thursday for possession of bombs were placed under $200,000 bail yesterday after a prosecutor said they were connected to a series of more than 100 actual or attempted bombings in the city over the last two years.

The suggestion that free heroin be dispensed to addicts in the United States was described yesterday as, at best, something to be approached with "great caution" and, at worst, "a public health catastrophe."

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., March 19 (AP) -- Zelmo Beaty, Willie Wise and Glen Coombs combined for 73 points tonight to lead the Utah Stars to a 115104 American Basketball Association victory over the New York Nets at the Island Garden.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- When the news broke last May that Speaker John W. McCormack was retiring, Representative Wilbur D. Mills was presiding over a meeting of his House Ways and Means Committee.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, March 20 -- The South Vietnamese command announced yesterday that it had withdrawn 2,000 to 3,000 of its troops from action in Laos in 48 hours.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (Reuters) -- Representative Wilbur D. Mills, the Arkansas Democrat who helped to persuade the Japanese textile industry to impose voluntary restrictions on exports to the United States, said today that a similar formula should be applied to shoe imports.
MOSCOW, March 19 (UPI) -Authoritative Soviet sources today denied reports that the Soviet Union intended to issue 300,000 visas over the next few years to Jews who want to leave the Soviet Union.
Hoist the Flag, Mrs. Stephen C. Clark Jr.'s colt who was the champion of his division in 1970, will encounter more opposition than was expected in the seven-furlong Bay Shore at Aqueduct today.

ANKARA, March 19 -- President Cevdet Sunay ended a week of constitutional crisis today by designating a respected middle-of-the-road politician to form a new government. The President also called on all parliamentary groups to give the new leader, Nihat Erim, their unconditional support.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (UPI) -- Secretary of the Army Stanley R. Resor announced today major policy changes designed to end off-base housing discrimination wherever American soldiers are stationed and to help make sure Negroes get fairer treatment generally.

FORT BENNING, Ga., March 19 -- The jury of six combat officers charged with determining the fate of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. ended its third day of deliberation today without reaching a verdict.

CULEBRA, Puerto Rico, March 11 -- A campaign of demonstrations motivated by concern for ecology, hopes for Puerto Rican independence, and, perhaps, for future real estate values has won one victory over the United States Navy on this island and could win another.
ALBANY, March 19 -- "He's this year's scapegoat," a state official said today. "He's the rod drawing the lightning of people critical about welfare costs."

In the half-century since its creation the Port of New York Authority has tended increasingly to become a law unto itself, initiating its own policies and having them dutifully rubber-stamped by the elected officials of New York and New Jersey.
HARTFORD, March 18 -- It may be true, as many say, that the income tax is the fairest of all taxes, but a good many people in Connecticut are not convinced.
Louis (Satchmo) Armstrong has responded to treatment and "made further improvement" in the intensive care unit of Beth Israel Hospital, a hospital spokesman said yesterday.
Remember how General Host got involved in that big battle for Armour Co. with Greyhound and lost? Well, lots of people in Wall Street are wishing they could lose the way General Host did.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -Foreign Minister Abba Eban of Israel emphatically reaffirmed today that his country would never withdraw to the boundaries before the 1967 war as the price for a peace treaty with the United Arab Republic.

The Consumer Price Index in the New York-Northeastern New Jersey area rose at four times the national rate last month, mostly because of higher rents and automobile insurance rates, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.
LIMA, Peru, March 19 (AP) -An avalanche rained tons of water, mud and rocks on an isolated mining camp high in the Andes Mountains and killed 400 to 600 people, the federal police said today.

Stockholders of American Airlines, the nation's second largest domestic air carrier, and Western Air Lines, the sixth largest, approved yesterday a merger initially proposed in a different form last October.
The American Stock Exchange ended the week in a bearish manner yesterday as the list declined in less active trading.
LONDON -- Twenty years ago Ingrid Bergman shocked her fans, outraged the Daughters of the American Revolution and saw her films boycotted in the United States.

If a boutique needs an image to make good, then Narcissa should be around for a long time. The shop put on a fashion show earlier this week to display its spring and summer line and its image was certainly clear: Narcissa is for the young woman who's into all the latest looks and has the body to wear them.

CAIRO, March 19 -- The United Arab Republic reported today that two Israeli Phantom jet fighter-bombers intruded into Egyptian air space this morning near the northern end of the Suez Canal and were challenged by antiaircraft defenses.

The subtitle of Morris Dickstein's study points less to the development of the work than to the consciousness of the man who wrote it. There was, of course, enormous development in the work. The jump from the poems in the first book to the poetry brought out only three years later is almost impossible to measure.
A microwave television network will link the offices of 16 local governments in the metropolitan area starting this autumn, officials of the Metropolitan Regional Council announced yesterday.
NEWTON, Mass., March 19 -- The Nixon Administration would admit it publicly if South Vietnamese combat forces were mauled by the enemy in Laos, Vice President Agnew said today.

RALEIGH, N. C., March 19 -- Pennsylvania, the only undefeated baseketball team in the nation and Villanova will meet tomorrow afternoon in the first battle of neighborhood rivals ever staged in the quarterfinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship.

No normal person validly denies the existence of a world that shows orderly intelligence in its origin and its creation by some power. If we agree that this power was a conscious and intelligent force that is still functioning, then we fulfill the literal definition of believers in God.

SYRACUSE, March 19 -- Minnesota, a fifth-place finisher in its own Western Association and a definite underdog in this tournament, ended Harvard's dream of a national hockey title tonight by defeating the Crimson, 6-5, in a 10-minute sudden-death overtime period.
A 28-year-old teacher in the Bronx was sexually assaulted in her third-grade classroom by an intruder yesterday shortly before class was to start.

The East River Savings Bank announced yesterday the appointment of Walter Oberstebrink to the new post of senior vice president and executive assistant to the president. Mr. Oberstebrink, who will join the bank April 5, has been vice president and assistant to the chairman and president of the Security National Bank, based in Huntington, L. I. His new duties will include the areas of bank operations, marketing and personnel administration.

George A. Stinson, president and chief executive officer of the National Steel Corporation, served notice here yesterday that the steel industry expects more than one round of price increases on most of its major products this year.

ATLANTA, March 19 -- The world champion Dallas Aces came within a hairbreadth of defeat in a quarterfinal match in the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship here last night. They won on the very last deal of a 72-deal match in this premier event of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals.
BUENOS AIRES, March 19 -President Roberto Marcelo Levingston said today that he had dismissed the chairman of the Argentine joint chiefs of staff for "a disciplinary infraction of grave character."

Mayor Lindsay suggested yesterday that the city take the lead in formulating an action plan for the aging to present to the Nixon Administration, but without associating it with his office because "politically it cannot help."

PASADENA, Calif., March 19 -- The various creative undercurrents in this loosely knit but prolific artistic region are very much in the spotlight these days, with the output filling the galleries of the Pasadena Art Museum.
LOS ANGELES, March 19 (AP) -- Mayor Sam Yorty has advised an aide to President Nixon that without reciprocal protections "the American Film industry will cease to exist."

NEWARK, March 19 -- Frank Addonizio, a former City Councilman here who is awaiting prosecution under a 66-count Federal indictment charging extortion and conspiracy, is scheduled to take up his duties on Monday as one of three newly appointed investigators of fraud for the Essex County Welfare Board.

The Columbia University Senate, by a 53-to-6 vote, yesterday approved a resolution condemning classroom disruption and other "violent, coercive or destructive" actions that interfere with academic freedom at the university.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -The United States Geological Survey reported today that snow depth and snow water content in the Northeast were far above normal.

The Benrus Corporation estimated its operating loss for the year ended Jan. 31 at "over $2million." Victor K. Kiam 2d, president, said that in addition it was estimated that non-recurring losses in connection with restructuring of watch manufacturing facilities, a previously announced change in marketing policies, write-offs of physical assets and revaluation of inventories would also be "in excess of $2-million."

JERUSALEM, March 19 -Deputy Premier Yigal Allon emphasized today Israel's conviction that no political arrangements or guarantees could substitute for defensible frontiers, guarded by Israel's own forces.
British Government bonds gained and Australian yesterissues were in demand yesterday on the London Stock Exchange, but trading was at a low level. American stocks were firm.

DETROIT, March 19 (AP) -Domestic automobile production continued steady this week with the industry planning to assemble its two-millionth car of calendar 1971 two and a half weeks earlier than last year.

A Swiss inventor was granted a patent this week for a wristwatch that checks on radioactivity in the environment. The luminescence of material forming part of the watch face varies with the radiation to which it has been subjected.
VILA, New Hebrides, March 8 -- Changes have already come to Vila, normally a sleepy town of about 4,000 people.

WARSAW, March 19 -- Edward Gierek, Poland's Communist party leader, indicated today that only firm action by the Polish Army in putting down last December's antiGovernment riots kept Soviet troops from intervening.

Prompt action by the City of New York and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority in tolling bridges and tunnels would encourage a more balanced transportation system and limit the number and magnitude of transit fare increases.

Listeners eager to catch Mike Seeger, just back from a tour of Australia, New Zealand and Japan and en route to Saratoga Springs to appear tonight and tomorrow at the Cafe Lena, packed the Folklore Center, 321 Avenue of the Americas, on Thursday.

The 34th annual National Invitation Tournament opens today at Madison Square Garden with eight hours of basketball, some of the nation's top college scorers and rebounders, and a wide open race for team honors.

Prof. Alexander Birman, Soviet economist and chief of the chair of economics of the Moscow State Institute of National Economy, suggests in his Op-Ed article (March 10) that "mankind ought to mark" the fiftieth anniversary of the U.S.S.R. State Planning Committee "just as it would the first round - the - world trip or Copernicus' discovery, as a historical event, signifying man's attainment of a basically new stage in human development."
Jim Hall brought his deft and subtle guitar to the Jazz Adventures series yesterday afternoon at Downbeat, Lexington Avenue at 42d Street, and both he and the audience made a happy discovery.

A group of 43 politicial leaders yesterday denounced as "irresponsible" an effort to repeal the part of last year's rentcontrol amendments that authorizes a second round of rent increases next January.

The State Senate's vote to increase membership on the New York City Board of Elections, from the present four members to a proposed ten, perpetuates a political anachronism. The board is a patronage pot, largely controlled by the Democratic and Republican leaders of Manhattan and Brooklyn. In general, its members have been aged politicians rewarded for partisan service.

STAPHORST, the Netherlands, March 19 (Reuters) -A poliomyelitis epidemic attributed in part to a religious sect's refusal to accept vaccination struck two more children here, raising the total to 32. Three children have died.
What was described as the first government - financed neighborhood consumer complaint office in the country was formally opened yesterday amid considerable confusion in Forest Hills, Queens.
Net income of the Dayton Hudson Corporation rose in the final quarter but fell in the fiscal year ended Jan. 30, 1971, the retail chain reported yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, March 19 (AP) -- Michael Budzanoski, incumbent president of United Mine Workers District 5, was declared the winner of a controversial election today.

ANDOVER, Mass., March 19 (AP) -- The Gillette Company, which has been without a president since Stuart K. Hensley resigned three years ago, has filled the void by promoting two executive vice presidents to share the responsibilities.
Six students from New York who are attending medical school in Mexico filed a lawsuit yesterday to obtain internships in hospitals in the city.

BURBANK, Calif., March 19 -- Officials of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, the British Government and bankrupt Rolls-Royce, Ltd., completed a full day of talks here today without reaching agreement to save the L-1011 Tristar jetliner program.

At the request of the ItalianAmerican Civil Rights League, the producer of the film "The Godfather" has eliminated all references to the Mafia and Cosa Nostra from the screenplay, which is based on the best-selling novel about a Mafia family.
Interest in world sugar futures dissolved here yesterday as a result of a sharp break in such futures at London. The decline was attributed to a weakening of sugar prices generally.

It takes two acts for Charlotte to discover that she returns Werther's love in the Massenet opera. Perhaps it was right that Rosalind Elias, singing the role of Charlotte for the first time in the Metropolitan Opera's new production of "Werther," on Thursday night, should have seemed rather bland for the first half of the performance.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- Following the death of a Maryland man, the Food and Drug Administration repeated today an urgent warning about a poison mistakenly sold as meat tenderizer in seven states.
Reacting to reports of his retirement, Joe Frazier implied yesterday that he would resume his boxing career, but not until next year.

LONDON, March 19 -- Informed sources in Rhodesia were quoted today as saying that peace talks between that breakaway colony and the British Government would begin in a few days. But the reports, from Agence France-Presse, were denied by the Government in London.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., March 19 (AP) -- If strip-mined coal were no longer available to the Tennessee Valley Authority, the agency said today, "the region it serves would immediately experience an emergency shortage of disastrous proportions."

WASHINGTON, March 19 -Nitroglycerine tablets, used by millions of heart-disease sufferers whenever they experience the chest pains of angina pectoris, lose their potency if dispensed in plastic vials or stored in plastic containers or strip packaging, a graduate student at the University of Maryland has found.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -A private study charged today widespread mismanagement and irresponsibility in the Federal program of educating migrant children.

JERUSALEM -- I am grateful that Philip Johnson's open letter to me on this page placed the controversy over Jerusalem's development in its proper perspective. Too many misconceptions have been created in the minds of Jerusalem's friends abroad.

LILLE, France, March 19 -The worn cobblestone streets of this capital of French Flanders have sprouted something new in the last year: parking meters. They add a little more austerity to what is already an austere region of textile mills, coal mines and steel plants.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- The White House announced today the selection of George C. Guenther to direct the Federal Government's recently enacted job health and safety program covering more than 50 million persons.

The Cloisters, the medieval branch of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in Fort Tryon Park, has taken upon itself to resurrect works that have been relegated to the storage cemeteries and, in some cases never exhibited.

LONDON, March 19 -- Jinxed by repeated lighting failures and by a topless group of People's Theater demonstrators who were finally carried screaming out of the auditorium, the Englishlanguage premiere of JeanLouis Barrault's "Rabelais" at the Roundhouse at least won support from the British sporting instinct.
Eighty-year-old reproductions of important 18th-century work prove that Colonial American furniture has been admired for a long time, and that caution is always advisable in collecting.

On Nov. 3, 1948, as the election tallies disclosed the major upset of modern American politics, the second biggest loser in the country was probably Dr. George H. Gallup, whose polls had promised the Presidency to Thomas E. Dewey by a decisive margin.

KATOWICE, Poland, March 13 -- At the Jan Mine outside this thriving industrial city in southern Poland, a visitor stepped from the main shaft into a clean reception hall. The guide pointed to two taps above a large sink.

TRIPOLI, Libya, March 19 (Reuters) -- Western oil companies have offered a package deal to four Mediterranean oilexporting countries aimed at breaking deadlocked talks here on oil prices, informed sources said tonight.

LONDON, March 19 -- The British Government, in a dramatic move, announced tonight that two key defense officials would fly to Belfast tomorrow in an effort to prevent the resignation of the Northern Ireland Prime Minister, Maj. James D. Chichester-Clark.

A 38-year-old Brooklyn pharmacist who killed a holdup man Thursday -- the second time in a month that he had foiled a holdup with his .38caliber revolver -- was robbed yesterday. His gun was at a police ballistics laboratory.
Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has served notice on the Motion Picture Association of America that it plans to resign from the organization within a year.

SMITHTOWN, L. I., March 19 -- The State Department of Mental Hygiene has directed its employes and patients not to use state resources or their own working time to lobby against proposed legislative budget cuts.

MEXICO CITY, March 19 -The Soviet Embassy responded today to the expulsion of five of its diplomats here with a statement that it had always observed the principle of nonintervention in the affairs of other countries.

Mohawk Airlines and its pilots, who have been on strike since Nov. 12, agreed yesterday to submit their contract dispute to binding arbitration unless they can resolve the principal issues by next Thursday.

IT is 6:30 A.M. on Saturday, a week ago. Peter Boyle sits in the lobby of the dowdy, benevolent Chelsea Hotel in lower Manhattan. He is disguised as an ordinary Joe -- except for his felt hat, which is somehow distinctive.

PARIS, March 20 -- Charles de Gaulle saw his successor as President, Georges Pompidou, as a man with a practical, prudent and reserved turn of mind.

GEORGE ECKMAN reports from Tokyo that the Phoenix, a bird out of mythology, will dominate the design of a 150-yen definitive stamp from Japan on March 29. Observing that Japan's stamp design committee "exercises a sense of shibui -- good taste in the restrained and cultured manner of old tradition,"

The fate of the controversial Harbour Village housing project in the Paerdegat Basin section of Brooklyn moves closer to resolution this week when the Board of Estimate is expected to vote on the 904-unit, $32-million plan at its meeting Thursday.

Urging their supporters at a rally here yesterday not to be "distracted" by their indictment in a kidnapping-bombing plot, two members of the "Harrisburg Six" and two of their alleged co-conspirators pleaded for emphasis on what they regarded as the main issues -- ending the war in Indochina and what they call repression in the United States.

Chi Cheng, the Taiwan sprinter who broke or equaled world records nine times in 1970, has been chosen to receive the annual Tanqueray Sports Achievement Award. She will receive the award, a silver plaque, at a luncheon Tuesday at Gallagher's Restaurant on West 52d Street.
MINEOLA, L. I., March 20 -A proposal to submit an offtrack betting system in Nassau County to the voters in a referendum is being viewed with caution here.
The sharp rise in lumber and plywood prices that has been under way since early this year is causing deep concern in the Nixon Administration.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., March 20 -- Boston University, sparked by Capt. Steve Stirling's two goals, shed its bridesmaid role tonight by beating Minnesota, 4-2, to win the National Collegiate hockey championship.

MONTREAL, March 16 -- Although Paul Rose, the first of the Quebec separatist revolutionaries to be tried, has been convicted and sentenced to life imprisonment, the civil ordeal of Canada's largest city following the terrorist kidnappings and murder five months ago is far from over.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 20 -- The United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France are still far from agreement on the issues of international guarantees and peacekeeping forces in the Middle East, according to informed sources.

Despite stay-at-home weather, thousands of people in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut earned 30 cents to $105.98 apiece yesterday for taking discarded bottles and aluminums cans to collection centers.

NAIROBI, Kenya, March 20 (AP) -- Drought in areas of Kenya has placed more than 140,000 persons on famine relief and abetted the spread of cholera. Twenty persons died of the disease in one recent week.
BRILLIANT color, unusual blooms and dramatic foliage are abundant when tender bulbs, tubers and rhizomes perform well in northern gardens. Some prefer shade; others full sun.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 20 (AP) -- Jim Grant struck out Leron Lee with two runners aboard to preserve a 4-3 exhibition baseball victory today for the Pittsburgh Pirates over the St. Louis Cards.

We agree generally with John Canaday's "A Revolutionary Way to See Guatemala" (Travel section, Feb. 14) and were sorry we didn't spend our originally planned two-night stay at Tikal instead of the one we had.

Conditions on the West Side of midtown Manhattan are for the most part, getting worse or staying the same, in the estimation of businessmen responding to a survey undertaken by the West Side Association of Commerce.

CAIRO, March 20 -- The Soviet Union has signed an economic agreement with the Egyptian Government involving more than $400-million, the Cairo press has reported.

WASHINGTON -- The economy is emerging from the recession of 1970 much more slowly than the Administration, and most private forecasters, had hoped or expected. And with each passing day the Administration's target of a Gross National Product of $1,065-billion this year seems less likely to be attained.

ROCHESTER, Mich., March 20 (AP) -- Top-seeded Mrs. Billie Jean King played a strong net game to wear down Britain's Mrs. Ann Jones and the No. 2 seeded player, Rosemary Casals, defeated Mrs. Mary Ann Curtis of St. Louis in the semifinals of the K-Mart invitation tennis tournament today.
Should a college student be deprived of a possible national collegiate pistol-shooting championship because he happens to be a policeman?
Community leaders of the East Bronx have lodged a strong protest against the dismissal of the director and four staff members of a neighborhood methadone clinic.
FORT BENNING, Ga., March 20 (AP) -- First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. said today that if he is acquitted he will go on a worldwide tour, delivering anti-war lectures.

HOUSTON, March 20 -- At Grenada, Miss., in the summer of 1966, Stokely Carmichael, the bushy-haired, overalls-clad, 25-year-old head of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, gave a new direction to the Negro civil rights movement in the United States with his "black power" speech.

A MOVIE that appears suddenly, without much advance publicity, surrounded by rumors of disastrous, outraged preview reactions, usually has something going for it. There may be exceptions to this perverse rule, but interesting, important films like "Performance," "Burn!" "Pretty Poison," and Billy Wilder's "Kiss Me, Stupid" had all been written off before they opened, and never had a chance to find their audience.

ONE out of 10 babies is born difficult. The difficult babies are the red-faced infants whose howling wakes the other newborns in the hospital nursery. They're the babies who twist and scream when their faces are washed. Who spit out new foods. Who'd rather cry than sleep -- or so it seems to their harassed parents, who are often not only bewildered by these cantankerous infants but deeply anxious, even guilty.
DACCA, Pakistan -- "If you are united, there is no power on earth which can prevent you from getting Pakistan."

ADEN, Southern Yemen, March 20 -- The neighboring Republic of Yemen, a country emerging from the Middle Ages, has just elected the first members of her new Consultative Assembly, or parliament. The election of representatives for the twin capitals of Sana and Taiz and the port of Hodeida on the Red Sea marks a huge change in a country that for centuries had been under the absolute theocratic rule of imams.

EATING in Paris, as described by some gourmets, seems to be the most expensive dining in the world. Many an American, contemplating a trip to Paris, will say, "How can the Parisians afford to eat in a restaurant?" The answer is that American travelers, even learned and sophisticated ones, rarely if ever find the eating places that average French citizens cherish for themselves.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla. March 20 -- John Miller of San Francisco carded a three-underpar 69 in a howling wind today and tied Hal Underwood for the lead after three rounds in the $125,000 Greater Jacksonville open tournament. Their totals were 210.

WHITE PLAINS, March 20 -- Two housing studies released this week by the County Department of Planning show Westchester to be a highly mobile society, in which 38 per cent of low-income families and 28 per cent of middle-income families have moved within the last three years.

ANKARA -- The Turkish brand of parliamentary democracy, a young and delicate plant, was saved from being uprooted last week. A political crisis that had culminated in the forced resignation of Premier Suleyman Demirel appeared to have abated with the naming of a successor.

TWO new artificial soil "recipes" for growing tropical foilage plants have been developed at the N.Y. State College of Agriculture at Cornell University. Though developed for commercial plant growers, the mixes can be adapted for homeowner use.

NORTH BERGEN, N. J. -- Outside, red neon lights blink "Embassy" on the white marquee above the Bergenline Avenue storefronts. Once it was a movie theater, but now it advertises seven bingo dates each week. And about once a month there's a boxing show.

WASHINGTON -- Instead of old and new Nixons, there are now said to be two Nixons, the public and the private -- and maybe even a third Nixon. It is the private President, we are told, who has been finally coaxed and encouraged to show himself so elaborately in public.

PETER MENNIN leaned back in his chair and said: "I could never by nature be a successful pessimist." The statement sounded both true and characteristic of the composer who is also president of the Juilliard School. It was made during a conversation in his office recently, when he was discussing his Sinfonia, which will be given its New York premiere by the New York Philharmonic this week under the direction of Stanislaw Skrowaczewski.

Blades is a British percussionist who lives, breathes, eats and sleeps percussion, loves percussion and, the guess is, talks about nothing but percussion.

Ruckelshaus has been watched with a critical eye since he took command of the new Environmental Protection Agency nearly four months ago. There were three reasons for this special interest.

ATLANTA, March 21 -- The world champion Dallas Aces showed world championship form in winning the Vanderbilt Cup knockout team championship for the first time here last night. Bill Eisenberg, Bob Goldman, Bob Hamman, Jim Jacoby, Mike Lawrence and Bob Wolff, under the nonplaying captaincy of Ira Corn, won the final match against strong opposition by 156 international match points, the largest margin ever in a national knockout final.
