TRENTON, March 22 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that the state's rarely used criminal law against fornication could not be used o prosecute unwed parents seeking welfare assistance for their illegitimate children.

Controller Abraham D. Beame reported yesterday that the final audit by his office found that the Board of Education's current budget deficit was $29.2-million, or $7-million under the board's previous revised estimate.
ALBANY, March 22 -- Unemployment throughout the state rose to 5.8 per cent last month, up two-tenths of a percentage point above the January figure.

General Mills, Inc., a leading producer of packaged consumer foods which has expanded into non-food product lines, reported yesterday slightly higher sales and earnings for the third fiscal quarter, ended Feb. 28.
The Ford Foundation is spending nearly a quarter of a million dollars to find out how television is affecting the environment.
In active trading, plywood-futures prices bounced back on the Chicago Board of Trade after dropping on Friday.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- President Nixon said tonight that the South Vietnamese drive in Laos "has made considerable progress" thus far toward the goals of insuring United States withdrawals from Vietnam, reducing the threat to the American forces still there and developing the ability of Saigon's army to defend itself.
With Ron Turcotte riding to his third triumph on the program, Here Comes Trouble carried the colors of Anne Randazzo to a convincing success in the feature seventh event at Aqueduct yesterday.

Two British officials asked Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally Jr. yesterday for a guarantee to repay British outlays for a Rolls-Royce jet engine if the Lockheed L-1011 airbus eventually fell by the wayside, according to reliable industry sources. They were said to have been turned down.

PARIS, March 22 -- The Ministry of the Interior reported today that the "great losers" of the municipal elections completed yesterday were those groups in the middle that tried to maintain their independence of both the Gaullists and the Communists.
When Frederic Waldman and his Musica Aeterna Orchestra and Chorus revived the Dvorak Requiem at Carnegie Hall in 1964, the performance was its first appearance in New York in more than 60 years.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Final Census Bureau figures for metropolitan areas confirmed today the preliminary finding that metropolitan areas grew far faster than central cities during the sixties.
The City University, in the first year of a new program, has designated 27 internationally known American, British and Japanese scholars as Distinguished Professors.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- The Supreme Court declined today to consider whether mutual-fund investors have a right to bring personal lawsuits against funds and their management.
Ira Nerken is proving again that one lone person with the proper spark and drive can get the ball rolling in this country.
Mr. and Mrs. Anibal Martinez and their six small children vacated three seedy rooms at the Kimberly Hotel yesterday and set up house in a freshly painted five-room apartment in the South Bronx.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, March 23 -- North Vietnamese soldiers carrying satchel charges broke into Khesanh today behind a heavy artillery barrage, but were driven out with heavy losses, the United States command said.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to consider if the Constitution bars Indiana officials from recounting the votes in the disputed election of Senator Vance Hartke over former Representative Richard L. Roudebush.
BERKELEY, Calif., March 22 -- Dr. Roger W. Heyns said today that budget cuts were spoiling the educational opportunities for students at the Berkeley campus of the University of California.

M. F. Jamali's March 16 letter seems to have been written in ignorance of "2,000 years" of recorded (and thus not subject to modification) history. Mr. Jamali was a participant in a council for internationalization of Jerusalem (1950). Perhaps he can explain why, for seventeen years thereafter, it remained entirely Jordanian, far from international.

MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, March 22 -- Achieving an incredible 20-knot speed on the final Caribbean leg, Windward Passage sailed across the finish line first in the 811-mile Miami to Montego Bay Yacht Race. Her elapsed time clipped more than 30 hours off her own record for the event.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Treasury bill rates advanced at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.
The 1971 convention and exhibition of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers opened yesterday as planned but not as usual.
ATHENS -- I spent this New Year's Eve planting bombs at three American targets in Athens.

WASHINGTON -- "You just can't get good help like you used to," a Louisville matron complained. "You have to stand over them all the time. And they won't do any hard work like scrubbing floors with a rag and soap."

WASHINGTON, March 22 (UPI) -- The White House said today that President Nixon would meet Thursday with 12 Negro members of the House -- a meeting the so-called "black caucus" has been seeking for nearly a year.

ALBANY, March 22 -- Community School District 7, composed of 23 schools with 30,000 pupils in the South Bronx, has been selected by the State Education Department for participation in a pilot program in the redesign of education.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- President Nixon said tonight that segregation in the nation's suburb was caused by economic problems rather than racial problems and that, as long as this was true, the Government would not take steps to alter the situation.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The long-dormant House Foreign Affairs Committee, which has tended to be an acquiescent partner to the executive branch, is staking out a more active, independent role in the formulation of foreign policy.

I'm all for the Irish, God bless them. And if we must have a parade, surely St. Patrick's is a worthy name to honor. But why do we close schools and turn children loose in Central Park and elsewhere to raise Cain, get drunk and terrorize the neighborhood? [Editorial March 19.]
WASHINGTON, MARCH 22 (Reuters) -- The State Department today declined to rule out the possibility that Secretary of State William P. Rogers might visit Israel and Arab capitals next month.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court today granted a hearing to the New York State Superintendent of Insurance, who has been trying to sue five banks over stock transaction of the Manhattan Casualty Company, now in liquidation. The court will hear the case next fall or winter and decide it by written opinion.

The Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation filed suit yesterday against a group of dissident stockholders who launched a proxy fight for control two weeks ago, charging them with making "false, misleading, incomplete and inaccurate" statements to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The Federal Government yesterday agreed to guarantee up to $6-million of trustee certificates for the bankrupt Central Railroad of New Jersey. With this assurance of working funds, the trustee, R. D. Timpany, filed with the Federal District Court in Newark a plan showing how he believes the road must be restructured to make it a viable operation.
A $2.5-million auto crash award was cut to $1-million in Federal Court yesterday.
The problem with Presidential news conferences is that there is no confrontation between the Administration and the news media over the facts concerning Vietnam or anything else.

Art may be long, but ballet history is surprisingly short. Over the past weekend -- I saw it on Friday night -- the City Center Joffrey Ballet revived Frederick Ashton's "Facade" at the New York City Center. Although "Facade" is regarded as a modern ballet, it is going to be 40 years old at the end of this week.
E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. Inc., announced yesterday that it planned to spend more than $300-million over the next three years on air-and water-pollution control in the United States.
Wall Street analysts have been saying for some time now that the stock market needs to pause and digest its spectacular gains of recent months.
The Gray Sheet is out with its annual review and forecast for the computer industry.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- President Nixon's revenue-sharing proposal received another blow today when Senator Edmund S. Muskie told about 800 mayors that as a "practical political matter" they should support instead a Federal take-over of welfare costs.
WIMBLEDON, England, March 22 (AP) -- The All-England Tennis Club reduced prize money for the Wimbledon tournament today, but said it would pay large travel expenses to the stars competing.
ALBANY, March 22 -- A legislative commission found grave problems in the state's manpower programs today, describing the welfare work incentive program as "almost totally ineffective."

Mrs. Vince Reel says she is more introverted than extroverted prefers quiet occasions to parties, picks no fights with her husband and is teased about her new name by fellow college students at California Poly, Pomona.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (UPI) -- Vice President Agnew challenged the Columbia Broadcasting System television network today to allow him to edit personally his own critical remarks that will appear tomorrow night following the repeat showing of the documentary "The Selling of the Pentagon."

BERN, Switzerland, March 22 (UPI) -- The Soviet Union's defending world champions taught the United States how to play hockey tonight, trouncing the Americans, 10-2, in the 1971 world ice hockey championships.
The Ford Foundation announced yesterday a $285,000 grant to the Environmental Defense Fund, public interest law group that was founded by lawyers and biologists.

LOS ANGELES, March 22 -- ''This team has impressed me all season long with its poise, patience and intelligence." That was Coach John Wooden's tribute to his still-alive University of California, Los Angeles Bruins on the eve of their bid for a fifth straight National Collegiate basketball title.
A Black Panther who jumped $25,000 bail after his indictment with 13 others currently on trial, returned here voluntarily and was held without bail yesterday by Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh.

Mayor Lindsay's $880.7-million tax program was formulated in large measure by a management consulting company to which $160,000 in two contracts were let without competitive bidding or public hearing.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The National Railroad Passenger Corporation made public today the routes and schedules available to intercity train riders after May 1. The network will provide 184 trains a day connecting 114 cities around the country, or roughly half the service now available.

A Federal judge in Brooklyn declared a second mistrial yesterday in an extortion and conspiracy case involving two former Federal narcotics agents pending a ruling on whether to admit the results of lie-detector tests as evidence.

FORT BENNING, Ga., March 22 -- The story of the alleged massacre of South Vietnamese women and children in an irrigation ditch outside the hamlet of Mylai three years ago was told again today to the military jury weighing the fate of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr.
The American Stock Exchange turned in its second consecutive loss yesterday as the list declined in slower trading.
The Columbia Broadcasting System continued yesterday to announce program plans for next fall. The latest announcement covered special shows.
A 2-month-old Brooklyn baby, kidnapped from in front of a Bay Ridge drug store yesterday afternoon, was returned to his mother unharmed within 45 minutes.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (UPI) -- Using confiscated marijuana, the Government began making two million cigarettes today for use in laboratory experiments to see if smoking large amounts of "pot" can lead to cancer.
HONOLULU, March 22 (UPI) -- The students Judith Parish teaches from her "one-wagon schoolhouse" have a lot to remember.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, March 22 (AP) -- President Joaquin Balaguer accused the press of North America today of emphasizing terrorism and violence in coverage of Latin America.

HANOI, North Vietnam, March 22 (Agence France-Presse) -- A high-ranking North Vietnamese officer wrote today that the South Vietnamese forces were in the midst of a "bloody retreat," but that it was "too late" for the bulk of their troops to escape from southern Laos.

KARACHI, Pakistan, March 22 -- Urgent pressure for a settlement of differences between East and West Pakistan -- even if broad autonomy must be granted to the East -- is coming from industrialists in Karachi and Lahore, the two big manufacturing centers of Pakistan.

Paul E. Bragdon, a vice president of New York University, accepted yesterday an invitation become the 11th president of Reed College in Portland, Ore., long rated one of the top colleges in the country.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 22 -- The Protestant right wing made an unforeseen bid to take over the leadership of Northern Ireland's ruling party today but an Ulster moderate, Brian Faulkner, was favored to win the Unionist party leadership tomorrow and thus become the next Prime Minister.
The existence of a primitive form of life on Mars has been shown in laboratory experiments to be possible through a chemical process stimulated by the sun's ultraviolet radiation.
The proposed reductions in state expenditures are all directed at the poor. Governor Rockefeller's proposals are hitting the indigent and the sick, particularly the mentally ill and the retarded.

PARIS, March 22 -- New York bettors trying to beat the new triple at Roosevelt Raceway will be interested to know that a lone plunger in Marseilles won the equivalent of $200,000 on a French triplet recently at a harness track.
The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said yesterday that it would follow other producers in raising prices of carbon and alloy hot-rolled bars and semi-finished steel products, effective April 15.

VIENNA, March 22 -- Common Market negotiators have agreed to Austria's request for an across-the-board reciprocal tariff cut during the period be fore Vienqna's proposed permanent association with the European Economic Community.

DACCA, Pakistan, March 22 -- President Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan of Pakistan today postponed the National Assembly for a second time, saying that more delay is needed to resolve the crisis over East Pakistan's demands for serf-rule.
Your March 15 editorial calling for the abolition of the St. Patrick's Day parade has to take its place alongside the famous Sun editorial replying to Virginia O'Hanlon's question about Santa Claus.

LISBON, March 22 -- A Cuban Army officer captured with nationalist guerrillas in Portuguese Guinea will be tried by Lisbon's Second Military Court although the court's judges have declared that the tribunal lacks jurisdiction in the case.
Vandalism in the city's schools decreased by 10 per cent last year, reversing the upsurge of recent years, according to a report released yesterday by the Chancellor of Schools Harvey B. Scribner.

Your March 5 editorial is a clear exposition of the city's appalling fiscal problems. The most depressing part, as you point out, is that the taxpayers would gain absolutely nothing in the way of improved services in return for sharp increases in tax burdens.

WASHINGTON, March 22--Some South Vietnamese soldiers, in the retreat from Laos, have been clinging to the landing skids of American helicopters. Some have been failing to their deaths from these precarious perches, and in addition, "we just have to kick some of them off," an American pilot has reported. "We have to think about ourselves, too. You just cannot lift this bird with fifteen guys clinging to it."

Duke and North Carolina, members of the Atlantic Coast Conference, advanced last night to the semifinal round of the National Invitation Tournament during a basketball triple-header at Madison Square Garden watched by 12,347 fans.

WASHINGTON, March 22--The House Armed Services Committee gave its final approval today to a two - year continuation of the draft, but voted an increase in military pay and allowances that many Congressmen believe would permit the draft to be ended well before the two years are up.
MOSCOW, March 22 -- A prominent Soviet population specialist is arguing against proposals to abolish legal abortions as a way of raising the falling Soviet birth rate.

G. McMurtrie Godley, the United States Ambassador to Laos, has been called one of a new breed of American diplomats; men as much at home in jungle fatigues as in striped pants; men as conversant with guerrilla infiltration as with diplomatic nuances.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review a lower court decision that the Government asserts drastically upsets procedures for handling business proxy cases.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 22 -- The New York Mets crossed a linguistic frontier today when they searted a 25-day crash program in English for 15 Spanish-speaking minor leaguers in their training camp.
BOSTON, March 22 (UPI) -- Representative Louise Day Hicks, Democrat of Massachusetts, ran to a house next to a burning building and led an elderly blind man and his wife to safety.

PARIS, March 22 -- AS Western Europe and Japan struggle under a load of surplus dollars, specialists of a Western economic-cooperation agency are circulating forecasts showing that the load will remain unusually heavy through the course of this year.
The Long Island Railroad has started a five-day experiment on the feasibility of replacing its 18 bar cars with portable bar units in the regular coaches.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- A "national week of concern" for the American prisoners of war and servicemen missing in action in Indochina opened here today amid growing Congressional feeling that an alternative to President Nixon's policy on the prisoners must be found.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 22--The New York Mets won their third straight game today and the St. Louis Cardinals lost their fifth straight when the Mets scratched out a 2-1 decision in 10 innings.

R. H. Macy Co., Inc., rang up record sales and earnings in the 13-week and 26-week periods ended Jan. 30, reflecting the improved buying attitudes of consumers, particularly in December and January, according to the results issued yesterday by the big department-store chain.

Sears, Roebuck has guts. It will be bringing back that almost-forgotten art form, the live television commercial, to give added believability to the claim that its Eager 1 lawn-mower engine starts the first time almost every time.

ATHENS, March 22 -- A group of 133 prominent Greeks declared today that the suspension of political liberty and democracy in Greece, under military rule since the coup d'etat of April 21, 1967, had led "to the spiritual and political withering" of the country.
WILLIAMSBURG, Va., March 22 -- The jet set lost a promising young couple to a hill farm in Arkansas today.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (Reuters) -- Two Sprint missiles sucessfully intercepted the nose cone of an intercontinental ballistic missile over the Pacific today in the latest test of the Safeguard defense system, the Pentagon announced.

Bernardo Bertolucci, who is associated with Italy's avant - garde because of such films as "Before the Revolution," "Partner" and "The Spider's Stratagem," has at last made a very middle-class, almost conventional (in the context of his other work) movie that turns out to be one of the elegant surprises of the current New York Film Festival.

PHILADELPHIA, March 23 (UPI) -- Economists at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School of Finance and Commerce predicted today that the United States economy would approach the two-trillion - dollar level by 1980, almost double the one-trillion mark it passed this year.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Tuesday, March 23 -- Heavy fighting was reported just north of the royal capital of Luang Prabang yesterday.
Two Washington Irving High School girls described by the police as "major suppliers" of heroin were arrested in a pizza shop across from the school yesterday morning.

WESTBURY, L.I., March 22 -- Competition to determine the world champion harness-racing driver, which was introduced last year, will begin at Roosevelt Raceway the night of May 3 and wind up at Philadelphia's Liberty Bell Park on May 15.
WASHINGTON, March 22--The Federal Government has informed all 50 states that it regards their laws governing construction wages on Government projects as no longer in effect.

Prime Minister Heath has reaffirmed British policy and responsibility for Northern Ireland in a clear manner that may yet bring the warring factions into contact with reality. The statement was overdue but Stormont politicians and Belfast terrorists can have no doubt about its meaning.
On the eve of the richest tournament in their new professional tour, leading women tennis players will meet tonight to discuss plans, progress and problems.

ROME, March 22 (Reuters) -- The Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano sharply criticized Israel today for policies that it said were aimed at achieving virtual sovereignty over the entire city of Jerusalem

ROME, March 22 -- Italian authorities said today they were pressing criminal charges against two officials of the Boston Museum of Fine Arts in an effort to retrieve a painting attributed to Raphael that they alleged was smuggled out of this country in 1969.

Burton Sapiro and John Bagatta have been appointed senior vice presidents of the Macy's New York division of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., effective May 1. Mr. Sapiro, merchandise vice president for junior wear, misses' and women's dresses, will be senior vice president' in charge of merchandising women's, misses' and junior better and budget ready to wear apparel, intimate apparel, accessories, footwear, millinery and fashion fabrics.
Breaking longstanding tradition, the International Game Fish Association last month moved to drop its regulation prohibiting the use of gang (double or treble) hooks on plugs.
WHEATON, Ill., March 22 (UPI) -- Rod Laver withdrew today from the $50,000 Sportface international tennis championship because of a back injury.
Thousands of retail buyers of men's sportswear are in New York this week with less open-to-buy funds available but high hopes for business in 1971.

The General Accounting Office's allegations of serious abuses in allocating the Administration's special school desegregation funds emphasize the need for effective guidelines for these vital appropriations.
LONDON, March 22 -- Prime Minister Heath said today that "urban guerrilla warfare" was threatening Northern Ireland and stressed that Britain had the "ultimate authority" to deal with terrorists.

The 12 male jurors in the murder and manslaughter trial of Mrs. Alice Crimmins ex-examined exhibits yesterday that included maps, drawings and 17 photographs of the bodies of her two children, whom she is alleged to have killed.

Negotiations designed to facilitate the New York filming of Mario Puzo's "The Godfather" have caused something of a corporate rift between Paramount Pictures and its parent company, Gulf Western Industries.

Harlem's Intermediate School 201 complex -- the pioneer experiment in community control of schools -- is beset with growing division and unrest among some of those who demanded its creation five years ago.

ATLANTA, March 22 -- The Open Pair Championship that ended the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here last night resulted in a tie, a rare event. Sharing the title with a score of 854 1/2 match points were Barry Crane of Los Angeles, the world's leading master-point holder, and Dr. John Fisher of Dallas, and a Midwest couple, Vince and Joan Remey of Southfield, Mich.
MIAMI, March 22 -- Three thieves invaded the Vizcaya Museum early today and made off with a valuable collection of historic silver.

Katy Industries, Inc., announced yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire the Cenac Towing Company, Inc., and its related companies through an exchange of stock valued at $12-million to $14-million. Katy said it was en-I 'gaged in final negotiations for the acquisition, The Cenac companies are based in Houma,[ La., where Katy[ has its main iron-[ works subsidiary. 1 The Genac-related] concerns involved are the Louisiana Mud Company, Inc.;
WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- President Nixon sent Congress today a juvenile delinquency report urging "a new national program strategy" to deal with a rise in crime among the nation's young people.
A lawyer who acted as a judge at city parking violation hearings was arrested yesterday on charges of attempting to fix a speeding case for a client by offering $750 to "third parties."
The special impasse panel in the police, fire and sanitation cases worked late yesterday preparing recommendations for settling the long-drawn-out disputes.

WASHINGTON, March 22--Faced with rising prices, dwindling support from home and merchants who are sometimes not above taking advantage of them, college students across the country are turning increasingly to independent buying cooperatives in an effort to stretch each dollar as far as possible.
The New York Times has entered the educational audio tape cassette field, it was announced by Karl Horwitz, manager of the Library Services Division.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., March 22 -- Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso announced today that the county's $27-million Coliseum at Mitchel Field would open April 1, 1972 for major sports events.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- The Food and Drug Administration ordered today a phased recall of contaminated intravenous fluids that have been linked to 350 cases of hospital blood infection.

BRUSSELS, March 22 -- With angry farmers demonstrating all over Europe and preparing a protest march on Brussels for tomorrow, the six European Economic Community Agriculture Ministers; met here today to set new prices for a range of products guaranteed under the European farm policy.
SAIGON, March 23 -- United States fighters and bombers struck at missile sites inside North Vietnam yesterday for the second consecutive day as South Vietnamese troops retreating from Laos continued

HUNTINGTON TOWNSHIP, L. I., March 22 -- More than 1,000 persons paid $125 a plate tonight to attend a testimonial dinner for Joseph A. Colombo Sr., who has been called a Mafia leader by both a Senate investigating committee and the Justice Department.

A professor at the University of the Americas in Mexico City believes designs on a stone recently placed on display at the National Museum of Mexico indicate contact between Mediterranean people and the Maya of Mexico as early as 700 A.D.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 22 -- While girls in the briefest of bikinis sunned themselves on the beach outside, Pete Rozelle sat dressed in a business suit in a room at the expensive Breakers Hotel today and discussed the adverse effect the Spencer Haywood case could have on pro football.

The region around Maine's Penobscot Bay, one of the last strongholds of the independent Yankee farmer-fisherman, is largely unspoiled land where wooded hills plunge to the rugged, granite shores of an island-studded sea. The bay, Robert P. T. Coffin once wrote, has "a loveliness as fresh as the morning of Creation."
The use of trailers as temporary relocation homes was approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

MOSCOW, March 22 -- The Soviet Communist party Central Committee gave formal approval today to the main reports that the party leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, and Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin will deliver to the 24th party congress, which begins a week from tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Diary of a spring (excerpted):

These remarks by former Secretary of State Dean Rusk are excerpted from a conversation he held last month with Georgia broadcasters at the University of Georgia's School of Journalism. The conversations were broadcast by WSB in Atlanta; this is the second of two articles derived from the broadcast. Mr. Rusk is now Professor of International Law at the University of Georgia.

LONDON, March 22 -- One member from each of the two British teams that have been negotiating for the rescue of the Lockheed Tristar aircraft and its Rolls-Royce engine reported to the British Government today on Lockheed's counteroffer.
The credit markets moved confidently toward still lower interest rates yesterday as investment bankers set the terms on more than $1.1-billion of bonds scheduled for sale today.

Al McGuire, a tough-minded disciplinarian who guided Marquette to its first undefeated regular season in history, was voted college basketball's coach of the year in the United Press International poll yesterday.

ST. PAUL, March 22 -- Charles A. Lindbergh, the aviator and conservationist, told a conservation group here tonight that the speed of proposed supersonic planes did not justify the perils of upper atmospheric pollution and the disturbance caused by the sonic boom.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 22 -- An 11th-inning home run to right field by the eighth Detroit pinch-hitter of the game, Kevin Collins, gave the Tigers a 5-4 victory over the Yankees today. It was the former Met's first hit in 17 trips to the plate.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 22 -- Baseball has seen a steady increase in the number of switch-hitting batsmen of recent years. Almost without exception they have been natural right-handed hitters with a distaste for curved balls. So they crossed to the other side of the plate and swung lefty whenever the situation suggested the wisdom of such action.
What the wheel did for transportation, 48-year-old Israel Robert Smuts hopes his latest invention will do for spaghetti.
The Board of Higher Education last night approved a request for $2.7-million for the purchase of the site and building of the newly formed Med-gar Evers College.

Soviet military aid to Communist and underdeveloped countries amounted to more than $19-billion in the years from 1955 to 1970, according to authoritative sources in the United States and Allied governments.

Reports of attempted bribes, evictions and other means of pressure to force tenants to yield apartments were related to the City Council Housing Committee yesterday by speakers discussing the conversion of rental apartment houses to cooperatives or condominiums.
WELLESLEY, Mass., March 22 -- A special commission at Wellesley College has urged that the 96-year-old women's college accept a limited number of male students on an experimental basis.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- The Supreme court today allowed Connecticut to extend aid to parochial schools in the state.

The First Boston Corporation in 1970 headed the list of leading investment.banking syndicate managers for the eighth year in a row, data published by the Investment Dealers' Digest showed yes. terday.

KHESANH, South Vietnam, March 22 -- A commanding general said today he did not plan to take disciplinary action against 53 of his men who refused an order to move forward to secure a damaged helicopter and their commanding officer's armored vehicle.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., March 22 (AP) -- Skidmore College, with an exclusively female enrollment since its inception 60 years ago, will admitt male students beginning with the fall term.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The I.Q. and grade equivalency scores by which most public schools attempt to measure student potential and performance were attacked as "psychological and statistical monstrosities" here today by one of the country's foremost authorities on testing.
Plans for 50 new day-care centers to accommodate 5,000 children in the South Bronx, Harlem and Central Brooklyn in the next two years were announced yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.

WASHINGTON, March 22! (AP)--The space agency plans to ask Congress for $100-million over the next four years to develop an exprimental jet short-take-off-and-landing re- search plane. George M. Low, acting head of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, gave the figure to a House appropmations subcommittee today in response to a question from the subcommittee chairman, Representative Edward P. Boland, Democrat of Massachusetts.

The National Credit Office, Dun Bradstreet division that evaluates issuers of commercial paper, withdrew yesterday its "prime" rating from such unsecured corporate notes sold by the Chrysler Corporation and two of its subsidiaries -- the Chrysler Financial Corporation and Chrysler Credit Canada, Ltd. No new rating was substituted.
Deputy Mayor Richard R. Aurelio last night assailed Controller Abraham D. Beame, "clubhouse politicians," The Daily News and other critics of Mayor Lindsay "who enjoy dumping on the city."

Rogers C. B. Morton, the new Secretary of the Interior, has set out to get a firmer administrative grip on his huge department. The planned appointment as Under Secretary of Dr. James R. Schlesinger, an expert on systems analysis, and of two new Assistant Secretaries with broad administrative responsibilities should strengthen Mr. Morton's control. The choice of an Under Secretary is particularly significant in the light of the Nixon Administration's peculiar treatment of this office.

Last September, two women tennis players, Ceci Martinez and Esme Emanuel, passed out questionnaires at the United States open championships to determine whether people would pay to see women play tennis.

BOGOTA, Colombia -- When the indomitable Bolivar first freed this great country from Spain it included, in addition to Colombia, Venezuela, Ecuador and Panama. The famous Liberator settled into what is still the presidential palace, a jewel of eighteenth-century Spanish architecture that even now delightedly maintains the bedroom from which Bolivar escaped would-be assassins while his mistress held them at bay.

The work of Chris Wilmarth at the Paula Cooper Gallery, 96 Prince Street, is defined as "glass sculpture." Although the definition may be applicable for practical and categorical purposes, the sculpture is still closer in feeling and conception to spatial drawing in glass.

A disappointing showing by President Nixon in the New York audience popularity ratings and a flap over granting equal time to William Magruder, Director of Supersonic Transport Development for the Department of Defense, enlivened yesterday's business hours for the American Broadcasting Company. The President, in an exclusive interview Monday night with Howard K. Smith, attracted only an 11 per cent share of the available audience in the metropolitan area.

Roger Penske, manager of the Sunoco-Ferrari team that ran sixth in Saturday's 12-hour endurance race at Sebring, is appealing what he considers an insufficient penalty against the fifth-place Gulf-Porsche.
TRENTON, March 23 -- A redistricting of New Jersey for this year's State Senate and Assembly elections was announced early this morning by the bipartisan Legislative Reapportionment Commission.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The constitutional amendment to give 18-year-olds the right to vote in all elections appears likely to win approval in enough state legislatures to take effect by the 1972 elections.
BUENOS AIRES, March 23 -- The three commanders of the Argentine armed forces assumed control of the Government as a junta today after deposing Gen. Roberto Marcelo Levingston as President.

A police detective who is one of the key prosecution witnesses in the murder and manslaughter trial of Mrs. Alice Crimmins conceded under cross-examination yesterday that he never included in his official reports any reference to several pieces of evidence he allegedly saw in the two dead children's bedroom.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 23 -- Tom Egan, a third-string catcher with a career major league batting average of .194, accumulated four extra-base hits today to lead the Chicago White Sox to a 4-3 victory over the New York Yankees.
The bond market yesterday began flirting with the low interest rates that proved so ephemeral a month ago.

Jonathan Purvin, a young pianist with strong, facile fingers and a dead-serious approach to music, played what amounted to two recitals at the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium on Monday night.

F. I. duPont, Glore Forgan Co., one of the nation's largest brokerage firms, has been rescued from the brink of collapse once again through another refinancing involving H. Ross Perot, the Texas computer millionaire.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The Supreme Court declared today that it lacked the time and the expertise to play a major role in antipollution litigation.

WILTON, Conn., March 23 -- Mrs. Suzanne Cameron Black, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Cameron of Greenwich, was married here yesterday to Herbert Dietrich Schutz, a vice president of Time Inc., and president of its subsidiary, the New York Graphic Society, Ltd.

John (Whack) Hyder, the Georgia Tech basketball coach, was not happy with the way his Engineers played in the first round of the National Invitation Tournament here Saturday night against La Salle, even though they won.

BRUSSELS, March 23 -- Eighty thousand Western European farmers swarmed into Brussels today in a violent protest demanding increased prices for their produce. Automobiles were burned, street signs torn up and windows broken.

WINTER HAVEN, Fla., March 23 -- The New York Mets were extended to extra innings today for the second straight time, but again came out on top with a 5-4 victory over the Boston Red Sox that stretched their winning streak to four games.

FREETOWN, Sierra Leone March 23 (AP) -- Senior army officers arrested their commander in this West African nation tonight, hours after he announced the seizure of power from the Prime Minister, Siaka P. Stevens.
Stock prices slipped a bit further yesterday as the second trading day of spring continued Monday's lackadaisical movement.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Senator J. W. Fulbright came to the defense of Secretary of State William P. Rogers today against Senate critics who charged that the Secretary was undermining Israeli interests in a Middle East settlement.

ALBANY, March 23 -- More than 2,000 residents of moderate-income housing in New York City called upon legislators here today to enact legislation that would keep rents and housing costs within limits they could afford.

The Arab nations intend to move from being just producers of oil to participation in the entire spectrum of the world petroleum industry, A. M. Suhail Sadawi, Secretary General of the Organization of Arab Petroleum Exporting Countries, said yesterday.

What is good and bad in Respighi's music is good and bad in his opera "Belfagor," which was given its American premiere, in concert form, by the Opera Orchestra of New York in Tully Hall on Monday night. The composer's gift for highly colored, sensual orchestral effects and his ability to write equally sensual vocal lines make this work luscious to hear.
ALBANY, March 23 -- Governor Rockefeller and Republican legislative leaders met for four hours today in an attempt to resolve an impasse over the Governor's $8.45-billion budget.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Scene I. The library of the White House. The President and Howard K. Smith of A.B.C. talking before the TV cameras sitting under a portrait of General Washington.
Soybean and wheat futures prices advanced rather sharply shortly after the opening of trading on the Chicago Board of trade yesterday but profit taking trimmed the gains before the session ended.
The Atlanta Hawks are the first obstacle on the path the New York Knickerbockers must traverse to win a second straight National Basketball Association title. And it could be a big obstacle.
" Anything can win this one," the trainer of Lord Pino said hopefully in the paddock before yesterday's second race at Aqueduct.

A letter carried by Pony Express in 1860, its envelope bearing the Wells Fargo adhesive stamp, and a 1918 airmail stamp on which the airplane was printed flying upside down were among 261 lots of rare stamps that brought a total of $700,690 at auction here last night.

A permit requiring "extensive protections and valuable compensations for Central Park" was granted yesterday to the Transit Authority for the construction of new Queens-Manhattan subway lines in the southern end of Central Park.
A state Senator who has been one of the most outspoken critics of using retarded children in hepatitis research said yesterday he was now persuaded that the work was being properly conducted.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The Army Corps of Engineers would be transferred to the proposed Department of Natural Resources under an executive reorganization bill that will be released by the White House on Thursday, Nixon Administration sources said today.

MOSCOW, March 23 -- The Soviet Union announced today that its foreign trade with Communist China fell to a new low last year but that the two countries had agreed to triple their trade this year, apparently as part of an effort to have more normal governmental relations.

TOKYO, March 23 -- Three youthful followers of the novelist Yukio Mishima went on trial here today on five charges -- including the unusual one of "murder by request" -- in connection with his ritual suicide last November.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Attorney General John N. Mitchell issued an urgent plea to the press today not to publish information from files stolen earlier this month from the Federal Bureau of Investigation's office in Media, Pa.

A policeman is seriously injured in a gunfight that apparently started as part of a family argument. A deranged sniper fires at passing traffic. A 16-year-old boy attempts to hijack an airliner at gun point.
SEATTLE, March 23 -- Joseph L. Alioto, the Mayor of San Francisco, was indicted today under a Federal statute against interstate racketeering.
The magic number is 4225B. There are other numbers being played, too: 6053, 6476 and 4452, but 4225B is given the best odds for coming up in the legislative roulette.
MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, B. W. I., March 23 -- Fourteen boats had completed the 811-mile course in the Miami-Montego Bay yacht race at nightfall today. Seventeen were still at sea in diminishing winds.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 23 -- The allied thrust against Communist supply lines, now drawing to a close, may have achieved some limited military success and killed thousands of the enemy, but in political propaganda terms Hanoi seems to have won the day.

Dale Wasserman's play, "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest," was first given in 1963 on Broadway, where as a flier it proved a lame duck. It has now been revived, and I understand in part rewritten. Last night it opened at the Mercer-Hansberry Theater.

Johnny Neumann of the University of Mississippi, a sophomore who was the leading scorer in college basketball this season, signed yesterday with the Memphis Pros of the American Basketball Association. Neumann, a 6-foot-6 1/2-inch guard, averaged 40 points a game.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- A key Republican Senator said today that he did not believe President Nixon's chosen candidate would be nominated to the important post of Under Secretary of the Interior.
ROME, March 23 -- The new travel season's first tourists, already numerous, were warned today that they would have a hard time getting a cup of coffee or a meal tomorrow.
ALBANY, March 23 -- Governor Rockefeller proposed substantial reductions in state penalties for marijuana offenses today, including dropping the criminal stigma for minor first offenses.

The words "Mafia" and "Cosa Nostra" will not be heard on the American Broadcasting Company's television series "The F.B.I." when that program begins its new season in September, the Italian-American Civil Rights League said yesterday.

At the age of 35, Richard Hunt can look back on an astonishingly productive and successful career as both a sculptor and graphic artist. The retrospective exhibition of his work opening tomorrow at the Museum of Modern Art contains about 50 sculptures and a selection of drawings and prints dating from 1956.
Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner yesterday promised "a tightening up" of school security in an effort to curb violence by intruders and disruptive students.
Prices closed higher yesterday on the London Stock Exchange, with leading industrial issues firmer, indicating a lack of sellers.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- A proposed constitutional amendment to lower the voting age to 18 in all elections cleared Congress today after little more than token opposition.

Natale Marcone, president of the Italian-American Civil Rights League, was among four persons indicted yesterday on charges stemming from a fracas with the police when the league picketed the offices of The Staten Island Advance last month.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The Defense Department acknowledged today that South Vietnamese troops might have stayed longer in Laos if the Communists had not reacted as strongly as they did to the attacks on their vital supply line.

WESTBURY, L. I., March 23 -- Del Insko, having driven Redmond Lane and Tired to victory three times each in the local preliminaries of the Yonkers-Roosevelt Hopeful Pacing Series elected to handle Redmond Lane in tomorrow night's $17,500 final of the competition for 3-year-olds.
GATESHEAD, England, March 4 -- The Hebrew chants begin shortly after dawn on Bewick Road, a meandering lane of old redbrick houses in this northern industrial community.
KEENE, N. Y. -- Roland Smith, who lives in an area beautiful enough to attract visitors from around the world, exists in the kind of poverty that most people associate with city slums.

BERNE, March 23 (AP) -- Finland scored the first four goals and downed the United States, 7-4, today in the world ice hockey championship. Gary Gambucci scored two goals for the Americans.

Saul, outgoing president of the American Stock Exchange, told the exchange's members at its annual meeting yesterday that "in response to questions," he again wanted to make it clear that the Amex and the New York Stock Exchange "are definitely not considering merging, but only consolidating certain facilities to better serve the public and their memberships."

They are as much a part of the job as is the parlor in their hotel suites or the front seat in the player bus or a private office in the clubhouse. Yet there are 23 somewhat envious big-league managers who are absolutely convinced that Earl Weaver, the manager of the world champion Baltimore Orioles, has no problems at all. That's manifestly ridiculous.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Republicans moved on several fronts today to counter Democratic pressure for speedy approval of legislation to limiting spending in political campaigns.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (UPI) -- The Senate Government Operations Committee said today that if disorder, riotous conduct and violence by students were "carried repeatedly to the extremes which the nation has seen during the past several years, they will eventually destroy many of our major educational institutions."

ALBANY, March 23 -- Senate Majority Leader Earl W. Brydges today ordered a special legislative committee to determine whether what he termed "skyrocketing" public employe retirement benefits should be regulated by a bipartisan pension commission.

A profitable fourth quarter enabled the Allied Stores Corporation to report yesterday earnings of $14,801,412, or $1.71 a share, for the fiscal year ended Jan. 31. This, however, was sharply lower than the previous year's net of $22,163,288, or $2.63 a share.
