WASHINGTON, March 24 -- If you are the parent of a 13-year-old child or even an 18-year-old brute with biceps like Max Baer, you have doubtless wondered why your telephone keeps ringing. "That is the 200th time it has rung today," you have cried aloud to an indifferent heaven. "What can they possibly have to talk about?"

George W. Mitchell, a member of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, declared yesterday that the volume of checks now being written was becoming increasingly difficult to handle, and would become "economically unmanageable" in the next 10 years under the present system.

One of the very few people who can be considered in world class both as player and writer is B. Jay Becker of New York. In almost four decades at the top of the tournament tree, he has won two world titles and a host of national ones.
The credit markets' trend toward higher prices and lower interest rates that got under way on March 9 faltered yesterday.

ALBANY, March 24 -- State Senator Roy M. Goodman charged yesterday that conditions at Manhattan State Mental Hospital on Wards Island were "an outrageous disgrace," with inadequate staffing, a serious shortage of medical equipment and generally filthy conditions.
A free "Safari to Harlem" bus ride to and from performances of the Al Fann Theatrical Ensemble's production of "King Heroin" will get under way tonight.
Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor's "Let's Unite on Vietnamization" [ Op-Ed March 10] has the qualities of both a bad joke and a bad dream.
Recent snowstorms in the North Country have encouraged ski resort operators to put on added attractions.

As pleasant and accommodating a young man as ever made it to the top of his family's business, Oakleigh B. Thorne has never felt drawn to that supercharged world of achievement with its socially responsible whirl of charity balls, board meetings and fund-raising cocktail parties.

The New York and American Stock Exchanges yesterday issued their latest reports on changes in stockholdings by major stockholders, directors and officers of their listed companies. The lists include the following:
Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that he would ask the city to observe one minute of silence on Good Friday, April 9, and that he would proclaim April 28 as Prisoner of War Day.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Senior Administration officials said today that security arrangements in the Sinai Peninsula, including the status of Sharm el Sheik, the strongpoint at the southern end of the peninsula, should be negotiated by Israel and the United Arab Republic in arriving at a peace agreement.
Long after the grim-faced leaders had hurried past, a leggy blonde girl slid down off the hood of her father's Mercedes-Benz.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (UPI) -- America's infant death rate, long a cause of debate over health care for the poor, dropped to a record low in 1970, the Health. Education and Welfare Department said today.

A customer of a Bronx food store was shot and killed, and another customer and the owner critically wounded last night when three armed men attempted a holdup at the Commock Superette, at 1362 Clinton Avenue, at 10:50 P. M.

The pastor of the United Church of Christ in Newark, charged yesterday that the "church historically and hysterically has been the greatest antihomosexual force," but that "one does not have to be a heterosexual before he can be a Christian.

Despite the proliferation of all-white private schools and the probable creation of all-black public school systems in some parts of the South, desegregation for the first time is the rule rather than the exception in the region at large, according to a report made public yesterday by the Southern Regional Council in Atlanta.

WINTER HAVEN, Fla., March 24 -- The New York Yankees, who broke out champagne for finishing second last year, didn't break out anything today -- but might have been tempted after they defeated the Boston Red Sex, 9-5.

ALBANY, March 24 -- Senator Donald M. Halperin charged today that the state had been defrauding the public by labeling lottery proceeds as "a dol-ar for education" because the money had not been "segregated" specifically for education.

Commission-rate competition, traditionally forbidden by the New York Stock Exchange, has begun to materialize on Wall Street in anticipation of an April 5 deadline set by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
" Jane Eyre is a nonconformist, a rebel who comes up against the Establishment and wins out over it."

NEW HAVEN, March 24 -- Warren Kimbro, the man who has admitted firing the first shot at Alex Rackley the night he was murdered, described graphically today how Rackley was beaten and tortured by fellow Black Panthers three days before his death.

Andrew Soltis, a member of the United States students world championship team and a three-time champion of the Marshall Chess Club, led the Marshall Club championship, a 12-man round robin, after the fourth round with a score of 3 1/2-1/2.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- President Nixon told Republican diners who contributed $1.5-million to the party at a dinner here tonight that the Republicans would go into the 1972 elections with the achievement of "minimum goals -- peace and prosperity without war."
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- After weeks of internal infighting, President Nixon unveiled today a general plan for merging the Peace Corps, VISTA and seven other voluntary service programs.

Speculative Australian issues dropped sharply yesterday on the London Stock Exchange following the suspension in Sydney of Leopold Minerals, but early protective marking-down prevented any large-scale selling.
The city's public hospitals are sure to run out of cash before the fiscal year ends June 30 and will be forced to borrow to keep going.

PALM BEACH, March 24 -- When Wellington Mara, the owner of the New York Giants, received word yesterday that New Jersey was proceeding with its plans for a football stadium, he and the rest of the National Football League owners were deeply immersed in their deliberations over a Super Bowl Site.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The House Ways and Means Committee has reached tentative agreement on a comprehensive revision of the welfare system that would guarantee a $2,400 annual income for a poor family of four from Federal funds.
Corn futures and soybean prices held onto early gains, but some of the rises achieved early in the day by wheat futures were trimmed yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.
The practice of allowing more than one prosecutor to interrogate a potential defendant before a grand jury has been questioned by a State Supreme Court Justice.

PHILADELPHIA, March 24 (AP) -- Gaylord P. Harnwell resigned today as board chairman, president and chief executive of the Penn Central Company, parent concern of the financially troubled railroad. Four other directors also resigned.

Miss Judith Susan Rosenthal was married here last evening to Steven Howard Wayne Winter, whom she met at the start of her freshman year at the University of Vermont. The bridegroom was graduated from Vermont in 1969. His wife expects to receive her degree next year.
A protest over the arrest of three students earlier this week forced the closing of the Bronx High School of Science yesterday morning.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The Treasury announced late this afternoon the acceptance tenders for $2,000,395,000 of 23-day tax anticipation bills.

The RCA Corporation announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the Chunghwa Electronics Development Company, Ltd., of Taiwan for the formation of a joint company to manufacture and sell black-and-white television picture tubes. The new company will be known as Chunghwa Picture Tubes, Ltd.

A model bitten by a lion during a photographic sequence at a preview of the International Automobile Show in the New York Coliseum five years ago was awarded $500,000 damages by a State Supreme Court trial jury yesterday.
GENEVA, March 24 -- The Swiss Federal Bank Commission banned today the public offering of the two mutual funds still being sold in Switzerland by Investors Overseas Services.

Mayor Lindsay visited the city's 14th methadone center yesterday -- in the heart of the financial district -- and was told by a patient being treated for heroin addiction that the program was "lifesaver."

MIAMI, March 24 -- Tony Jacklin, the United States Open champion, is a frustrated golfer these days. But he hopes his "bad batch" of golf will end here during the $200,000 National Airlines open that starts tomorrow -- or next week or the week thereafter at the Masters in Augusta, Ga.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Copies of Federal Bureau of Investigation documents that have been mailed anonymously to several newspapers and individuals indicate that the agency is engaged in active surveillance of student, Negro and peace groups.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The mandate of Congress to the Railpax corporation was to establish and operate a basic railroad passenger service for the nation. The route system announced this week does little to answer the question whether Railpax can even come close to doing so -- whether, in fact, it is simply another step toward a foreordained death of rail passenger service in America.

Two teachers at Intermediate School 201 in Harlem were arrested yesterday afternoon when the police said they had found quantities of heroin and marijuana in a car the two said they were using to transport five children to basketball in East Harlem.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Two British ministers arrived here today for meetings tomorrow with executives of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation and Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally that could lead to a showdown on the high-stakes trans-Atlantic dispute over the Rolls-Royce RB-211 jet engine.

Before another capacity crowd of 19,500, even though it will be a weekday afternoon, the New York Knickerbockers will begin defense of their National Basketball Association title today at 2:30 P.M. at Madison Square Garden, facing the Atlanta Hawks in the opener of a four-of-seven playoff series.
The Lindsay administration is considering charging tolls on the nine Harlem River bridges as well as on the four East River bridges, Controller Abraham D. Beame said yesterday.
On Saturday evening, a New Jersey dance company will perform in a Hackensack auditorium a work created in 1947 and last danced 12 years ago. It was never seen by the man who is directing it.

Perhaps because of his background in movie-music scoring, for which he has won four Oscars, Andre Previn seems drawn to symphonic works that in the wrong hands can sound like the music that flourished back when Hollywood was really Hollywood.

Whenever Mable Grimes returns to Denver, they still talk about her hot tamales of 40 years ago, for in their day they became a local legend. She still makes them in New York for special occasions, using a handsome old copper washboiler that used to belong to her grandmother.
ALBANY, March 24 -- Acting with unusual speed, the Senate and the Assembly passed a bill today to strip the State Board of Social Welfare of its power to appoint the Commissioner of Social Services.

Mrs. Nancy Richey Gunter wore out the new gut in her racquet, Pip Jones said it was the finest exhibition of ground strokes he'd ever seen and his wife, Ann, said that if the match had been played at Wimbledon, "it would have brought the place down."
Shareholders of The New York Times yesterday approved by a margin of more than 40 to 1 the acquisition of a number of properties from Cowles Communications, Inc.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Leaders of the United Sioux Tribes of South Dakota disclosed today plans for a multimillion-dollar international travel agency designed to lure Europeans to the American West.
Nine commercial banks said yesterday they were setting up a $1-million corporation to invest in minority enterprises in the New York metropolitan area.

Oh, yes. The American Indian. Ho hum. Our guilt boxes are so full these days that there is hardly room for the biggest load in our national hertigate. Besides, Arthur Kopit piled it too high and deep in his theatrical extravaganza, "Indians"; Vine Deloria has already proved that Indians can talk for themselves (if someone will listen); and Dee Brown's history, "Bury My Heart at Wounded Knee," is climbing the best-seller list.

Of all the Verdi operas, "Un Ballo in Maschera" of 1859 occupies a special niche. In many respects it is the most songful of any. Melody follows melody in an unforced manner -- lyric, spontaneous, gorgeous melody.
A Federal judge ruled here yesterday that Local 638 of the Steamfitters Union had practiced racial discrimination here for years in maintaining a predominantly white membership.

Successive defeats by two odds-on favorites confounded the students of form at Aqueduct yesterday. The more startling failure occurred in the $32,350 Correction Handicap, the six-furlong test for fillies and mares.

ROME, March 24 -- Whenever President Nixon's special envoy to the Vatican, Henry Cabot Lodge, is about to see Pope Paul VI he dons a dark blue suit and blue necktie and does some last-minute reading on Indochina in the confidential files from Saigon, Washington and Paris.

BALTIMORE, March 24 -- Led by Hal Greer, their 34-year -old backcourt marvel, the Philadelphia 76ers opened the National Basketball Association playoffs handsomely tonight, drubbing the Baltimore Bullets, 126-112, before a crowd of 6,707 at Civic Center.
The 23d annual George Polk Memorial Awards for outstanding achievement in journalism during 1970 were presented yesterday to the winners in 12 categories at an awards luncheon.
New York yesterday became the first state to have a special set of rules governing courtroom behavior.

Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., had a smaller loss in the fourth quarter of last year than a year earlier, but the deficit for all 1970 grew to $69,19,000 from $38,294,000 the year before, Paul Thayer, chairman and president of the Dallas-based conglomerate reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 24- The National Education Association and the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employes announced today the formation of a "coalition" to promote the interests of public service workers throughout the country.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 24, (AP) -- Mayor Joseph L. Alioto asserted today that Federal indictments against him in Seattle were a "shoddy fake" concocted by high-ranking Republicans. He pushed for a speedy trial as political and business associates rallied to his support.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (UPI) -- Average interest rates on conventional home-loan mortgages registered the sharpest decline on record in February, falling below 8 per cent for the first time in 18 months, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.

MIAMI, March 24 (AP) -- Meyer Lansky, reputed financial wizard of the underworld was indicted by a Federal grand jury for contempt today for refusing to testify about the operations of a Las Vagas casino.

Frenzied trading in Rolls-Royce in the overthe-counter market by naive traders in recent weeks has carried the shares as high as 80 cents, despite the weight of informed opinion that they are virtually worthless.

Bergdorf Goodman, the Fifth Avenue specialty store, has signed an agreement in principle to be acquired by Broadway-Hale Stores, Inc., the largest department store organization in the West and one of the 50 largest retailers in the United States.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The Democratic party's Policy Council voted unanimously today to support a Congressional cutoff of all funds for American military operations in Indochina after Dec. 31.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange declined yesterday for the fourth consecutive session as the trading pace slackened. Brokers attributed most of the weakness to continued profit taking. Prices opened stronger and then gradually weakened throughout most of the session.

DES MOINES, Iowa, March 24 -- In a brisk 25-minute special meeting at the Look Building here this morning, stockholders of Cowles Communications, Inc., approved a proposal to exchange 10 publishing and broadcasting properties for 2.6 million shares of Class A common stock of The New York Times Company. Cowles is an Iowa corporation.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The Senate voted, 51 to 46, today to end further funding of the supersonic transport aircraft.
In his recent letter Vice President Agnew has again properly focused attention on the contradiction in media attitude concerning their role and rights in our American social and economic structure.
" We must have more help from Washington," may be the sentence that John V. Lindsay has uttered most often in his five years as Mayor.

A legal tight-rope walking act of breath-taking, or at least bewildering, proportions may bring about a merger of the National Basketball Association and the American Basketball Association very quickly -- or it may end in a slip that will lead to a bigger court fight than the one now in progress about Spencer Haywood.

An order to grant United States citizenship to a 24-year-old homosexual from Cuba was issued in Federal District Court here yesterday over the opposition of the Immigration and Naturalization Service.

Demands by some real-estate brokers for exorbitant commissions and gratuities for apartment rentals have led New York Secretary of State John P. Lomenzo to start what he called a "crackdown" on guilty brokers.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Younger liberal Democratic members of the House of Representatives from New York staged a small revolution today by replacing two senior New York Representatives on party advisory and patronage posts.

The late Brothers Grimm, who, for the record if not posterity, are no strangers to moviegoers, should be whirling like dervishes wherever they are as a result of "Grimm's Fairy Tales," the German-made, English-dubbed color version of some of their classic tall tales for kids, which turned up at the Penthouse yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- One of President Nixon's key budget advisers said today that the President had the right to impound money that Congress had ordered spent, but he declared that Mr. Nixon would never do it to thwart the lawmakers.

FORT BENNING, Ga., March 24 -- Cries of "whitewash" would inevitably follow an acquittal of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. and angry criticism of another kind would just as surely greet a conviction, the military judge said today while defending the Calley jurors against defense charges of "wining and dining" and dilatory conduct.

Current hearings in the Congress concerning medical care in this country have again raised the issue of the "doctor shortage." Several observations are offered to substantiate a shortage of physicians:
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Investment abroad by United States corporations soared 22 per cent last year to a record of $13.2-billion, the Commerce Department reported today.

Public School 63 in the Morrisania section of the Bronx and Public School 23 in Manhattan's Chinatown have much in common: They both serve poor neighborhoods, they both occupy old buildings and they both have reputations as orderly, well-run schools.

KARACHI, Pakistan, March 24 (AP) -- Leaders of five minor groups in Pakistan's National Assembly said today that President Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan and Sheik Mujibur Rahman had reached "complete agreement" on constitutional questions that threatened a political split between East and West Pakistan.
DUBLIN, March 24 -- The Irish here, historically committed to reuniting Northern Ireland with the Irish Republic in the south, are split in their reaction to the troubles in the north.
ALBANY, March 24 -- In the midst of negotiating massive cuts in his proposed $8.45-billion budget, Governor Rockefeller warned his cabinet today to "reef the sails and batten down the hatches."
Marine Midland Bank-New York announced yesterday the election of Stanley W. Hubbel to the newly created position of senior vice president. He was also elected a member of the bank's senior

With the official start of spring most people have begun to think in terms of summer vacations at the seashore or in the mountains. Where to go? How much will it cost? Shall it be a hotel or a rental cottage?
The police seized more than $250,000 in allegedly stolen antique silver, jewelry, paintings and other items last night at a cooperative apartment house at 27 West 55th Street.

LONDON, March 24 -- Sir Laurence Olivier, the first actor to be made a peer, took his' seat in the House of Lords today as Lord Olivie'r, the second to bear that title. The new life peer took the oath in the presence of many of his relatives and friends.
A police undercover agent who joined the Black Panther party here denied yesterday that his superiors had pressured him to "make up" conversations he allegedly overheard among the Panthers.

Responding to a soaring rate in reported robberies -- and a study showing that less than 6 per cent of the robberies assigned to detectives result in an arrest -- the Police Department formed special robbery squads yesterday in each of the city's 17 detective districts.

The bill of irrelevancies invoked by Vice President Agnew and Defense Secretary Laird against the Columbia Broadcasting System's documentary, "The Selling of the Pentagon," missed the central issue. It is not the Defense Department's flamboyant tactics in advertising its skills with arms and men. It is not the question of profligate spending of taxpayers' money on publicity side-shows and expensive lobbying for the favors of American business leaders.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Well-placed Pentagon sources say that President Nguyen Van Thieu decided to curtail South Vietnam's offensive in Laos despite suggestions from some senior American militarymen that he send in replacements and try to stay on for a few more weeks.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (UPI) -- By a tie vote, the Supreme Court today upheld conviction of a New York City art dealer for displaying the United States flag in a disrespectful way.

The nation is weary of chronic inflation, economic sluggishness and unemployment. President Nixon has make clear his determination to get the economy back to full employment -- or as close to it as possible -- before the 1972 election. Obviously this is a desirable objective, although it deepens public cynicism to have such vital matters as policies to end unemployment closely geared to the election timetable.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The Nixon Administration is making a "thorough" review of the Interstate Commerce Act to determine how it could initiate a plan for gradually dropping the regulation of the nation's surface-transportation industry in its 1971 report to Congress.

In endorsing the House of Representatives' refusal to grant additional funds for the supersonic transport plane, the Senate has brought to an end a long story of error and of stubborn refusal to admit error. Yesterday's vote is a welcome break with the obsessions of the last decade and marks a move toward a saner, more balanced understanding of the national interest.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., March 24 -- The American Textile Manufacturers Institute, pointing to a 100,000-job loss last year and declining industry earnings, sales and capital investment, today sharply criticized a recent Japanese industry move to voluntarily limit its exports to the United States.

OTTAWA, March 24 -- Canadian hopes that a route through Canada might be used to bring Alaskan oil to United States markets dimmed today after a meeting between Government ministers and the senior executives of five international oil companies.

CAIRO, March 24 -- A new wave of weapons and military equipment deliveries from the Soviet Union has reached the United Arab Republic in the last few weeks, according to reliable Western sources, coinciding with stepped-up, widely publicized measures by the Egyptian leadership to prepare the country for war.
SAN JUAN, P.R., March 24 -- State racing commissioners from the United States and Canada proposed today that offtrack betting be placed under their supervision and operated by the tracks.

TEL AVIV, March 24 -- The Supreme Rabbinical Council in Jerusalem decided today to ease conversion procedures for non-Jewish spouses and children accompanying Jewish immigrants from the Soviet Union and Soviet- bloc countries.

Soon after Tricia Nixon announced her engagement to Edward Cox last week, she received a telephone call from two young women who not so long ago had been in the same situation -- or predicament, as they might call it.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- After a year of disagreement, the Nixon Administration and liberal Democrats in the Senate have agreed on compromise legislation for Federal aid to school districts that are trying to desegregate.

In September, 1895, in China, one Blue and white day the scholar led me to a lighthouse of black wood on the sands of the shore. We emerged from the last thickets, and walked half-asleep, drowsy from the sloth of the ground -- a spongy powder that soaked up our efforts and yielded under our feet. At last we quit the sand.

The President has recommended a major overhaul of executive departments. Many think such reorganization is long overdue. The pros and cons of the particular changes proposed are proper subjects for public debate. One statement sometimes heard in that debate is that departments such as the one recommended will be unmanageable because they will be too large.

Major elements of television are bracing for a tilt with Congress and the Nixon Administration on the exercise of reportorial independence by a journalistic medium that operates under a Federal Government license.
Georgia Tech and St. Bonaventure emphasized last night the prediction that the National Invitation Tournament would be a wide-open battle for team honors.

Nigel Coxe, a Jamaican-born pianist who received his musical education in England and now lives there permanently, made his New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night. Mr. Coxe is teaching at Smith College this semester.

Leaders of public employe unions warned yesterday that any legislative move to have members' pensions regulated by a bipartisan commission would jeopardize collective bargaining under present state law.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- The United States and Mexico today exchanged ratifications of a treaty providing for cooperation in recovering and returning what has become a flood of stolen art treasures from Mexico.
LONDON, March 24 -- The Government's controversial bill to reform labor-management relations passed its last major Parliamentary hurdle today after a lengthy debate in the House of Commons.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (UPI) -- Meyer Lansky, a reputed financial leader of the underworld, was indicted today on charges of illegal gambling activities in connection with a hotel in Las Vegas, Nev.
BEREA, Ky., March 25 -Berea College presented the first W. D. Weatherford Award today to Ben A Franklin, a regional reporter of The Times. Mr. Franklin is based in Washington.

Wall Street has encountered increased difficulty in processing its paperwork in recent weeks, but its troubles still have not reached a critical level, according to a report issued yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.
AMES, Iowa, March 25 (AP) -- Gary Hall of Indiana and Stanford's 400-yard medley relay team set American records tonight in the 48th National Collegiate Athletic Association swimming championship.

Twelve New York City public high, school students who were among 340 winners of the National Achievement Awards for outstanding Negro students were honored yesterday by the Board of Education at its headquarters at 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The Commerce Department said today that, while auto production has rebounded as expected in the current quarter, neither output nor sales to consumers are "exceptionally high."
BRUSSELS, March 25 -- European Common Market ministers agreed today on higher farm prices and a $1.48-billion program to modernize backward agricultural enterprises.
In a surprise appearance, Joe Frazier arrived in New York last night from his Philadelphia hospital hideout and upstaged a news conference announcing the formation of a monthly TV boxing network.

ALBANY, March 25 -- The Assembly gave final legislative approval today to a measure expanding the membership of the New York City Board of Elections from 4 to 10 and giving representation to the Bronx, Queens and Staten Island.

HANOI, March 25 (Agence France-Presse) -- United States bombing raids over the southern provinces of North Vietnam have caused some 100 casualties since the beginning of the month, according to a communique published here today.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 25 -- Northern Ireland's Prime Minister, Brian Faulkner, made gestures tonight to both the Protestant majority and the Roman Catholic minority of this bitterly divided province when he named his Cabinet.

The Whitney Museum program notes for "Quick Billy," a 75-minute experimental film by Bruce Baille, refer to "the essential experience of transformation, between Life and Death, death and birth, or rebirth."
In the menus below dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

HOUSTON, March 25 -- Villanova became tonight the first team from the Eastern College Athletic Conference to reach the final of the National Collegiate basketball championship in 16 years when the Wildcats survived two overtimes and beat Western Kentucky, 92-89, in the Astrodome.

Contessa Marietta de Flemotomos was married here yesterday afternoon to Daniel Plato Skouras, vice president in charge of foreign distribution for American International Pictures. Criminal Court Judge Nicholas Tsoucalas performed the ceremony at the bride's apartment.
PARIS, March 25 -- Europe has too many farmers, and few of them want to leave the land. In France there is a special attachment to "la terre": that is part of the national character.
DETROIT, March 25 -- The General Motors Corporation has said for the first time that it might be able to pass tough anti-pollution tests for 1975 cars, but only if the Government changes the tests.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 25 (UPI) -- The California Supreme Court, in a decision that could affect 400,000 families and threatens the state budget, ruled today that recent welfare cuts by the administration of Gov. Ronald Reagan violated state law.
The New York City Transit Authority asked for bids yesterday for the construction of the portion of the new Queens-Manhattan subway under Central Park.
SYDNEY, Australia March 25 -- David Rockefeller told a group of leading Australian businessmen today that the United States economy "has hit bottom and is on the way up."

NEWARK, March 25 -- The Newark Teachers Union accepted a proposal by the state-appointed mediator today to settle its eight-week-old strike, but the Board of Education announced that it would make no response to the proposal.

OSAKA, Japan -- Twenty-five years ago the great familyowned financial trusts of Japan, Mitsui, Mitsubishi, Sumitomo and others, lay prostrate -- their coffers nearly empty, their mines and factories devastated by bombing, their few workable installations earmarked for reparations to the victorious Allies.

LONDON, March 25 -- The deadlock in the 53-day strike against the British subsidiary of the Ford Motor Company deepened today with the suspension of union meetings for two weeks and an offer of cash assistance to the British strikers from automobile unions around the world.

KHESANH, South Vietnam, March 25 -- When Specialist 4 Gregory Geneviva heard at noon today that the American troops of the 101st Airborne Division would shortly be leaving the huge allied base here, with the Vietnamese drive into Laos at the feeble end of its final chapter, he shook his head and sighed:
The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People filed its first lawsuit yesterday challenging the constitutionality of zoning ordinances that bar apartment houses from Suburban towns.

FORT BENNING, Ga., March 25 -- For the first time since they received the case nine days ago, the military jurors in the trial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. deliberated today without asking the judge questions or requesting any re-reading of testimony.

MIAMI, March 25 -- Jerry Michael Heard, who wears his golf hat like a sailor -- on the back of his head with the brim upturned -- led the $200,000 National Airlines open golf tournament today with a 66.

TRW, Inc., a large aerospace and automotive-parts manufacturer, and the Collins Radio Company announced yesterday that they had started exploratory discussions for a possible affiliation of the two concerns.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, March 26 -- United States units began pulling away from the Laotian border today as concern continued that North Vietnamese troops would try to intensify their attacks against American installations.

The city's plan to keep the Yankees and the football Giants in New York by buying and modernizing Yankee Stadium was imperiled yesterday when City Councilmen -- rebuffed in their attempt to get the Giants to agree to stay -- deferred action on the purchase.

The London stock market closed firm yesterday, and dealers said that buying and institutional inquiries in anticipation of a reflationary Government budget had met a shortage of issues.
WARSAW, March 25 -- A five-year effort by Pan American World Airways to open service to Poland has ended successfully with agreement on a New York-Warsaw route.
Officials of New Jersey's thoroughbred race tracks reacted with dismay yesterday to the prospect of competing against a state-operated "super track" in the Hackensack River meadowlands.

BOGOTA, Colombia -- This nation's greatest short-range problem would be solved if every American housewife brewed twice as many cups of coffee and its greatest long-range problem would be solved if every Colombian housewife took the pill. However, since neither event is likely to occur, a time of trouble looms.

In some vocal recitals the interest can lie in seeing how much a singer can communicate with a small voice. In Roland Hayes's later years, when the tenor's vocal resources were a shadow of what they had been, he could turn a recital into a remarkable artistic experience through an uncanny knowledge of how to use what he had.

A State Supreme Court justice temporarily upheld a court order yesterday that prohibited Mrs. Nellie R. Duncan, the suspended superintendent of School District 23 in Brooklyn, from assuming her office.
Silver futures prices rose yesterday in moderately heavy trading on the New York Commodity Exchange.
Sixty years ago the Red Cross was raising money to combat tuberculosis through the sale of Christmas seals. Today in New York, it is assisting in the detection of a new scourge, lead-paint poisoning.

A group headed by a major subcontractor on the supersonic transport began intensive consultations with the financial community yesterday in hopes of resurrecting the SST program without further Government aid.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -Senator Edward M. Kennedy today described the South Vietnamese incursion into Laos as "a nightmare" that has ended in a "humiliating retreat" carried out "so obviously in panic."

A "poker" face is a desirable asset for bridge players, but also a rare one. Playing against a member of the great majority -- those who do not have impeccable facial control -- it is often possible to judge whether an opponent is gloomy or contented.
A bellowing, fist-shaking group of 150 Brooklyn homeowners forced the Board of Estimate to retire for more than an hour yesterday before the homeowners were made to leave the City Hall meeting room.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, March 25 -- An American newly arrived in Pakistan might have been surprised by the speech of a right-wing Pakistani politician at a Karachi rally Monday claiming that the United States Central Intelligence Agency, Premier Golda Meir of Israel and Indian officials had teamed up "to divide Pakistan under the patronage of the United States of America.

DETROIT, March 25 -- The chairman of the General Motors Corporation today attacked the social critics of business as the "adversary culture" and charged them with misleading the young, the courts and the Government.
For a while it looked as if no one would take charge of the lagging New York Knickerbocker offense in the last quarter of their playoff opener against the Atlanta Hawks in the Garden yesterday.

The well-known spawning run of rainbow trout in the Finger Lakes and their tributaries may be past its peak by the April 1 opening of the fishing season, according to the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation.

Arthur Mizener has now affixed the original title to his account of Ford's life, where it fits a bit loosely.

New York City will soon have a central authority to regulate the burgeoning CATV industry within the city. This was assured late Thursday when the Board of Estimate passed unanimously a resolution authorizing establishment of an Office of Telecommunications within the Bureau of Franchises.
The Phelps Dodge Corporation, the second largest producer of American primary copper, announced yesterday that it would raise the basic price of the metal by about 4.7 per cent, effective Monday.

LOS ANGELES, March 26 (AP) -- Gail Goodrich, the smallest man on the floor, scored 14 points in the final quarter tonight to rally the Los Angeles Lakers to a 105-95 victory over the Chicago Bulls and a 2-0 lead in their National Basketball Association playoff series.

Seldom has a nation-state enjoyed as great a moral justification as the state of Israel. It has received a homeless, vilely persecuted people and made them strong and proud. Under their care, the land they occupy has been made to flourish. When, as part of the spoils of war, the sacred and beautiful city of Jerusalem passed under Israeli control, the promise implied in Israeli occupation seemed to be realized under Mayor Kollek's administration.

BERKELEY, Calif., March 26 -- The flower children are gone from Telegraph Avenue, and their disappearance underscores a fundamental change that is taking place in the lives of disaffected young people across the country.

NEW HAVEN, March 26 -- After calling 19 witnesses in less than five hours, Ericka Huggins's attorney today concluded her argument that tape recordings made during the torture of Alex Rackley should not be admitted into evidence against her client.
A State Education Department inquiry cleared the Board of Education here yesterday of having violated a state law against overspending in connection with its current $29.2-million budget deficit.
CAIRO, March 26 -- A little black and white taxi, No. 2338, stopped at a red light in downtown Cairo. Another taxi pulled alongside and the driver shouted a warning, "Your tire is going flat?"
DETROIT, March 26 -- The Chrysler Corporation said today it will hire or recall 1,325 workers at two plants to increase its big-car production May 10.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- United States officials said today that the pattern of recent construction of intercontinental missile sites in the Soviet Union might presage the deployment of a new Soviet offensive-weapon system.

PARIS, March 26 -- A group of 46 American Protestant church leaders, clergymen and laymen urged the United States today to pledge unconditional withdrawal of its troops from Indochina in the immediate future to facilitate a political settlement at the Vietnam peace talks.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 26 -- The last time Frank Robinson was at Fort Lauderdale Stadium he was in a role that prompted Ralph Houk to say, "I'd rather see him in the dugout than in the outfield."
WASHINGTON, March 26 (UPI) -- President Nixon urged a visiting group of clergymen at the White House today to give youth "some sense of faith" as the best alternative to a life ruined by drugs.

The noontime jazz concerts that have been presented on Fridays by Jazz Adventures at Downbeat, Lexington Avenue at 42d Street, for the past three months, will move next Friday to La Martinique, 57 West 57th Street, which will become a center of jazz activity.

The director of the Institute for Juvenile Justice, a national child-advocacy organization, said yesterday that legal action would be taken to close the Spofford Juvenile Center in the Bronx "once and for all."

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The welfare reform plan developed by Representative Wilbur D. Mills in the House Ways and Means Committee seems certain to disappoint some Governors, despite the $2.1-billion in fiscal relief it would provide the states.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- (UPI) -- Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, accused the Food and Drug Administration today of endangering small children by failing to ban drain cleaners that contain liquid lye.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Warfare in East Pakistan would find the regular West Pakistani army with superior numbers of troops and modern weapons, according to United States analysts here.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 26 -- Premier Nihat Erim announced his Cabinet today, choosing 15 of the 25 ministers in it from outside the Turkish Parliament. It includes many young technical experts with no political experience.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 26 -- Mayor Lindsay invited Secretary General Thant today to use New York as a "laboratory" in seeking ways to combat drug addiction.

The Detroit Edison Company showed gains in operating revenues and net income in 1970, according to the company's report mailed yesterday to stockholders.

Federal health officials reported yesterday that at least 350 patients had suffered blood infections from contaminated intravenous fluids and that a growing number of American hospitals had recognized that their patients were affected by the problem in recent weeks.

ALBANY, March 26 -- Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea Jr. told Republican Assembly-men today that Governor Rockefeller and Republican legislative leaders had agreed to cuts of $700-million in the administration's proposed $8.45-billion budget.

A firmer tendency began to falter toward the close of trading in the London stock market yesterday as buyers failed to follow early small institutional support and many prices finished below the day's highs.

COMMON sense suggests that great wealth is better than moderate wealth. And in bridge it is true that wealth in trumps is desirable. A player with a good trump fit in the combined hands can expect to make at least as many tricks as he would if be had chosen a trump suit with a lesser total of cards. But there can be interesting paradoxical exceptions, as on the diagramed deal.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- In northwest Indiana, they tell a story about a man from Hammond who was contemplating a bus trip to Chicago, a distance of about 10 miles.

NEW DELHI, March 28 -- The people of East Pakistan, armed with sticks, spears and homemade rifles, are mounting a resistance movement against a military force from West Pakistan that is armed with planes, bombs, tanks and heavy artillery.
The power of positive thinking is likely to dominate this week's 24th Soviet Communist party congress, an event some Kremlinologists are already calling the coronation of Czar Leonid I.
Spinning past a leaderless Boston defense and outmaneuvering would be checkers, the Rangers last night continued their march to playoff form by handing the Boston Bruins their fourth straight defeat.

Put Susanne Marsee's name on your list of Rosinas to hear and enjoy in the future. The young mezzo-soprano took over the role of the marriageable girl in Rossini's "Il Barbiere di Siviglia" for the first time in the New York City Opera performance on Saturday afternoon and showed that her voice, looks and personality make her highly suitable for the part.

HONIARA, Guadalcanal -- The jungled, malarious Solomon Islands in the Southwest Pacific, where Americans cut off the Japanese advance toward Australia early in World War II, are expected to become an independent nation in this decade.

FREETOWN, Sierra Leone, March 28 (Reuters) -- Armed forces from neighboring Guinea flew into Sierra Leone today at the request of Prime Minister Slaka P. Stevens, whose army commander last week staged an abortive coup.

A major segment of the auto insurance industry, in a move to separate the good drivers from the not-so-good and the really bad ones, is attempting to introduce a new rate classification system in New York that has long been in operation almost everywhere else. The industry tried to get approval for the plan here in the past but was rebuffed by the State Insurance Department. Now it is making a new attempt.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (UPI) -- Treasury Department statistics released today showed that 56 Americans had an adjusted gross income of more than $1-million in 1969, but paid no Federal income taxes.

Bess Myerson, the city's Commissioner of consumer Affairs, today attacked proposed department of Agriculture regulations that would allow packers to inject meet and poultry with fluids. She said the regulations were misleading and likely ot cost the consumer more money.

EVANSTON, Ill., March 28, (Reuters) -- John Newcombe, the Wimbledon champion, defeated Arthur Ashe of Gum Spring, Va., 4-6, 7-6, 6-2, 6-3, today to win the $10,000 top prize in the $50,000 Sportface tennis tournament.

LINCOLN, N. H., March 28 -- In an unusual display of form consistency for a major eastern ski racing tournament, Wayne Wright of Wilmington, N. Y., and Brad Kennison, Essex Center, Vt., were the two top finishers for the second straight day on Loon Mountain.

FORT BENNING, Ga., March 28 -- The military judge in the Mylai murder trial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. announced today that he would consult with defense and prosecution attorneys tomorrow on whether to prod a jury that has deliberated longer than any other in the history of military justice.

New York Hota routed Hoboken, 5-2 to maintain its lead in the North Group of the German-American Soccer League yesterday, while Elizabeth and the German-Hungarians, battling for supremacy in the South Group, posted 1-1 ties.
President Nixon says he wants business to pass future savings from productivity gains down the line to consumers.

CHICAGO, March 28 (AP) -- Fired by the ejection of Coach Dick Motta, the Chicago Bulls battled to a 106-98 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers today in their National Basketball Association playoff series.

Fortunately, the company had a fine replacement on hand, Michael Devlin, who was singing the role for the first time, and the young bass made a resounding success of it.
SEOUL, South Korea, March 28 -- South Korea's two major political parties opened their campaigns yesterday for the April 27 presidential election.

BOSTON, March 28 -- "We have to meet our Jewish kids where they're at," a group of Jewish mothers were told here today. "They saw, long before many of their parents did, the evils of racism, the blight of urban poverty and the immorality of the war in Vietnam."
AMMAN, March 28 -- The Jordanian Government showed new power today by cowing Palestinian guerrilla gunmen after shooting spread from the provinces to Amman.

Countrywide Publications, which moved during its 14 years from "one-shot" romance and fan magazines to special interest magazines, is now ready to go for the big one -- a monthly general interest magazine.

Progress has been reported in plans for reducing pollution of the Hudson River from the General Motors plant at North Tarrytown, N.Y., with the pollution scheduled to stop completely by the end of the year.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, March 28 (UPI) -- Ramon Ernesto Cruz, candidate of the governing National Party, took the lead tonight in Honduras's first peaceful presidential election in decades.
The Pakistani Government continued yesterday its strict military censorship on developments in East Pakistan, where the army was seeking to crush the nationalist movement.

HICKSVILLE, L. I., March 24 -- "Overqualified," a term that connotes education, skill and experience, has become the bane of many engineers and scientists on Long Island who have been thrown out of work and onto the welfare rolls.
YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, March 28 -- Gary Smith looked at a cardboard folder with cutouts for dimes that his church had sent him to fill up by Easter Sunday. It was still empty.

The annual Alvin Landy Memorial game, the biggest charity effort of the year by the Greater New York Bridge Association, will be played tonight at 15 locations in New York City and Long Island. Almost all the proceeds will be channeled through the American Contract Bridge League's Charity Foundation to the National Multiple Sclerosis Society.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- By Thursday, Nebraska must bring its welfare system into compliance with Federal welfare regulations or face the loss of $15-million a year in Federal aid.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Information reaching the United States Government from Pakistan today indicated that the military Government appeared to be in control of Dacca.

ALBANY -- A tenement house burned down last winter across the street from the Schuyler Mansion, Governor Rockefeller's official residence, and the sound of the sirens and the sight of the flames, reflected in the mansion's windows, attracted the attention of the servants.

DETROIT, March 28 (UPI) -- Alex Delvecchio scored Detroit's second unassisted goal of the game with 5:09 elapsed in the third period today and it gave the Red Wings a 2-1 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs in a National Hockey League game.

SAN CLEMENTE, March 28 -- Justice Department officials said today that James R. Hoffa, whose application for parole will be reviewed Wednesday, considered and apparently rejected a bizarre scheme to enlist the support of the man who did as much as anyone else to put him in prison -- Senator John L. McClellan, Democrat of Arkansas.

BRISTOL, Tenn., March 28 (UPI) -- David Pearson of Spartanburg, S.C., took the lead 63 laps from the finish today, held off a threat by Richard Petty and won the Southeastern 500 nascar race in a Ford.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, March 29 -- Thirty-three American soldiers were killed and 76 wounded early yesterday when enemy forces attacked and partly overran a United States Army artillery base in northern South Vietnam.

SEOUL, South Korea, March 28 -- Kim Dae Jung, the opposition legislator running against President Chung Hee Park in next month's South Korean presidential election, is a farmer's son who calls himself a Willy Brandt-type politician.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Senator Henry M. Jackson proposed today a one-year agreement with the Soviet Union freezing the deployment of most land-based missiles. He said this would "arrest the decline in the security" of the United States nuclear deterrent.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 28 -- Here in Eden some of the apples are turning sour.

ALBANY, March 28 -- Mayor Lindsay said today that state budget cuts proposed by legislative leaders would mean the loss of $104-million in state funds earmarked for city workers' salaries within the next three months and "substantial layoffs of city employes."

MOSCOW, March 28 -- Le Duan, the leader of North Vietnam's Communist party, arrived in Moscow last night with ranking Vietcong and Pathet Lao officials to attend the 24th Soviet Party Congress and discuss Indochinese developments with Soviet leaders.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (UPI) -- The door-to-door selling industry, which about doubled in volume in the 1960's, appears to have benefited from the recession.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 25 -- Just a year ago Pnompenh slid from peace into war without missing a beat in the serene and smiling rhythm of its placid life. For a long time afterward even the growing realization that Cambodia was at war did not seem to diminish the city's pleasure in being alive.

The Roller Derby, a sport that matches good against evil, made its final appearance of the season yesterday at Madison Square Garden. As 19,507 people looked on, the good (the San Francisco Bay Bombers) defeated the evil (the Midwest Pioneers), 52-48.

Shortly before Virginia Slims announced a $15,000 women's tennis tournament for New York City, Mrs. Billie Jean King expressed two private concerns: (1) Was it necessary for the women to risk bombing out in the big town after successes elsewhere, and (2) Would she manage finally to snap her string of tournament losses here?

His well-known report on the troubles at Columbia University reflected a particular sympathy for students and understanding of the reasons for their unrest. His person expresses a New England sense of moral conviction.

The Cleveland Cavalier will get first pick today when the National Basketball Association holds its annual draft. The Cavaliers, who finished witch 15-67 won-lost record, poorest in the league, won a coin flip with Portland, another expansion team, for the right to select first.

If you look up the date of Johann Sebastian Bach's birth in encyclopedias, you will find it given as March 21, 1685. But Joseph Kline, like others who have gone further into the matter, realizes that Bach was really born 286 years ago tomorrow. The Associated Dry Goods Corporation yesterday reported record sales and earnings for the fourth fiscal quarter, ended Jan. 30. WASHINGTON, March 29 -Breaking with other members of the House Democratic leadership, the Democratic whip, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. of Massachusetts, called today for withdrawal of all United States military forces from Indochina by the end of the year.

Vandalism on New York City's subways and buses last year cost the city's Transit Authority -- and ultimately the riders and taxpayers -- about $2.6-million, or as much as 10 new air-conditioned subway cars, the authority disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Julie Nixon Eisenhower is glad that she's finished with college. She's distressed over youngsters who take narcotics. She respects conscientious objectors who stay within the law. The National Collegiate Athletic Association is still investigating reports that some seniors signed professional basketball contracts or agreed with agents to negotiate for them before the end of the recent season.

Prices of soybean futures closed mixed yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade with the nearby options gaining after having dropped sharply early in the session. The new crop, or the deferred months were little changed after opening lower and closed slightly lower.
GREENSBORO, N.C., March 31 -- Billy Casper has chosen a royal road, with a stop here, to prepare for the defense of his Masters golf title at Augusta, Ga., next week.

Bucking the severe bear market for corporate jets, the Cessna Aircraft Company kicked off a sales campaign here yesterday for a new plane that it said would give executive access to hundreds of American airports that are too small for present jets.

In two places in his "Voices," which was given its New York premiere on Tuesday night by' the Juilliard Repertory Orchestra, the several percussionists take over in quasi-jam sessions that give the work both focal and climactic points.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit ruled today that railroad operating union could conduct strikes against a few railroads to bring pressure on all the nation's rail companies.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 31 -- The first silver dollar to be minted by the United States since 1935 was struck here this morning at the United States Assay Office.
Putnam County streams may have a surplus of anglers today as the trout fishing season opens in New York State.

CHICAGO, March 31 -- Dean Burch, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, told broadcasters today that they were colliding head-on with the concerns of consumers and a more active participatory democracy.

HARTFORD, March 31 -- A controversial plan to raise new taxes in Connecticut by imposing a 7 per cent sales levy on all policyholder insurance premiums came under strong attack here today by the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, the nation's largest all-line insurer, with assets of nearly $10-billion.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., March 31 -- President Nixon today asked the Senate and House Armed Services Committees to approve the first in a series of nationwide moves to transfer billions of dollars worth of federally owned land to state and local governments for recreational and other public uses. ceeds from such sales would' be earmarked for che land and water conservation fund of the Interior DePartment for use in developing new stae or national parks.
DONGHA, South Vietnam, March 31 -- President Nguyen Van Thieu declared today that his troops' recent thrust into Laos had attained "the biggest victory ever" for the armed forces of South Vietnam.

ATHENS, March 25 -- United States diplomats in Athens, under fire from both Senate investigators in Washington and opponents of the military Government here, are shifting their tactics slightly but holding firm to the policy that they and the State Department have formulated.
Let's take a moment, kids, to relive one of the golden moments of early television.

Every 10 days a truck rolls up to Bill and Betty Roberts's St. Bernard kennel in Tolland, Conn., and drops off two tons of dry dog food. Once a month, 30 cases of beef, each holding 50 pounds, are added.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Navy has begun a five-year program to bring the number of blacks in the Navy up to the level of their 12 per cent representation in the nation's population.

GENEVA, March 31 -- The draft of an international convention banning bacteriological weapons will probably be submitted to the United Nations General Assembly for approval this fall, delegates at the disarmament conference here said today.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -The Treasury reported late this afternoon the sale of $2.2-billion of "strip" bills. The amount of accepted tenders on these bills will be equally divided among 11 issues of outstanding Treasury bills maturing on consecutive dates beginning July 18, 1971.
A Long Island State Supreme Court justice was suspended yesterday pending a review of his record by a six-judge Court on the Judiciary.

NEWARK, March 31 -- Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson supported the suspension of 347 striking Newark teachers today, as indications mounted that the nine-week-old strike was further polarizing this racially divided city.

The Board of Education has asked local school authorities to investigate charges by some teachers that pupils at two Brooklyn elementary schools were recently coached for the citywide reading tests by being drilled on sections of the actual examinations.

DETROIT, March 31 -- Bayard Rustin, the civil rights leader, asserted today that no progressive social or political movement could develop in America without the continued close cooperation of the black and Jewish communities.

WESTPORT, Conn., March 31 -- The Westport Board of Selectmen was permanently enjoined today from conducting a special recall election aimed at ousting the chairman of the school board, Mrs. Joan G. Schine, a leading figure in a controversy that began over the busing of children from Bridgeport.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -The Air Force has used a nuclear power plant on the shore of Lake Michigan as a practice target in simulated low-level bombing runs, according to Glenn T. Seaborg, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -Only a small fraction of American workers belonging to private pension plans ever receive a penny in pension benefits, according to a Senate subcommittee study released today.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -Representative John E. Moss of California has asked the Securities and Exchange Commission for an explanation of why it diluted its original proposal to end price-fixed sales comnlisstuns on large stock transactions.

Two thousand uniformed firemen, their white-gloved hands raised in salute, lined a quiet street in Queens yesterday to pay tribute to Capt. John F. Dunne, who died Sunday in a futile rescue attempt in a blazing buiding.
Dore Schary, the playwright and former Hollywood producer, will withdraw from his $35,000-a-year post as the city's Commissioner of Cultural Affairs next summer to "get back to my work."

HOUSTON, March 31 -- The Yankees moved to the Astrodome tonight to continue spring training, but the new environment didn't help. Houston won the night exhibition, 9-3. It was the Yankees' 19th loss in 27 games.
DONG HA, South Vietnam, March 31 -- President Nguyen Van Thieu said today that he had been confident that justice would punish those guilty of the killings at Mylai.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- To reduce the risk of oil spills from ship collisions, two environmental groups petitioned the Coast Guard today to establish "sea lanes" and shore-based radar surveillance systems to control traffic in the nation's major ports.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Bureau of Mines has ordered the retirement of James C. Westfield, the nation's leading authority on the causes and prevention of coal mine disasters, officials disclosed today.

Alan Shestack has been appointed director of the Yale University art gallery, effective July 1. He will succeed Andrew C. Ritchie in a post Mr. Ritchie has held since 1957.

AMMAN, Jordan, March 30 -King Hussein's relations with Cairo have grown frosty lately as the Egyptian authorities have made friendly gestures toward the fedayeen.

Interest rates on corporate bonds took a good-sized step upward yesterday.

OAKLAND, Calif. April 1 (AP) -- Joe Ellis threw in a 40-foot jump shot with one second to play tonight to give San Francisco a 106-104 victory over the Milwaukee Bucks and keep the Warriors alive in the National Basketball Association Western Division playoffs.
A Sanford, N. C., woman with four children is suing the city in an effort to get on the welfare rolls. The city maintains that the family is already getting assistance from its home state.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -Democrats pushed a public service jobs bill through the Senate today and proposed a minimum wage increase in the House. Both actions represented the Democrats' efforts to write their own economic program.
SAN RAFAEL, Calif., April 1 -- Angela Davis charged today that the latest judge appointed to hear her pretrial motions was prejudiced against her interest and asked that he be disqualified.

While it has become commonplace for fashion designers to turn their talents to towels and bed linens, not many interior designers have. But David Hicks of London has, and his new line for J. P. Stevens Co., Inc., will be in Bloomingdale's seventh floor linens department early this month.

Led by a small group of inmates, about 270 prisoners gained control of their cell blocks at the Federal House of Detention in Manhattan for three hours last night but returned peaccably to their cells after a show of force by correction officers.

I nurse this odd sentimental hope that one of these days some school of writers is going to come along and make great fictional art out of some old five-and-dime form like the private-eye thriller, or the whodunit, or science fiction. The way Shakespeare elevated the traditional revenge tragedy when he wrote "Hamlet." Something like that.

GREENSBORO, N.C. April 1 -- Bob Charles, golf's No. 1 southpaw Lee Trevino, No. 1 on the 1970 money-winning list and Miller Barber, golf's "Mr. X," shared the lead at 67 today in the $190,000 Greater Greensboro open.
Mayor Lindsay wagered two play-dollars yesterday in a demonstration of how the city's offtrack betting system will work when it starts operating Thursday.

HOUSTON, April 1 -- Larry Dierker and Denny Lemaster of the Houston Astros combined tonight to shut out the New York Yankees, 5-0, on four hits. It was the 20th loss of the spring for the Yankees, who have, won only eight times.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- Provisions to charge both aged and low-income persons part of the cost of health services they now receive free have been tentatively written into a new welfare bill, it was reported today.

More than 400 student presidents and college editors have signed an open letter to President Nixon condemning his policies in Vietnam and charging that the Administration "seriously misinterprets the mood of both the campus and the countryside."
MIAMI, April 1 -- Eastern Air Lines, one of the biggest customers for the much-troubled Lockheed Tristar jetliner, stressed today its "continued confidence" in the three-jet airbus.

WEST POINT, N. Y., April 1 -- Craig Lincoln of the University of Minnesota was the winner of the men's event, the one-meter springboard, and Capt. Micki King of the United States Air Force, took the women's three-meter springboard title tonight at the Amateur Athletic Union's national indoor diving championships.
The Sperry Rand Corporation has elected Shelton Fisher, president and chief executive officer of McGraw-Hill, Inc., as a director.

BALTIMORE, April 1 -- A mishandled pass from Wes Unseld to Jack Marin with five seconds to play thwarted an amazing comeback attempt by the Baltimore Bullets tonight and kept the Philadelphia 76ers alive in their National Basketball Association first-round playoff.

ANKARA -- When Ali Ihsan married here five years ago, he paid his father-in-law 6,000 Turkish lira (the equivalent then of $500) in baslik, or bride price. Now Ali's 18-year-old sister is being courted by a fellow student whose family has hinted that it considers 12,000 ($800 since last summer's devaluation) as a fair price.
DENVER, April 1 -- Mild to moderate high blood pressure may be good for the aging mind, a scientist who has been studying the elderly for more than a decade said here today.

A veteran of the war in Vietnam who has three Purple Hearts, a Bronze Star and a Silver Star told a noontime Wall Street rally yesterday, "We are all of us in this country guilty for having allowed the war to go on."

The Italian-American Civil Rights League may have rendered a public service in persuading the movie makers to eliminate all mention of the Mafia and Cosa Nostra. The implication that criminality is an Italian trait is perhaps too much to take each time the crime ring is mentioned.
The restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored where indicated.

CAIRO, April 1 -- The United Arab Republic offered tonight to reinstate a formal cease-fire along the Suez Canal for a limited period if Israel would agree to a proposal of President Anwar el-Sadat for a partial withdrawal of troops to be followed by a reopening of the waterway to international shipping.

CALCUTTA, India, April 1 -Troops from West Pakistan were reported on the offensive today against pockets of resistance in at least nine East Pakistani cities and towns Thousands of civilians were reported fleeing into the countryside.

I was glad to see Richard Shramko's proposal (letter Feb. 22) that a quality of life index (Q.L.I.) should be developed, in spite of a disparaging reference in Time as "an engaging, if wistful suggestion." While the day for a single quality index, comparable to the gross national product economic index is quite distant in the future, several public and private groups have been in the process of attempting to develop social indicators.
Dr. William G. Agnew, head of the emission research department of the General Motors Corporation, said yesterday that pollution from automobiles was decreasing.

BOULDER, Colo., April 1 -- Miss Joan Cadden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Cadden of New York and East Hampton, L. I., was married here this afternoon to Curt R. Zimansky, son of Prof. and Mrs. Curt A. Zi. mansky of Iowa City.

KHESANH, South Vietnam, March 30 -- The American infantrymen who have been patrolling the jungle-covered mountains west of Khesanh -- fighting and sometimes dying in obscure small-unit clashes while supporting the South Vietnamese invasion of Laos -- feel that they are forgotten men.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -Vice President Agnew called critics of the war in Indochina "home-front snipers" today and accused them of having fostered a negative attitude toward American combat veterans.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- A break appeared today in the once solid Southern flank in the House supporting the Vietnam war as two conservative Democrats from Georgia announced their opposition to continuation of the fighting.

ATHENS, April l -- Athens's chief prosecutor ordered criminal proceedings today against the "civilian or military officials" who made an arrest that was branded arbitrary by an opponent of the military-dominated government.

SANTIAGO, Chile -- In formulating foreign policy Washington must always separate two considerations: what is good for the inhabitants of the country in question and what is good for the United States. This duality lies at the heart of the approach to Chile's new Marxist Government.
Mayor Lindsay issued a brief, sharply worded statement yesterday attacking the spending cuts fashioned by the Republican leadership in the Legislature.

WASHINGTON -- Social issues are often shrouded in myth and misconception. As an example, for too long it was popularly believed that fathers of welfare families irresponsibly abandoned their wives and children to live carefree, devil-may-care lives financed by the public's largesse.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The rise in wholesale prices continued at a moderate rate in March -- a rise slower than in most of 1970 -- the Labor Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The nation's passion over the Calley verdict and confusion over the Laos invasion have combined to produce a brand new phase of the Indochina debate here. And the central element of that debate, for reasons of policy as well as politics, has become the issue of a date for final disengagement.

Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Ltd., second largest Canadian distiller and one of the four principal producers of whisky and gin in the United States, showed substantially larger sales in the fiscal quarter and six months ended Feb. 28, but earnings were virtually unchanged, according to the semiannual results reported yesterday.

QUITO, Ecuador, April 1 (AP) -- A disgruntled general's oneday revolt against the Government of President Jose Maria Velasco Ibarra ended today the way it began -- with a communique. Not a shot was fired in the interim.

BEKAA, Jordan, March 28 -Goats romp, Old men doze in the sun. Children race on rented bicycles. But the armed Palestinian commandos who once swarmed through Bekaa's dirt alleys are nowhere to be seen.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, April 1 -- Peter Darrell's production of "Giselle" for Scottish Theater Ballet proves that original thought can still pay dividends, even with such an old classic. This is the company's first venture into the standard repertory, and Mr. Darrell has applied the same dramatic logic and consistent characterization as in his own new works.

ALBANY, April 1 -- Democratic legislators, who were severely criticized by the Republicans in 1965 for not passing a budget by the deadline of midnight March 31, could hardly conceal their glee today at the discomfiture of the Republicans for failing to meet the deadline this year.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., April 1 (AP) -- The White House announced today a $42-million effort to promote jobs and help retrain unemployed scientists and technicians who are victims of defense-aerospace cutbacks.

SHARM EL SHEIK, IsraeliOccupied United Arab Republic -- The Red Sea waters at the point of Ras Nusrani, 15 miles north of here, are clear and deep. The far shoreline is the barren Saudi Arabian island of Tiran; on this side, two spiked old British-made cannon placed by the Egyptian Army point out across the strait.
The real truth about New York today -- the awful truth -- is that it's a one-night stand between Hackensack and Pittsburgh.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -Members of two of the Government's major regulatory agencies took opposing views today on the proposals for reorganization of those agencies that were made by a presidential task force headed by Roy L. Ash, president of Litton Industries, Inc.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The recent disclosures about extensive Government spying on private citizens raises a practical question: Why not a domestic intelligence advisory board to help the President maintain a balance between the security of the nation and the rights of its citizens?
In the menus below dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
The British bank-rate cut from 7 per cent to 6 per cent was largely responsible for higher prices and active trading on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.

MOSCOW, April 1 -- President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania told the Soviet Communist party's 24th Congress today that his country would continue to follow an independent course even if this brought it into conflict with Soviet policies.
The 4,500 union men who move household and office furniture in the meropolitan area overwhelmingly rejected a contract offer yesterday and went on strike.

The Chesapeake Potomac Telephone Companies, which has four companies that have been served by three ad agencies, has decided as a costsaving measure to centralize its advertising functions. The beneficiary of this move (and of some $2-million in billings) is Ketchum, MacLeod Grove, which has a Washington office.

One of the few encouraging developments in our city's financial crisis is the apparent awakening of The Times to the fact that there are limits to the extravagance of Mayor Lindsay that cannot be exceeded without grave peril to the city's viability. [Editorial March 13.]
Prices on the American Stock Exchange closed mixed yesterday on moderate trading.
LONDON, April 1 -- The British bank rate was cut by one percentage point today, from 7 per cent to 6 per cent, the lowest level since the predevaluation days of 1967.
YONKERS -- Put a group of 6-year-olds in a planetarium, give them an astronomy lecture and a celestial show and out will come a tumble of sometimes sophisticated, sometimes naive questions.
As in his previous recitals here, Francis Brancaleone, who played at Tully Hall Wednesday night, showed formidable control of color and nimble technique.

Small private colleges and universities suffered a decrease in voluntary financial support last year, while public institutions had a substantial increase, according to a national survey by the Council for Financial Aid to Education.
The prosecution rested yesterday in the trial here of 13 Black Panthers accused of conspiring to bomb public places and murder policemen and of possessing dangerous weapons and explosives.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 1 -- A dozen residents of nearby suburban communities have put up their homes and other property as security to cover a $100,000 bail bond for a former leader of the Black Panther party here.
UNITED NATIONS, New York, April 1 -- Secretary General Thant officially established a United Nations fund for drug abuse control here today and the United States promptly donated $1-million.

A series of five Czechoslovak films, two of which will have their premiere showings in this country, will be presented at the New York Cultural Center in Columbus Circle starting Wednesday. The screenings, which will be held Wednesdays through Sundays at 4 and 6 P.M., will extend through May 2.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Dr. William T. Pecora, director of the United States Geological Survey, has been picked to become Under Secretary of the Interior.
A State Supreme Court Justice ruled illegal yesterday the $50 fee that the city imposes for towing away cars it deems to be illegally parked.

CALCUTTA, India, April 1 -Workers dig tunnels under main roads at night so they will collapse when soldiers in trucks move down them. Children in trees and women hidden along roadways serve as lookouts and spies.
A Federal judge in Brooklyn declared a second mistrial yesterday in the case of Rocco Miraglia, charging that newspaper reports had made it impossible to grant him a fair trial.
The Board of Education has decided to permit two students to attend the screening of candidates for the job of principal of the Sheepshead Bay High School in Brooklyn.
Trading in silver coin futures began yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange with mixed reactions from thoses participating in the market.

Having read with interest your "Uneasy Riders" editorial [March 18] and being one of the unhappy straphangers who leave the house at the same time but never get to work at the same time, I should like to bring to your attention another problem which "could be avoided without additional funds."
The Chesapeake Ohio-Baltimore Ohio railroads announced yesterday they had placed in service a fleet of 35 custom-built flatcars for hauling communication and power cable.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The Nixon Administration is prepared to support and help negotiate an agreement between the United Arab Republic and Israel to reopen the Suez Canal, according to knowledgeable sources here.
PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, April 1 (AP) -- Mutiny courts-martial of 60 soldiers in this nation's tiny army have become a major issue in elections to be held this year.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The islanders of Culebra have won a 13-year-long struggle to prevent the United States Navy from using parts of their island as training targets. But it will take a few years for the Navy to leave the small Puerto Rican island.
Directors of Heublein, Inc., and the Kentucky Fried Chicken Corporation voted yesterday, at separate meetings, to approve the previously proposed merger of the two companies.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 1 -A man who said he was an Israeli Army officer defected to Lebanon yesterday. This brought to four the number of reported Israeli defections to this country in the last three months.

The city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, which has a possible budget deficiency of $40-million, has increased the total salaries for executives by $2.5-million in the last nine months, Controller Abraham D. Beame reported yesterday.

Playing a program that lasted less than an hour, Richard Johnson made his debut as a guitarist at the New York Cultural Center on Wednesday night. A native of Kansas City, where he studied with Walter Fritschy before working with Oscar Ghiglia in Paris, Mr. Johnson performed some half-dozen standard works correctly.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -Critics of the Nixon Administration's oil policies in South Vietnam are shifting the focus of their attacks.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, April 2 -- A two-day battle in the Central Highlands in which a North Vietnamese regiment stormed into a South Vietnamese fire base and then was pushed out again was reported today by the Saigon command.
PARIS, April 1 -- The dollar came under renewed pressure in Europe's money centers today despite the action taken by West Germany and Britain to lower interest rates.

The Rangers' plan to make 1,500 playoff tickets available only through a special telephone operation or through Ticketron outlets left in its wake thousands of frustrated fans, many of whom spent the night in vain at Ticketron locations.

Arlo Guthrie played a concert Wednesday evening at Carnegie Hall and made a significant move toward country music.

The trustees of the Penn Central Transportation Company informed the Federal District Court in Philadelphia yesterday that the bankrupt railroad operated at a loss of $66,344,876 in the first two months of this year.
